description:
Service Integration and Management (SIAM) is a management methodology for environments where services are sourced from multiple service providers and not just a single service provider. 

In this series we explore the SIAM Eco-system including the business case for SIAM, the benefits of the methodology, the processes involved, and the challenges to implementing and maintaining the eco-system.

This series also prepares you for the EXIN SIAM Foundation exam.

00:05:11.664 --> 00:05:15.610

managing IT services.

95
00:05:15.610 --> 00:05:21.510

00:06:18.440 --> 00:06:22.680

112
00:06:22.680 --> 00:06:27.450
This is not how I expect your

00:06:27.450 --> 00:06:28.390
But you'll see that for

114
00:06:28.390 --> 00:06:32.470
this example, in step one there

115
00:06:32.470 --> 00:06:36.590

116
00:06:36.590 --> 00:06:40.220

117
00:06:40.220 --> 00:06:42.790

125

00:07:09.500 --> 00:07:14.490

127

128
00:07:18.310 --> 00:07:20.610
Whoever that vendor may be,

129
00:07:20.610 --> 00:07:25.060

130
00:07:25.060 --> 00:07:30.800

131

132
00:07:32.700 --> 00:07:37.530

134
00:07:40.680 --> 00:07:43.610

we've got what we call multi-sourced

135
00:07:43.610 --> 00:07:48.550
environment where we've got an internal
IT structure, very minimal.

136
00:07:49.630 --> 00:07:54.513
But then what we have is a structure
there of multiple vendors.

137
00:07:54.513 --> 00:07:59.455

let's say, office and another supplier for

138
00:07:59.455 --> 00:08:01.249
maybe your financial system.

139
00:08:01.249 --> 00:08:05.519
And then another supplier for
something else and another supplier for

140
00:08:05.519 --> 00:08:06.610
something else.

141
00:08:06.610 --> 00:08:08.510
I just wanna spend a little
bit of time actually.

142
00:08:08.510 --> 00:08:12.507

spot, because I wanna spend a bit of time

143
00:08:12.507 --> 00:08:16.640

disadvantages of each of these structures.

144
00:08:18.060 --> 00:08:20.541
And let's look at
the traditional structure.

145
00:08:20.541 --> 00:08:23.851
Now by the way, I am not telling
you that any of these are right or

146
00:08:23.851 --> 00:08:25.490

147
00:08:25.490 --> 00:08:29.358
These are just the different types of
structures that we may have within

148
00:08:29.358 --> 00:08:30.138

149
00:08:30.138 --> 00:08:31.780
So let's take a look at the first one.

150
00:08:31.780 --> 00:08:38.539
The first one is our internal IT service
provider, as we might once call them.

151
00:08:38.539 --> 00:08:42.810
So we've got a lot of in-house
work that's going on there.

152
00:08:42.810 --> 00:08:45.623
What do you reckon the advantages
are Justin of that in house?

153
00:08:45.623 --> 00:08:49.779
>> So I would think the advantages here
is you kind of get to keep your eye,

154
00:08:49.779 --> 00:08:51.670
you finger on all peices of it.

155
00:08:51.670 --> 00:08:56.003
And you have more control over
what's actually happening with those

156
00:08:56.003 --> 00:08:59.297
respective subdivisions,
that would be my guess.

157
00:08:59.297 --> 00:08:59.955
>> Right.

158
00:08:59.955 --> 00:09:01.166
>> And you're looking at me-
>> [LAUGH]

159
00:09:01.166 --> 00:09:03.133
>> Sideways, like I don't know.

160
00:09:03.133 --> 00:09:08.449
And Just to clarify, we see that last
row there that we have outsourcing,

161
00:09:08.449 --> 00:09:10.620
that's just illustrative.

162
00:09:10.620 --> 00:09:13.890
There may be some of those subsections
that have no outsourcing, correct?

163
00:09:13.890 --> 00:09:16.811
>> Yes, that's right,
I mean sometimes in some organizations,

164
00:09:16.811 --> 00:09:18.389
development is done internally.

165
00:09:18.389 --> 00:09:22.614
So when we say outsourcing, what we
may mean is actually to the internal,

166
00:09:22.614 --> 00:09:26.170
sort of project teams, etc.,
software development team.

167
00:09:26.170 --> 00:09:28.390
So yes,
it could be a mixture of all of them.

168
00:09:29.550 --> 00:09:34.128
One of the advantages of this is
that you've got a response to your

169
00:09:34.128 --> 00:09:35.886
business environment.

170
00:09:35.886 --> 00:09:39.667
So when the business environment changes,
and let's face it, okay,

171
00:09:39.667 --> 00:09:43.764
there is absolutely no organization
anywhere in the world that consults with

172
00:09:43.764 --> 00:09:46.410
IT before it makes a business decision.

173
00:09:46.410 --> 00:09:50.106
Yeah, normally, if they're going to
acquire a subsidiary or something

174
00:09:50.106 --> 00:09:54.175

and then they'll tell IT afterwards.

175
00:09:54.175 --> 00:09:57.090
Yeah, so this allows us to react to that.

176
00:09:57.090 --> 00:10:01.670
It allows us to be very reactive
to the business organization.

177
00:10:01.670 --> 00:10:06.745
It also allows us to understand
the organization better as well.

178
00:10:06.745 --> 00:10:08.550
But then there are some disadvantages.

179
00:10:10.440 --> 00:10:13.842
So things like, in the same way that I
said that the organization doesn't tell us

180
00:10:13.842 --> 00:10:16.707

big decisions, well guess what?

181
00:10:16.707 --> 00:10:18.150

182
00:10:19.150 --> 00:10:23.832

decided that they no

00:10:48.910 --> 00:10:51.420

The other disadvantage to this sort of

193

00:11:11.842 --> 00:11:16.405

00:11:16.405 --> 00:11:19.880

00:11:19.880 --> 00:11:21.740

481
00:29:50.760 --> 00:29:55.530
And so really,
what we've done in this particular

482
00:29:55.530 --> 00:29:58.620
episode is we've kinda wrapped
up that introduction to SIAM.

483
00:29:58.620 --> 00:30:03.300
We've explained when it would
be useful to bring in SIAM.

484
00:30:03.300 --> 00:30:07.500
And in our next episode, we're actually
going to look at the ecosystem itself and

485
00:30:07.500 --> 00:30:09.340
what that ecosystem consists of.

486
00:30:09.340 --> 00:30:13.550
So I hope to see you in our next episode.
>> Well, thank you so much, Jo.

487
00:30:13.550 --> 00:30:17.260
I can definitely see how the service
integrators provide kind of

488
00:30:17.260 --> 00:30:23.250
a forward-facing interface that just
kind of takes away all the cares.

489
00:30:23.250 --> 00:30:24.470
I'm overgeneralizing there, Jo.

490
00:30:24.470 --> 00:30:26.820
She's giving me the sideways glance.

491
00:30:26.820 --> 00:30:29.671
But effectively, it's to reduce
the barriers to actually getting

492
00:30:29.671 --> 00:30:32.752
things done, right?
>> The sideways glance was really because

493
00:30:32.752 --> 00:30:35.646
of the fact that you
mentioned forward-facing, but

494
00:30:35.646 --> 00:30:37.520
I also need to look behind as well.

495
00:30:37.520 --> 00:30:40.250
As a service integrator,
I need to look at you.

496
00:30:40.250 --> 00:30:45.600
You are my customer, and
I need to respect you, but I also need to

497
00:30:45.600 --> 00:30:49.945
manage these guys behind me, and sometimes
that can be sorta quite chaotic, too.

498
00:30:49.945 --> 00:30:51.900
>> Well,

499
00:30:51.900 --> 00:30:56.240
I'm kind of interested to see how this all
comes together with herding cats, right?

500
00:30:56.240 --> 00:30:58.030
Those things can get
all kinds of sideways.

501
00:30:58.030 --> 00:31:01.030
So definitely stay tuned, we got more
coming at you, but for this episode,

502
00:31:01.030 --> 00:31:02.610
we're gonna go ahead and wrap it up.

503
00:31:02.610 --> 00:31:04.860
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host,

504
00:31:04.860 --> 00:31:06.720
Justin Dennison.
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

505
00:31:06.720 --> 00:31:08.567
>> And we'll see you next time.

506
00:31:08.567 --> 00:31:14.244
[MUSIC]

507
00:31:14.244 --> 00:31:17.052
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.210 --> 00:00:06.121
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:06.121 --> 00:00:08.246
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.246 --> 00:00:11.963
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.963 --> 00:00:15.570
>> Greetings everyone, and welcome back
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.570 --> 00:00:17.540
I'm your host Justin Dennison, and

6
00:00:17.540 --> 00:00:20.770
we're coming back at you with more
about SIAM, and, in particular,

7
00:00:20.770 --> 00:00:24.620
we're gonna be talking a little bit
about the ecosystem and terminology.

8
00:00:24.620 --> 00:00:27.380
And here to help us along in that
very endeavor, Ms. Jo Peacock.

9
00:00:27.380 --> 00:00:28.310
How are you doing, Jo?

10
00:00:28.310 --> 00:00:29.090
>> Absolutely great.

11
00:00:29.090 --> 00:00:29.720
Thank you, Justin.

12
00:00:29.720 --> 00:00:30.710
How are you?

13
00:00:30.710 --> 00:00:31.900
>> I am doing fantastic.

14
00:00:31.900 --> 00:00:34.170
And I do know that terminology and

15
00:00:34.170 --> 00:00:38.140
jargon can be a huge barrier to entry
when we're learning something new.

16
00:00:38.140 --> 00:00:42.210
So I guess we're gonna have to talk
about that before we get too deep

17
00:00:42.210 --> 00:00:43.180
into the weeds, right?

18
00:00:43.180 --> 00:00:45.920
>> You wanna talk about the English
language, is that what you're saying?

19
00:00:45.920 --> 00:00:49.470
>> No, no, no, I have no
expertise on the English language.

20
00:00:49.470 --> 00:00:52.787
I make up words on a regular basis.

21
00:00:52.787 --> 00:00:55.679
>> [LAUGH] Okay then, and
I only mentioned that because we just

22
00:00:55.679 --> 00:00:59.340
had a conversation about whether we
should say ecosystem or ecosystem and

23
00:00:59.340 --> 00:01:03.465
whether we should hyphenate it or
whether we shouldn't hyphenate it.

24
00:01:03.465 --> 00:01:04.742
But you know what?

25
00:01:04.742 --> 00:01:08.145
I just wanna say that us English
are a pretty flexible bunch.

26
00:01:08.145 --> 00:01:12.420
We understand that you guys spell
things slightly differently.

27
00:01:12.420 --> 00:01:14.905
I won't say wrong,
I'll just say differently.

28
00:01:14.905 --> 00:01:19.100
[LAUGH] We also understand that
some things are different,

29
00:01:19.100 --> 00:01:20.950
and we've come to a compromise.

30
00:01:20.950 --> 00:01:25.100
And we've compromised that in English,
it's ecosystem with a hyphen and

31
00:01:25.100 --> 00:01:29.060
in America, and then it's,
well, I don't know.

32
00:01:29.060 --> 00:01:30.236
I give up.

33
00:01:30.236 --> 00:01:31.610
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's what you're here for, right?

34
00:01:31.610 --> 00:01:33.170
>> Just remove the hyphen, I think.

35
00:01:33.170 --> 00:01:37.650
But I have heard people call it ecosystem,
and I'm like, I don't know, when I think

36
00:01:37.650 --> 00:01:41.650
echo, it's like you're yelling at the
cliff face and it's coming back at you.

37
00:01:41.650 --> 00:01:42.650
That has an H in it.

38
00:01:43.650 --> 00:01:46.965
>> When I say ecosystem,
it reminds me of submarines.

39
00:01:46.965 --> 00:01:50.170
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's what I'm thinking, but anyway.

40
00:01:50.170 --> 00:01:53.190
Nobody ever knows where my mind
is from one day to the next, so

41
00:01:53.190 --> 00:01:54.520
we're all right [LAUGH].

42
00:01:54.520 --> 00:01:58.290
But yeah, we're gonna look at this
SIAM ecosystem, as I would call it.

43
00:01:58.290 --> 00:02:04.480
And an ecosystem is really,
I like the word anyway.

44
00:02:04.480 --> 00:02:08.980
I like the fact that what it
actually does is it promotes

45
00:02:10.120 --> 00:02:14.050
the fact that we're not just talking
about one IT service provider.

46
00:02:14.050 --> 00:02:17.190
That we're not just talking about
one particular environment.

47
00:02:17.190 --> 00:02:21.890
We're talking about a whole sort of
living, breathing organism almost.

48
00:02:21.890 --> 00:02:26.060
Something that's going to help our
organization achieve their goals and

49
00:02:26.060 --> 00:02:27.810
achieve their visions.

50
00:02:27.810 --> 00:02:30.310
And it's not just one service provider.

51
00:02:30.310 --> 00:02:33.520
It's multiple service providers.

52
00:02:33.520 --> 00:02:36.250
So I've got a little diagram.

53
00:02:36.250 --> 00:02:40.910
I was gonna say a little picture but
a nice pretty diagram up there.

54
00:02:40.910 --> 00:02:45.280
And what you'll see is that we have, I
want you to just take a look at the middle

55
00:02:45.280 --> 00:02:49.680
for the moment and we've got customer
organization and the service integrated.

56
00:02:49.680 --> 00:02:53.890
Now, if you have been watching our
previous episodes then you'll see that in

57
00:02:53.890 --> 00:02:57.540
the last episode we discussed
the service integrator and

58
00:02:57.540 --> 00:03:01.730
who that is, or rather what that is and
what that role does.

59
00:03:01.730 --> 00:03:04.920
And now this is where I get
to put Justin on the spot

60
00:03:04.920 --> 00:03:08.580
because now I can ask Justin what he
remembers about the service integrator.

61
00:03:09.640 --> 00:03:13.360
>> Well I remember that they
are the individuals that

62
00:03:13.360 --> 00:03:17.870
interface with the customer organization,
but also with the respective services, and

63
00:03:17.870 --> 00:03:19.550
they kinda bring things together.

64
00:03:19.550 --> 00:03:23.120
They remove the barriers for

65
00:03:23.120 --> 00:03:27.920
the customers, but they also make sure
that everybody else works together on

66
00:03:27.920 --> 00:03:31.942
the other side to deliver on their
respective guarantees, right?

67
00:03:31.942 --> 00:03:36.980
Yeah, yeah, although there's one
problem that I've got with that.

68
00:03:36.980 --> 00:03:38.000
So don't look so happy.

69
00:03:38.000 --> 00:03:39.180
>> That I said it?

70
00:03:39.180 --> 00:03:40.359
I don't know.
[LAUGH]

71
00:03:40.359 --> 00:03:42.330
>> You used one word and

72
00:03:42.330 --> 00:03:44.440
I'm sure you now what word he used.

73
00:03:44.440 --> 00:03:47.960
It's the word I absolutely can't
stand when it comes to IT and

74
00:03:47.960 --> 00:03:50.519
the one thing that we
should never do in IT.

75
00:03:51.590 --> 00:03:54.520
Which is that word guarantee Justin.

76
00:03:54.520 --> 00:03:57.470
This is IT, we can't guarantee anything.

77
00:03:57.470 --> 00:03:59.935
We like to use the word ensure.

78
00:04:01.060 --> 00:04:02.780
Yeah?
Yeah, we wanna ensure.

79
00:04:02.780 --> 00:04:06.455
>> Well, I'm real bad about over
promising and under delivering.

80
00:04:06.455 --> 00:04:10.010
>> [LAUGH]
>> Maybe that's where I'm going wrong.

81
00:04:10.010 --> 00:04:10.549
>> Right, okay.

82
00:04:10.549 --> 00:04:14.320
Yeah, again, maybe it's just
down to the language type thing.

83
00:04:14.320 --> 00:04:18.980
But to me, guarantee means then that's
a promise, that's a commitment.

84
00:04:18.980 --> 00:04:21.690
And despite the fact that when we
talk about service level agreements,

85
00:04:21.690 --> 00:04:23.170
it's still a promise.

86
00:04:23.170 --> 00:04:24.130
It's still a commitment.

87
00:04:24.130 --> 00:04:29.060
And we can't 100%,
with certainty, accuracy,

88
00:04:29.060 --> 00:04:34.860
etc., we cannot promise
100% to deliver everything.

89
00:04:34.860 --> 00:04:37.017
So yeah we don't like to
use the word guarantee.

90
00:04:37.017 --> 00:04:38.177
We want to ensure.

91
00:04:38.177 --> 00:04:43.090
We want to ensure that we deliver services
to the agreed service level agreement.

92
00:04:43.090 --> 00:04:45.920
And if we can we wanna try and
exceed that but

93
00:04:45.920 --> 00:04:48.390
nevertheless we don't wanna guarantee it.

94
00:04:48.390 --> 00:04:50.500
But yeah,
you were right about everything else.

95
00:04:50.500 --> 00:04:53.765
>> Well, I think this might come down
to language semantics again, Jo.

96
00:04:53.765 --> 00:04:57.832
Cuz where I'm from,
guarantees aren't necessarily always 100%.

97
00:04:57.832 --> 00:05:00.230
>> That's not semantics.

98
00:05:00.230 --> 00:05:01.685
That's just wrong.

99
00:05:01.685 --> 00:05:03.375
>> [LAUGH] That's colloquialisms, Jo.

100
00:05:03.375 --> 00:05:05.220
[LAUGH]
>> Is that what it is?

101
00:05:05.220 --> 00:05:05.750
Okay, then.

102
00:05:05.750 --> 00:05:10.490
>> That's kinda like, where I'm from, when
I say a couple, that could be 2 up to 600.

103
00:05:10.490 --> 00:05:11.020
>> Actually,

104
00:05:11.020 --> 00:05:14.350
I'm okay with that one as well because
that's how I was brought up, right?

105
00:05:14.350 --> 00:05:17.820
Just a couple, it's like when I used
to get sent down to the store when I

106
00:05:17.820 --> 00:05:19.150
was a little kid, you know?

107
00:05:19.150 --> 00:05:21.960
You can get yourself a couple of sweets or
candy.

108
00:05:21.960 --> 00:05:23.430
That meant a bag full about 20.

109
00:05:23.430 --> 00:05:24.220
Yeah, that's fine.

110
00:05:24.220 --> 00:05:28.160
>> Yeah, so there's some ambiguity,
but I get what you're saying, right?

111
00:05:28.160 --> 00:05:31.500
You need to pick language
that appropriately

112
00:05:31.500 --> 00:05:34.860
provides your intentions, right?

113
00:05:34.860 --> 00:05:39.980
Without setting inappropriate
expectations, I guess.

114
00:05:39.980 --> 00:05:41.780
>> Right, it's about expectation setting.

115
00:05:41.780 --> 00:05:45.400
And also I just wanna remind
you that this is an accredited,

116
00:05:45.400 --> 00:05:48.350
it's a certified class and
we've got an exam.

117
00:05:48.350 --> 00:05:51.580
And you know what,
just a little bit of an exam tip here.

118
00:05:51.580 --> 00:05:55.950
If ever you see the word
guarantee in an exam answer,

119
00:05:55.950 --> 00:05:57.920
run away kicking and screaming very,

120
00:05:57.920 --> 00:06:02.540
very quickly from that answer,
because we can't guarantee anything.

121
00:06:02.540 --> 00:06:06.080
So it is important sometimes
the language that we use.

122
00:06:06.080 --> 00:06:08.640
But that service integrator,
you're right, on everything else.

123
00:06:08.640 --> 00:06:12.938
That is the role that acts
as the integration layer.

124
00:06:12.938 --> 00:06:15.700
That acts as the coordinator almost, for

125
00:06:15.700 --> 00:06:18.645
underneath you'll see that we've
got all of these service providers.

126
00:06:18.645 --> 00:06:20.594
We've got a couple in
this particular example.

127
00:06:20.594 --> 00:06:24.851
We've got a couple of internal service
providers and we've got three or

128
00:06:24.851 --> 00:06:29.180
a couple should we say of
external service providers, okay?

129
00:06:29.180 --> 00:06:35.940
But what we also have then, is that
integrator that acts as that translator.

130
00:06:35.940 --> 00:06:42.010
It's the relationship between the customer
organization and the service providers.

131
00:06:42.010 --> 00:06:45.980
We talk about retained capabilities
within the customer organization as well.

132
00:06:45.980 --> 00:06:48.341
We're not taking away
anything that they do.

133
00:06:48.341 --> 00:06:50.020
That's the one thing we don't want to do.

134
00:06:50.020 --> 00:06:54.660
But what we want to do is
facilitate the business processes.

135
00:06:54.660 --> 00:07:00.370
And therefore we want to deliver
value to all of those business units.

136
00:07:00.370 --> 00:07:03.660
So we don't have five.

137
00:07:03.660 --> 00:07:05.210
We've got five business units there.

138
00:07:05.210 --> 00:07:10.060
We don't have five contracts with each,
one with each business unit.

139
00:07:10.060 --> 00:07:11.580
We will have one.

140
00:07:11.580 --> 00:07:15.400
Well, it depends on whether the service
integrator is internal or external.

141
00:07:15.400 --> 00:07:16.320
But in this instance,

142
00:07:16.320 --> 00:07:20.450
I'm guessing internal because we got
some internal service providers there.

143
00:07:20.450 --> 00:07:23.670
So we'll have one agreement
with the service integrator and

144
00:07:23.670 --> 00:07:29.160
the service integrator looks after all
of the agreements that lay underneath.

145
00:07:29.160 --> 00:07:33.060
So between the internal and
the external service providers.

146
00:07:33.060 --> 00:07:35.960
And so this service integrator
takes that accountability.

147
00:07:35.960 --> 00:07:39.450
And what we're doing is we're just
taking that away from the business and

148
00:07:39.450 --> 00:07:41.780
just saying simply, leave it to us.

149
00:07:41.780 --> 00:07:42.620
We'll deal with that.

150
00:07:42.620 --> 00:07:44.331
We'll handle that for you.

151
00:07:44.331 --> 00:07:47.301
You don't need to worry about it.

152
00:07:47.301 --> 00:07:49.181
What's happened in, and

153
00:07:49.181 --> 00:07:53.796
I come across this in a lot of
organizations that I consult with,

154
00:07:53.796 --> 00:07:59.450
that I go on site with, and what tends
to have happened is that traditionally.

155
00:07:59.450 --> 00:08:02.467
>> We have this internal
service provider and

156
00:08:02.467 --> 00:08:07.244
the internal service provider simply
can't keep up with demand and

157
00:08:07.244 --> 00:08:12.269
what tends to happen is that those
business units that you see up there,

158
00:08:12.269 --> 00:08:18.430
they'll go off somewhere themselves and
they will approach suppliers directly.

159
00:08:18.430 --> 00:08:22.950
Because lets face it, everybody
has some knowledge of IT nowadays.

160
00:08:22.950 --> 00:08:25.360
We all go out and buy our cellphones.

161
00:08:25.360 --> 00:08:26.910
We've all got PCs at home.

162
00:08:26.910 --> 00:08:28.610
We've all got tablets at home.

163
00:08:28.610 --> 00:08:33.810
We've all got quite a good knowledge
of IT not necessarily of IT for

164
00:08:33.810 --> 00:08:34.650
the organization.

165
00:08:34.650 --> 00:08:39.710
I mean, I don't expect everybody to
be DBAs and I don't expect regular

166
00:08:39.710 --> 00:08:45.130
business individuals to understand
cybersecurity, that sort of thing.

167
00:08:45.130 --> 00:08:49.900
But nevertheless,
they have a fairly good knowledge of IT.

168
00:08:49.900 --> 00:08:55.580
So imagine what happens when a business
unit approaches the internal IT service

169
00:08:55.580 --> 00:09:01.900
provider and they say, right,
we like an application to do x, y and zed.

170
00:09:01.900 --> 00:09:05.680
Or X, Y and
Z as you might say in your language

171
00:09:05.680 --> 00:09:09.640
now that we're talking languages and they
approach the internal service provider.

172
00:09:09.640 --> 00:09:12.770
And the internal service provider,
depending on who they are.

173
00:09:12.770 --> 00:09:15.903
And if they're in government,
for instance, it's not so

174
00:09:15.903 --> 00:09:18.170
easy just to bring something in tomorrow.

175
00:09:18.170 --> 00:09:22.318
And what happens is the internal service
provider kinda scratches their chin and

176
00:09:22.318 --> 00:09:24.210
looks and goes well, you know what?

177
00:09:24.210 --> 00:09:26.050
I can do that in about, I don't know.

178
00:09:26.050 --> 00:09:30.010
Maybe two years or so,
what's gonna happen?

179
00:09:30.010 --> 00:09:34.190
Well, the business unit, they're gonna
outside and that's exactly what they do.

180
00:09:34.190 --> 00:09:36.134
And they'll go outside, but

181
00:09:36.134 --> 00:09:39.800
they go outside with limited
IT knowledge themselves.

182
00:09:39.800 --> 00:09:44.069
So they start negotiating contracts
with external service providers.

183
00:09:45.320 --> 00:09:48.923
Number one, the business unit
might know what they want.

184
00:09:48.923 --> 00:09:54.030
But they don't necessarily
know what our IT looks like.

185
00:09:54.030 --> 00:09:55.780
They don't know what's
on the infrastructure.

186
00:09:55.780 --> 00:09:59.020
They don't know anything about
the security of our infrastructure.

187
00:09:59.020 --> 00:10:05.780
They don't know how our infrastructure is
setup and what our service look like, etc.

188
00:10:05.780 --> 00:10:09.732
They don't know even basic things
like car operating system and

189
00:10:09.732 --> 00:10:13.406
what firewalls we have in place,
one of that sort of thing.

190
00:10:13.406 --> 00:10:17.970
But nevertheless, they're gonna go away
and they're gonna negotiate a contract

191
00:10:17.970 --> 00:10:21.200
directly from the business
unit to the supplier.

192
00:10:21.200 --> 00:10:24.285
They negotiate this directly
with that supplier and

193
00:10:24.285 --> 00:10:29.480
that supplier then releases
an application onto our infrastructure

194
00:10:30.720 --> 00:10:34.340
bypassing all of our firewall,
bypassing just about everything that

195
00:10:34.340 --> 00:10:38.810
weâ€™ve put in place which is a complete
exposure for our infrastructure.

196
00:10:38.810 --> 00:10:42.420
You can just imagine the sort
of chaos that ensues and

197
00:10:42.420 --> 00:10:47.330
also the danger and the risk that
that our poses to our infrastructure.

198
00:10:48.460 --> 00:10:52.320
Well, that happens quite often,
believe or not and I have been into some

199
00:10:52.320 --> 00:10:56.810
organizations fairly recently, in fact,
where exactly that has happened.

200
00:10:56.810 --> 00:10:59.870
And they've ended up in a bit of,
well, I'm gonna say,

201
00:10:59.870 --> 00:11:01.520
in a bit of a pickle to be honest.

202
00:11:01.520 --> 00:11:06.210
Because what you've done is where you've
got these external service providers,

203
00:11:06.210 --> 00:11:09.350

37
00:01:57.920 --> 00:02:03.480

38
00:02:03.480 --> 00:02:06.990

39
00:02:06.990 --> 00:02:09.789

59
00:03:38.510 --> 00:03:43.230

60
00:03:43.230 --> 00:03:46.270

00:25:53.814 --> 00:26:00.090
to another to another to another, and
then it's gone back to the customer fixed.

414
00:26:00.090 --> 00:26:03.695
The customer doesn't need to see
what's happened in the background.

415
00:26:03.695 --> 00:26:08.150
We've still got to manage that
because if we don't, trust me.

416
00:26:08.150 --> 00:26:11.250
And I've known Justin well enough to
know that if I pass something to him,

417
00:26:11.250 --> 00:26:13.657
he might turn around to me and
say that's not my problem.

418
00:26:13.657 --> 00:26:14.482
I'm not dealing with that.

419
00:26:14.482 --> 00:26:16.030
And he's gonna pass it back to me.

420
00:26:17.160 --> 00:26:19.660
And at the same time,
if Justin gives [LAUGH] something to me,

421
00:26:19.660 --> 00:26:23.280
then I'm gonna say, nope,
it's not happening.

422
00:26:23.280 --> 00:26:25.070
And I'm gonna give it back to him.

423
00:26:25.070 --> 00:26:26.820
Somebody's gotta manage that.

424
00:26:26.820 --> 00:26:30.474
Somebody has got to come along [LAUGH] and
say, you two need to work together.

425
00:26:31.670 --> 00:26:34.650
And that's exactly what has got to happen.

426
00:26:34.650 --> 00:26:37.060
And this is why the SIAM ecosystem, and

427
00:26:37.060 --> 00:26:40.290
that service integrator role,
is so important because

428
00:26:40.290 --> 00:26:45.400
that service integrator role is the one
that acts as the voice of reason.

429
00:26:45.400 --> 00:26:51.270
The one that simply lays out exactly
what should happen in certain instances.

430
00:26:52.690 --> 00:26:56.120
So do you think that the service
integrator role, right, and

431
00:26:56.120 --> 00:26:58.660
it's gonna be a group of people, do you
think that they need to be technical

432
00:26:58.660 --> 00:27:01.810
people?
>> I would expect that they would need to

433
00:27:01.810 --> 00:27:02.650
be technical people.

434
00:27:02.650 --> 00:27:05.560
But they also need to have
a certain amount of people skills.

435
00:27:05.560 --> 00:27:09.680
Because I know a bunch of highly technical
people that would not serve as great

436
00:27:09.680 --> 00:27:12.190
moderators between individuals.
>> [LAUGH] Right.

437
00:27:12.190 --> 00:27:13.030
>> They would actually

438
00:27:13.030 --> 00:27:16.370
exacerbate the situation,
and choose a side.

439
00:27:16.370 --> 00:27:20.180
And, I got him all ramped up now,
and then leave, right.

440
00:27:20.180 --> 00:27:21.920
>> Right, yeah, exactly.

441
00:27:21.920 --> 00:27:25.710
We do need to have interpersonal skills
[LAUGH] in that particular role.

442
00:27:25.710 --> 00:27:29.570
But you've gotta have a technical bias,
as well, in that particular role.

443
00:27:29.570 --> 00:27:31.610
Sometimes, in some ecosystems,

444
00:27:31.610 --> 00:27:35.450
it's the service desk that actually
act as the service integrator role.

445
00:27:36.590 --> 00:27:37.970
If you're using a service desk,

446
00:27:37.970 --> 00:27:41.670
you have to make sure that the service
desk are empowered to make decisions.

447
00:27:41.670 --> 00:27:45.626
Because we're talking about contracts
with external service providers.

448
00:27:45.626 --> 00:27:50.059
So it has to be somebody that's got
enough technical knowledge to be

449
00:27:50.059 --> 00:27:54.116
able to tell when somebody just
doesn't wanna do something.

450
00:27:54.116 --> 00:27:58.591
It's also gotta be enough
technical knowledge to be able to

451
00:27:58.591 --> 00:28:02.617
understand where the lines
of responsibility lie and

452
00:28:02.617 --> 00:28:06.940
on what side of the line
a particular issue falls.

453
00:28:06.940 --> 00:28:10.090
But it's also got to be in somebody
with enough sort of, as you mentioned,

454
00:28:10.090 --> 00:28:12.710
their interpersonal skills
to be able to mediate, and

455
00:28:12.710 --> 00:28:17.490
to be able to negotiate with
the service providers, too.

456
00:28:17.490 --> 00:28:21.200
So it has to be somebody
that can fulfill both roles.

457
00:28:21.200 --> 00:28:25.460
But they certainly do have to have
a certain amount of technical bias.

458
00:28:25.460 --> 00:28:28.520
They have to be able to understand
what's being said to them.

459
00:28:28.520 --> 00:28:33.110
And that leads us into this last
particular factor on this driver for

460
00:28:33.110 --> 00:28:35.230
our sourcing landscape.

461
00:28:35.230 --> 00:28:37.480
And that are inflexible contracts.

462
00:28:39.680 --> 00:28:45.070
Justin and I have had discussions about
inflexible contracts in the past.

463
00:28:45.070 --> 00:28:49.217
And the fact that certain,
especially within government,

464
00:28:49.217 --> 00:28:53.781
certain contracts are negotiated for
quite a long period of time.

465
00:28:53.781 --> 00:28:59.004
Because the actual process of negotiating
a contract, certainly in government,

466
00:28:59.004 --> 00:29:03.194
can take anywhere up to two years
to go through the tender process.

467
00:29:03.194 --> 00:29:08.147
And that can be quite a long
process just in itself just

468
00:29:08.147 --> 00:29:12.070
to negotiate a particular contract.

469
00:29:12.070 --> 00:29:15.780
Unfortunately, the tendency is, then,
that we negotiate a contract for

470
00:29:15.780 --> 00:29:19.570
a long period of time because it's
taken two years to get to this point.

471
00:29:19.570 --> 00:29:22.730
So we're gonna negotiate a contract for
at least five years.

472
00:29:22.730 --> 00:29:25.450
Now, of course,
a lot can change in five years.

473
00:29:25.450 --> 00:29:28.480
And this is where we bring
in this inflexible contract.

474
00:29:28.480 --> 00:29:31.630
Bearing in mind that SIAM
came from the government.

475
00:29:31.630 --> 00:29:33.250
Very similar to ITIL.

476
00:29:33.250 --> 00:29:38.270
So SIAM came from that
particular environment

477
00:29:38.270 --> 00:29:43.290
where we quite often will end up with
inflexible contracts, contracts that

478
00:29:44.790 --> 00:29:49.790
do not fit the needs of
the organization any more.

479
00:29:49.790 --> 00:29:52.485
They did when they were negotiated, and

480
00:29:52.485 --> 00:29:56.510
at that point in time that they
were signed, they were great.

481
00:29:56.510 --> 00:30:00.470
But now technology's changed, our
service level targets have changed, and

482
00:30:00.470 --> 00:30:03.360
our requirements have changed
within the organization.

483
00:30:03.360 --> 00:30:05.490
But the contracts still remain the same.

484
00:30:07.240 --> 00:30:11.956
What I've seen happen, and
I have seen this, I have witnessed this

485
00:30:11.956 --> 00:30:16.175
with my own two eyes,
is that in this particular situation,

486
00:30:16.175 --> 00:30:19.569
instead of trying to
renegotiate the contract,

487
00:30:19.569 --> 00:30:24.203
what happens is a new contract is
then negotiated with a completely

488
00:30:24.203 --> 00:30:29.540
different supplier to make up for
the shortcomings in that first contract.

489
00:30:29.540 --> 00:30:34.482
And again we end up in that situation
where we are just kind of bringing more

490
00:30:34.482 --> 00:30:38.860
suppliers into the mix and
just compounding the situation.

491
00:30:38.860 --> 00:30:39.727
And Justin's grinning at me.

492
00:30:39.727 --> 00:30:42.750
And you're gonna say that you've
seen exactly the same thing happen.

493
00:30:42.750 --> 00:30:44.330
>> I'm having bad nightmares and

494
00:30:44.330 --> 00:30:44.990
flashbacks.

495
00:30:44.990 --> 00:30:48.606
I'm about to break into a cold sweat
because this it doesn't seem like

496
00:30:48.606 --> 00:30:49.718
this should happen.

497
00:30:49.718 --> 00:30:53.266
You're like, wait a minute, you
negotiated a contract five years ago for

498
00:30:53.266 --> 00:30:57.211
something you're supposed to deliver a
year from now that you didn't actually get

499
00:30:57.211 --> 00:30:58.986
to start working on until last year?

500
00:30:58.986 --> 00:31:03.446
Yes.
And that's just how things roll.

501
00:31:03.446 --> 00:31:07.175
And I have also seen, well,
we brought in this other person,

502
00:31:07.175 --> 00:31:11.694
or this other whatever it may be,
this other company, to fix this one issue

503
00:31:11.694 --> 00:31:16.850
that we didn't really think about during
the original contract negotiations.

504
00:31:16.850 --> 00:31:20.830
And now you're like, well, am I supposed
to work with that person, or am I?

505
00:31:21.980 --> 00:31:25.480
You kinda get this weird flux of,
okay, I'm kinda lost,

506
00:31:25.480 --> 00:31:29.060
if it's not managed appropriately.
>> Right, and I have seen contracts that

507
00:31:29.060 --> 00:31:32.680
have been negotiated for things like
printing services, for instance.

508
00:31:32.680 --> 00:31:34.261
So the contract was negotiated,

509
00:31:34.261 --> 00:31:38.280
it took nearly two years to negotiate the
contract, and it was finally negotiated.

510
00:31:38.280 --> 00:31:41.598
It went out to tender, etc.

511
00:31:41.598 --> 00:31:42.930
It was signed.

512
00:31:42.930 --> 00:31:47.510
And then, we realize that actually
printing is no longer required because

513
00:31:47.510 --> 00:31:52.090
what's happening is that the entire
government department is then moving

514
00:31:52.090 --> 00:31:55.434
toward paperless printing,
moving toward PDFs, and

515
00:31:55.434 --> 00:31:59.670
scanning is actually more important
than the printing itself.

516
00:31:59.670 --> 00:32:03.970
But because the initial contract was so
inflexible, what happens is that you wound

517
00:32:03.970 --> 00:32:09.070
up then having to go through the entire
invitation to tender process again

518
00:32:09.070 --> 00:32:15.180
because what you need to do is negotiate a
new contract to look at scanning services.

519
00:32:15.180 --> 00:32:20.290
Well, and that's gonna take another
two years by the way, by which time

520
00:32:20.290 --> 00:32:24.990
In two year's time, then that particular
issue may well have moved on.

521
00:32:24.990 --> 00:32:28.200
It may well have evolved, and
we might have something else.

522
00:32:28.200 --> 00:32:32.000
And so what you're doing is every
time we're negotiating a new contract

523
00:32:32.000 --> 00:32:33.890
on top of the other one.

524
00:32:33.890 --> 00:32:38.020
And then, by the time we've negotiated
maybe our third contract to fix

525
00:32:38.020 --> 00:32:42.020
the problems in the previous contract,
then that first contact's now up for

526
00:32:42.020 --> 00:32:43.260
renewal and it's expired.

527
00:32:44.510 --> 00:32:48.140
But we've gotta be careful then how we
renew that first contract because it might

528
00:32:48.140 --> 00:32:52.120
impact the other two contracts
that we've got in place right now.

529
00:32:52.120 --> 00:32:55.640
You end up in a mess, it ends up in chaos.

530
00:32:55.640 --> 00:32:57.060
And more importantly,

531
00:32:57.060 --> 00:33:01.520
from a service provider perspective,
you just wanna run away screaming,

532
00:33:01.520 --> 00:33:05.510
because you've got yourself into
a position that you can't get out of.

533
00:33:06.980 --> 00:33:11.080
This is why the SIAM
ecosystem is important.

534
00:33:11.080 --> 00:33:14.090
The service integrator role

535
00:33:14.090 --> 00:33:18.320
is the role that manages
the complexity between the contracts.

536
00:33:18.320 --> 00:33:23.240
The service integrator will always,
is the role, a group of people that will

537
00:33:23.240 --> 00:33:28.690
step in and say, no, no, no,
no we cannot have inflexible contracts.

538
00:33:28.690 --> 00:33:33.150
And as each contract comes up for renewal,
then we're looking at the flexibility,

539
00:33:33.150 --> 00:33:37.160
the contract, and we're looking at the
purpose of that contract, understanding

540
00:33:37.160 --> 00:33:44.430
that IT just evolves incredibly
quickly in the 21st century.

541
00:33:44.430 --> 00:33:48.140
So what we've done really in this last
episode is we've look at our second

542
00:33:48.140 --> 00:33:54.770
driver, and that's a driver for
implementing the SIAM ecosystem.

543
00:33:54.770 --> 00:33:58.160
And in our next episode,
episode three of our mini-series,

544
00:33:58.160 --> 00:34:01.680
then we're going to be looking
at our next driver for

545
00:34:01.680 --> 00:34:04.810
implementing the SIAM ecosystem,
and that's going to be operational

546
00:34:04.810 --> 00:34:07.230
effectiveness.
>> Effectiveness,

547
00:34:07.230 --> 00:34:11.040
I'm pretty sure that one's going to be
an interesting set of conversations.

548
00:34:11.040 --> 00:34:15.230
But you'll just have to come on back and
see if that proves true.

549
00:34:15.230 --> 00:34:16.630
But we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

550
00:34:16.630 --> 00:34:20.250
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Justin Dennison.

551
00:34:20.250 --> 00:34:21.160
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

552
00:34:21.160 --> 00:34:21.722
>> And we'll see you next time.

553
00:34:23.440 --> 00:34:29.328
[MUSIC]

554
00:34:29.328 --> 00:34:32.168
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

>> Yes it does.

27
00:01:11.050 --> 00:01:13.360
>> Well, what can I say, anyway [LAUGH].

28
00:01:13.360 --> 00:01:18.115
What we're gonna be looking at,
we're in part three of our little

29
00:01:18.115 --> 00:01:23.580
mini-series here where we're looking
at drives for implementing SIAM, and

30
00:01:23.580 --> 00:01:28.770
so in this particular episode we're going
to be looking at the driver of operational

31
00:01:28.770 --> 00:01:34.260
efficiencies and effectiveness as well
as a driver for implementing SIAM.

32
00:01:34.260 --> 00:01:36.780
So I hope you're prepared for
that, Justin.

33
00:01:36.780 --> 00:01:39.620
>> Well I would like to say that I am, but

34
00:01:39.620 --> 00:01:43.635
you never know when Jo's involved,
so I'm gonna say yes.

35
00:01:43.635 --> 00:01:46.670
>> [LAUGH]
>> With full recognition that I

36
00:01:46.670 --> 00:01:50.530
may just think that I'm prepared and then
I'm actually just horribly unprepared.

37
00:01:51.680 --> 00:01:52.770
>> Well, I don't know what to say now.

38
00:01:52.770 --> 00:01:55.605
>> [LAUGH]
>> You never know when I'm involved, okay?

39
00:01:55.605 --> 00:01:56.145
Ok, right.

40
00:01:56.145 --> 00:02:00.135
So now is the time when I put
Justin through the ringer.

41
00:02:00.135 --> 00:02:02.525
But, okay, he set himself up for this one.

42
00:02:02.525 --> 00:02:08.465
And so, in our last two episodes we looked
at the reasons why the drivers behind,

43
00:02:08.465 --> 00:02:11.435
or evolving,
I was going to say implementing.

44
00:02:11.435 --> 00:02:14.505
But evolving to the SIAM ecosystem.

45
00:02:14.505 --> 00:02:18.910
There's a reason by the way,
why I sort of corrected myself.

46
00:02:18.910 --> 00:02:21.560
You don't just implement SIAM ecosystem,

47
00:02:21.560 --> 00:02:25.090
it's not something that you can just sort
of open the book, it's not plug and play.

48
00:02:26.160 --> 00:02:28.590
You can't just open a book and
read through some theory and

49
00:02:28.590 --> 00:02:32.050
say that's gonna work for me,
I think I will implement that.

50
00:02:32.050 --> 00:02:33.430
This is an evolution.

51
00:02:33.430 --> 00:02:36.430
And most organizations, and
we'll look at this in a later episode, but

52
00:02:36.430 --> 00:02:41.660
most organizations that move to
the SIAM ecosystem are moving from

53
00:02:41.660 --> 00:02:46.820
an ITIL based methodology,
an ITIL based framework.

54
00:02:46.820 --> 00:02:52.090
So they've already got a structure in
place for managing their IT services.

55
00:02:52.090 --> 00:02:56.920
But what they find is that that structure
is not a comprehensive enough to

56
00:02:56.920 --> 00:03:00.630
deal with the complexities
of the SIAM ecosystem.

57
00:03:00.630 --> 00:03:05.950
As we know the SIAM
ecosystem is a system for

58
00:03:05.950 --> 00:03:09.229
delivering services,
delivering value to customers.

59
00:03:10.530 --> 00:03:14.850
But using more than one service provider.

60
00:03:14.850 --> 00:03:17.150
That's pretty much
the norm nowadays anyway.

61
00:03:17.150 --> 00:03:19.990
This is not something that's unusual.

62
00:03:19.990 --> 00:03:24.950
So whereas the ideal framework
gives us a huge amount of benefit.

63
00:03:24.950 --> 00:03:29.730
It gives us efficiencies and effectiveness
in service delivery, delivering value to

64
00:03:29.730 --> 00:03:35.340
our customers for an internal service
provider and a single service provider.

65
00:03:35.340 --> 00:03:41.470
However, what ITIL doesn't
give us is the efficiencies

66
00:03:41.470 --> 00:03:46.612
that are required to be able to
manage multiple service providers.

67
00:03:46.612 --> 00:03:50.940
And so the SIAM ecosystem is something
that we would evolve generally

68
00:03:50.940 --> 00:03:52.870
from an ITIL based framework.

69
00:03:52.870 --> 00:03:56.490
Into this SIAM ecosystem
because it gives us a way,

70
00:03:56.490 --> 00:04:02.880
it allows us to consider
the multi-vendor service provider.

71
00:04:02.880 --> 00:04:07.500
Where we are managing across
multi-platforms, and multi-vendors

72
00:04:07.500 --> 00:04:12.289
in order to deliver services, and
in order deliver value to our end users.

73
00:04:13.460 --> 00:04:18.660
So why would we choose to move from
a methodology say a framework like ITIL,

74
00:04:18.660 --> 00:04:23.030
or maybe from an ISO 20,000
environment into SIAM?

75
00:04:23.030 --> 00:04:25.490
Well we've already looked at two drivers,

76
00:04:25.490 --> 00:04:31.090
we've looked at the external
sourcing landscape as we called it.

77
00:04:31.090 --> 00:04:35.570
And we also looked at satisfaction
as well, customer satisfaction and

78
00:04:35.570 --> 00:04:37.260
service satisfaction.

79
00:04:37.260 --> 00:04:39.600
And now we're gonna look
at our third driver.

80
00:04:39.600 --> 00:04:43.340
And bear it in mind that
a driver is the reason why,

81
00:04:43.340 --> 00:04:47.260
why would we move to SIAM as an ecosystem,

82
00:04:47.260 --> 00:04:51.500
as a way of managing our services,
and a way of delivering our services.

83
00:04:51.500 --> 00:04:52.660
Well, why?

84
00:04:52.660 --> 00:04:56.430
Maybe because we want to improve

courses that will cover each of
these steps in a lot more detail.

368
00:21:51.360 --> 00:21:54.630
They go into a lot more detail
about each particular step.

369
00:21:54.630 --> 00:21:57.770
So whilst here we've
just given an overview.

370
00:21:57.770 --> 00:22:02.370
This is what we need for
our SIAM foundation material and

371
00:22:02.370 --> 00:22:06.810
to ensure that you can get
through the SIAM foundation exam.

372
00:22:08.080 --> 00:22:12.650
But we go into this in a lot more
depth in other series, don't worry.

373
00:22:12.650 --> 00:22:15.160
You're not gonna be left out.
>> That

374
00:22:15.160 --> 00:22:18.250
actually soothes my heart a little
bit because I was getting scared,

375
00:22:18.250 --> 00:22:19.840
because I knew you were gonna test me-
>> [LAUGH]

376
00:22:19.840 --> 00:22:21.000
>> At the end of this.

377
00:22:21.000 --> 00:22:22.010
Which reminds me,

378
00:22:22.010 --> 00:22:24.990
where are we going from here again?
>> We're going to be looking at

379
00:22:24.990 --> 00:22:26.600
the different structures with SIAM.

380
00:22:26.600 --> 00:22:27.870
So we're going to be looking at,

381
00:22:27.870 --> 00:22:30.800
as service integrators
>> In our next episode we're gonna

382
00:22:30.800 --> 00:22:35.750
be looking at internal service integrators
versus external service integrators and

383
00:22:35.750 --> 00:22:40.510
hybrid service integrators as well.
>> That's still a lot coming at you, so

384
00:22:40.510 --> 00:22:42.135
you should definitely come back.

385
00:22:42.135 --> 00:22:44.730
I'm getting kind of exited,
I didn't think I would be, but

386
00:22:44.730 --> 00:22:47.560
I am getting kind of exited to know
more and hopefully you are as well.

387
00:22:47.560 --> 00:22:49.830
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

388
00:22:49.830 --> 00:22:52.910
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Justin Dennison.

389
00:22:52.910 --> 00:22:53.790
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

390
00:22:53.790 --> 00:22:54.370
>> And we'll see you next time.

391
00:22:54.370 --> 00:23:01.678
[MUSIC]

392
00:23:01.678 --> 00:23:04.493
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: The service integrator layer of the SIAM eco-system is explained and a deeper delve into the eco-system configuration with an internal service integrator.
episodes.title: Service Integrators - External Service Integrator
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.200 --> 00:00:03.208
Welcome to ITPROTV,

2
00:00:03.208 --> 00:00:08.392
I'm your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:08.392 --> 00:00:11.940
You're watching ITPROTV.

4
00:00:11.940 --> 00:00:15.984
>> Greetings everyone and welcome back
to another exciting episode of ITPROTV.

5
00:00:15.984 --> 00:00:17.085
I'm your host Justin Dennison.

6
00:00:17.085 --> 00:00:19.697
And we're continuing on with
our SIAM Foundation and

7
00:00:19.697 --> 00:00:22.607
we're gonna be looking at
external service integrators.

8
00:00:22.607 --> 00:00:25.935
I think I said all of those words
correctly, but I'm sure I'll know very

9
00:00:25.935 --> 00:00:29.475
quickly, because we have a very
special guest in house with us today.

10
00:00:29.475 --> 00:00:30.940
Ms. Jo Peacock, how do you do today Jo?

11
00:00:30.940 --> 00:00:32.670
>> Absolutely great, thank you Justin.

12
00:00:32.670 --> 00:00:33.420
How are you?

13
00:00:33.420 --> 00:00:37.020
>> I am doing fantastic, and you know,
we've been working along in this series,

14
00:00:37.020 --> 00:00:40.584
and now, we're actually gonna be talking
about these service integrators.

15
00:00:40.584 --> 00:00:44.960
There's been several questions in my mind
about what do these actually look like?

16
00:00:44.960 --> 00:00:49.130
How did they manage all their jobs also,
I'm scared, because I thought it would be

17
00:00:49.130 --> 00:00:53.190
a cool job, and
then it seems like a very complicated job.

18
00:00:53.190 --> 00:00:57.419
But external service integrators,
these are people that

19
00:00:57.419 --> 00:01:02.434
are helping a company with employing
the SIAM methodology, Right?

20
00:01:02.434 --> 00:01:06.302
>> Not necessarily employing it,
but certainly managing it.

21
00:01:06.302 --> 00:01:09.399
So if you remember we've
got three layers to SIAM.

22
00:01:09.399 --> 00:01:12.454
And those three layers that
we had were customer layer,

23
00:01:12.454 --> 00:01:17.370
then we have a service integrator layer,
and then we have our service providers.

24
00:01:17.370 --> 00:01:22.260
And in fact we've actually got a slide,
just to simplify that three layers.

25
00:01:22.260 --> 00:01:25.010
And, there we go,
[LAUGH] right in front of us now.

26
00:01:25.010 --> 00:01:28.160
So our customer organization with
their retained capabilities and

27
00:01:28.160 --> 00:01:29.420
we'll look at that in a moment.

28
00:01:29.420 --> 00:01:31.811
And then we've got our
service integrator there.

29
00:01:31.811 --> 00:01:35.920
And, as I said, we've got these
service providers underneath.

30
00:01:35.920 --> 00:01:38.490
Now, what we'll do is, we could,

31
00:01:38.490 --> 00:01:43.140
we've got various options in
terms of our service integrator.

32
00:01:43.140 --> 00:01:48.280
We could keep our service
integrator internal, we could go

33
00:01:49.520 --> 00:01:54.170
outside, and we could have
an external service integrator.

34
00:01:54.170 --> 00:01:58.576
We could have a hybrid,
which is a mixture of both internal and

35
00:01:58.576 --> 00:02:04.110
external service integrator, or we could
have what we call a lead supplier.

36
00:02:04.110 --> 00:02:06.547
And over the next few episodes, so

37
00:02:06.547 --> 00:02:11.265
we're gonna have another mini
series in this particular series.

38
00:02:11.265 --> 00:02:15.315
And over the next few episodes,
we're going to look at those four options.

39
00:02:15.315 --> 00:02:20.334
And we're gonna look at the pros and cons
of each particular option, so here we've

40
00:02:20.334 --> 00:02:25.083
got our external service integrator and
that is an outsourced organization.

41
00:02:25.083 --> 00:02:30.086
It's external to
the customer organization.

42
00:02:30.086 --> 00:02:34.166
There's a few things that really I wanna
mention, a few points that we've got to

43
00:02:34.166 --> 00:02:38.030
bring out here when we look at
external service integrators.

44
00:02:38.030 --> 00:02:42.396
An External Service Integrator,
is an integrator that is just simply well,

45
00:02:42.396 --> 00:02:45.320
as I said,
are external to the organization.

46
00:02:45.320 --> 00:02:50.380
And so, what that means is,
that we are handing over the management

47
00:02:50.380 --> 00:02:55.450
of all of those other service
providers to somebody external to us.

48
00:02:56.980 --> 00:03:01.348
This can happen in a number of,
well, for a number of reasons.

49
00:03:01.348 --> 00:03:06.223
One of those reasons being that maybe
we're a very small organization, but

50
00:03:06.223 --> 00:03:11.171
we've got a lot of suppliers, because
we've got a lot of bespoke software,

51
00:03:11.171 --> 00:03:15.060
bespoke applications,
tailor-made applications.

52
00:03:15.060 --> 00:03:17.510
We've got a lot of
specialist applications.

53
00:03:17.510 --> 00:03:21.943
And therefore, we're going to
employ somebody within an IT shop,

54
00:03:21.943 --> 00:03:25.227
as you might call it,
to manage all of that for us.

55
00:03:25.227 --> 00:03:30.195
Or another reason is that we might be
a huge organization, global organization,

56
00:03:30.195 --> 00:03:35.235
and we've got so many external providers
that it might be more cost-effective for

57
00:03:35.235 --> 00:03:36.710
us to outsource.

58
00:03:36.710 --> 00:03:42.860
And to go externally, and allow somebody
else to manage all of that complexity,

59
00:03:42.860 --> 00:03:46.970
all of the complex relationships
between our service providers.

60
00:03:46.970 --> 00:03:51.780
So an external service provider is brought
in or an external service integrators,

61
00:03:51.780 --> 00:03:55.280
sorry, is brought in by
a number of organizations.

62
00:03:55.280 --> 00:03:59.356
And scale doesn't necessarily
play a part in this at all.

63
00:03:59.356 --> 00:04:03.232
It really is down to what you want
that service integrator to do, and

64
00:04:03.232 --> 00:04:05.680
whether you have those skills in-house,

65
00:04:05.680 --> 00:04:10.190
and whether you're planning on retaining
those skills in-house, as well.

66
00:04:10.190 --> 00:04:14.965
So when we consider there has to be
a choice between whether you are going to

67
00:04:14.965 --> 00:04:20.155
stay in-house or whether you're going
to go outside and we've got a number

68
00:04:20.155 --> 00:04:25.175
of factors that we might want to to
consider when we're making that choice.

69
00:04:25.175 --> 00:04:30.089
But scale,
invariably is not necessarily one of them.

70
00:04:30.089 --> 00:04:33.137
Now, the scale of the external
organization though,

71
00:04:33.137 --> 00:04:34.467
may well be one of them.

72
00:04:34.467 --> 00:04:39.072
And the ability of that organization to
adapt to certain situations may well be

73
00:04:39.072 --> 00:04:40.040
one of them.

74
00:04:40.040 --> 00:04:42.001
Let's look at some pros and

75
00:04:42.001 --> 00:04:46.878
cons here on the internal versus
the external service integrator.

76
00:04:46.878 --> 00:04:52.206
So an internal service integrator,
Justin, let's bring you in on this one.

77
00:04:52.206 --> 00:04:56.944
All right, an internal service integrator,
their internal to our organization.

78
00:04:56.944 --> 00:05:00.140
What do you think the pros and
cons are on this?

79
00:05:00.140 --> 00:05:03.644
>> So the pros, I would think that they
would know more about your business.

80
00:05:03.644 --> 00:05:09.487
They would have more kind of insights
to respective business used cases and

81
00:05:09.487 --> 00:05:13.302
you would be able to work
more closely with them.

82
00:05:13.302 --> 00:05:18.338
The cons is now you're retaining,
you're also having to

83
00:05:18.338 --> 00:05:23.592
cultivate the actual skills
necessary to become that role.

84
00:05:23.592 --> 00:05:28.321
As well as there's some cost associated
with that by retaining those internally.

85
00:05:28.321 --> 00:05:32.910
So it's kind of a give and
take there I would think for internals.

86
00:05:32.910 --> 00:05:37.824
>> Right, and so, we just flip that on its
head for our external service integrators.

87
00:05:37.824 --> 00:05:40.440
So internal service integrators,
you're right,

88
00:05:40.440 --> 00:05:43.540
they are completely knowledgeable
about our organization.

89
00:05:43.540 --> 00:05:48.450
And there's something else that you might
have missed there, is the fact that they

90
00:05:48.450 --> 00:05:55.130
are also more likely to be privy to
the strategy of the organization as well.

91
00:05:55.130 --> 00:06:01.000
So they're more likely to be
aligned to the organization and

92
00:06:01.000 --> 00:06:02.750
to the strategy of the organization.

93
00:06:02.750 --> 00:06:08.060
And I say more likely, they're not waiting
to be told there in the organization.

94
00:06:08.060 --> 00:06:10.105
And depending on the actual culture, and

95
00:06:10.105 --> 00:06:12.793
I not necessarily mean just
the business culture, but

96
00:06:12.793 --> 00:06:16.373
depending on the actual culture itself
in the country that they're in.

97
00:06:16.373 --> 00:06:21.308
Then, they will be treated as though
they are part of the organization and

98
00:06:21.308 --> 00:06:25.208
therefore, they will be privy
to information within that

99
00:06:25.208 --> 00:06:29.448
organization that an external
service integrator might not.

100
00:06:29.448 --> 00:06:33.175
And I say depending on the culture,
because in some cultures will

101
00:06:33.175 --> 00:06:37.242
treat external organizations as sort
of just an extension of ours, but

102
00:06:37.242 --> 00:06:41.290
in other cultures they're
treated completely differently.

103
00:06:41.290 --> 00:06:45.815
And so, that again is something that you
have to consider when you're making that

104
00:06:45.815 --> 00:06:48.713
decision, to use an external
service integrator.

105
00:06:48.713 --> 00:06:52.831
In terms of with the pros and
cons you mentioned,

106
00:06:52.831 --> 00:06:58.658
the fact that an internal service
integrator may not be as flexible,

107
00:06:58.658 --> 00:07:01.580
may not be as adaptable to change.

108
00:07:01.580 --> 00:07:05.363
They may not necessarily
have these skills.

109
00:07:05.363 --> 00:07:10.284
And you also use word,
which I really like, which was cultivate.

110
00:07:10.284 --> 00:07:14.517
And external service integrator is gonna
be able to cultivate those skills.

111
00:07:14.517 --> 00:07:17.903
An external service integrator is actually

112
00:07:17.903 --> 00:07:22.301
going to be able to maintain
a skill level that is needed.

113
00:07:22.301 --> 00:07:27.530
It's going to be cheaper for them to do
that, because you would hope that that

114
00:07:27.530 --> 00:07:32.760
external service integrator has got
enough stuff, enough specialist stuff

115
00:07:32.760 --> 00:07:37.930
to be able to maintain that skill level
that's needed by the organization.

116
00:07:40.000 --> 00:07:42.800
But let's think about the external
service integrator and

117
00:07:42.800 --> 00:07:46.279
let's think about the pros and
cons of the external service integrator.

118
00:07:46.279 --> 00:07:49.274
Because you see with
the external service integrator,

119
00:07:49.274 --> 00:07:53.860
we've looked to all of the benefits as it
were with the external service integrator,

120
00:07:53.860 --> 00:07:56.700
but let's look at the disadvantages.

121
00:07:56.700 --> 00:07:59.957
The disadvantages
are perhaps that culture.

122
00:07:59.957 --> 00:08:04.389
Perhaps they are not as aware of
the strategy of the organization,

123
00:08:04.389 --> 00:08:06.377
the customer organization.

124
00:08:06.377 --> 00:08:09.800
We know that they gonna have skills,
that's great.

125
00:08:10.850 --> 00:08:14.770
But those skills gonna be very generic,
they're gonna be generic skills.

126
00:08:15.800 --> 00:08:22.470
Well, the internal service integrator,
their skills are gonna be very specific.

127
00:08:22.470 --> 00:08:27.120
But, the external service integrator,
they're gonna have generic skills.

128
00:08:29.110 --> 00:08:31.100
It's easy to keep those up to date.

129
00:08:31.100 --> 00:08:33.950
It's not so easy to keep
the specific skills up to date,

130
00:08:33.950 --> 00:08:36.380
certainly not at a reasonable cost.

131
00:08:36.380 --> 00:08:43.550
The external service integrator though,
is also going to have multiple clients.

132
00:08:43.550 --> 00:08:46.270
I would expect them to
have multiple clients.

133
00:08:46.270 --> 00:08:51.730
If they're just a service integrator fee,
your organization, then why would

134
00:08:51.730 --> 00:08:56.460
you select a service integrator that's
just going to be for your organization?

135
00:08:56.460 --> 00:08:57.230
Because surely,

136
00:08:57.230 --> 00:09:01.050
then they don't have the experience and
they don't have the credibility built up,

137
00:09:01.050 --> 00:09:04.710
to be able to demonstrate that
they could perform the role.

138
00:09:04.710 --> 00:09:09.210
When you're going out to look for
a service integrator, and

139
00:09:09.210 --> 00:09:12.130
you're going out into the world,
and you're going

140
00:09:12.130 --> 00:09:15.920
to perform maybe an invitation to
tender or request for proposals.

141
00:09:15.920 --> 00:09:19.230
Then you're going to look for
people that have got experience.

142
00:09:19.230 --> 00:09:24.170
And you're going to look for organizations
that have got credibility and that have

143
00:09:24.170 --> 00:09:28.620
got a very good reputation performing
the role that you want them to perform.

144
00:09:28.620 --> 00:09:30.620
And you'll certainly not going to look for

145
00:09:30.620 --> 00:09:33.550
somebody that doesn't have
any experience at all.

146
00:09:33.550 --> 00:09:36.600
So that means that my external
service integrator then,

147
00:09:36.600 --> 00:09:40.450
I expected them to probably
have all the clients.

148
00:09:40.450 --> 00:09:42.110
And if they've got all the clients,

149
00:09:42.110 --> 00:09:47.970
how can you be assured that you
are going to be their number one client.

150
00:09:49.690 --> 00:09:50.620
That's always a challenge.

151
00:09:52.010 --> 00:09:57.040
So, if we just take a look at that
diagram there, you'll see that we expect

152
00:09:57.040 --> 00:10:03.050
that external service integrator to
manage the external service providers and

153
00:10:03.050 --> 00:10:07.410
also to manage the internal
service providers as well.

154
00:10:08.600 --> 00:10:11.230
So any internal roles that we may have,

155
00:10:11.230 --> 00:10:14.440
I'm expecting somebody
external to manage that.

156
00:10:15.670 --> 00:10:21.190
So we've got a customer organization and
then we've got an external integrator,

157
00:10:21.190 --> 00:10:24.400
and then we've got internal
service providers.

158
00:10:26.610 --> 00:10:29.130
That presents us with another challenge.

159
00:10:29.130 --> 00:10:34.060
Inland is very, very easy for the customer
organization to buy past the integrated

160
00:10:34.060 --> 00:10:39.560
completely and go straight to
the internal service providers.

161
00:10:39.560 --> 00:10:41.482
That adds in a layer of complexity for

162
00:10:41.482 --> 00:10:44.710
the customer because the customer
got to know who to contact.

163
00:10:44.710 --> 00:10:49.960
But it is not unusual for my customer
to get to know individual people and

164
00:10:49.960 --> 00:10:55.138
for my customers to just pick up
the phone and call individual people.

165
00:10:55.138 --> 00:11:01.024
And in fact, that's what happens in
an organization, on a day to day basis.

166
00:11:01.024 --> 00:11:03.440
So we're adding in a layer.

167
00:11:04.670 --> 00:11:06.590
An external layer of that.

168
00:11:08.120 --> 00:11:10.600
That can be difficult to manage.

169
00:11:10.600 --> 00:11:15.017
And so
we have to ensure that as a customer,

170
00:11:15.017 --> 00:11:22.642
we have to empower that external service
integrator to act on our behalf.

171
00:11:22.642 --> 00:11:23.510
We have to empower them.

172
00:11:23.510 --> 00:11:28.100
And we have to empower them so that
the internal service providers, well, so

173
00:11:28.100 --> 00:11:31.330
that they actually report into
that service integrator and

174
00:11:31.330 --> 00:11:34.850
they don't report direct into
the customer organization.

175
00:11:37.730 --> 00:11:40.650
So, let's just take a look at
some characteristics then that

176
00:11:40.650 --> 00:11:43.480
we have here with an external integrator.

177
00:11:43.480 --> 00:11:47.000
And if we can just take
a look on the screen,

178
00:11:47.000 --> 00:11:49.580
you'll see there are some
words in the slide there.

179
00:11:49.580 --> 00:11:53.350
And by the way, all of these slides
are available to you to download, so

180
00:11:53.350 --> 00:11:57.370
you'll be able to pick these up
if you're studying for your test.

181
00:11:57.370 --> 00:12:00.710
Then obviously,
these are gonna be really useful to you.

182
00:12:00.710 --> 00:12:05.230
So, the external service integrator, the
last bullet point there, is exclusively

183
00:12:05.230 --> 00:12:10.000
focused on integration activities and
they don't actually perform any work.

184
00:12:11.080 --> 00:12:13.299
That's an interesting point to make.

185
00:12:13.299 --> 00:12:17.010
They don't perform any of
the service provider roles.

186
00:12:17.010 --> 00:12:19.414
So, when I say that I am for many work,

187
00:12:19.414 --> 00:12:22.580
I don't mean that they
don't do anything at all.

188
00:12:22.580 --> 00:12:27.370
What I mean is that, they don't actually
perform any of the service provider role.

189
00:12:27.370 --> 00:12:29.570
So they don't do any of
the development work and

190
00:12:29.570 --> 00:12:31.220
they don't do any of the support work.

191
00:12:31.220 --> 00:12:35.380
What they are doing is purely managing.

192
00:12:35.380 --> 00:12:37.540
And this is why right at
the beginning of the episode,

193
00:12:37.540 --> 00:12:41.560
when I picked Justin up on
his use of words there,

194
00:12:41.560 --> 00:12:46.715
because this was actually about,
this is managing our services.

195
00:12:46.715 --> 00:12:50.555
Managing our service providers,
not necessarily implementing.

196
00:12:50.555 --> 00:12:55.445
The implementation is decided
by the customer organization.

197
00:12:55.445 --> 00:12:59.855
And that was something that we looked at
in a previous episodes where we looked at

198
00:12:59.855 --> 00:13:04.405
the roadmap and the implementation
of SIAM, and the SIAM ecosystem.
