00:26:56.186 --> 00:27:00.945
have a direct service level agreement
with the customer organization.

430
00:27:02.380 --> 00:27:08.790
So sometimes we bring in the politics,
with a lowercase p, into this.

431
00:27:08.790 --> 00:27:11.460
And that doesn't help, either.

432
00:27:11.460 --> 00:27:14.105
So, how's your mind doing right now,
Justin?

433
00:27:14.105 --> 00:27:18.110
>> Well, you always have to add a little
dash of human behavior to really

434
00:27:18.110 --> 00:27:19.690
stir the pot, so to speak.

435
00:27:19.690 --> 00:27:26.100
And I'm thinking about these contracts and
trying to make these time targets, right?

436
00:27:28.920 --> 00:27:30.150
Because it's contracted,

437
00:27:30.150 --> 00:27:32.760
I'm guessing all of those have
to be very concrete in nature.

438
00:27:32.760 --> 00:27:36.180
You can't say, well, if you're
the second person to get the issue,

439
00:27:36.180 --> 00:27:37.460
then you only have an hour.

440
00:27:37.460 --> 00:27:39.615
That's not some kind of tiered approach.

441
00:27:39.615 --> 00:27:44.600
Men, you know what, this seemed like
an interesting job for a while, but

442
00:27:44.600 --> 00:27:49.720
sometimes it seems like you would just
need like a set of octopus arms to go, all

443
00:27:49.720 --> 00:27:53.220
right, hold on a second, let me just make
sure I have all of these things in place.

444
00:27:53.220 --> 00:27:56.750
And then when you add the human factor
into it, it just, I don't know,

445
00:27:56.750 --> 00:27:59.080
it seems like it might be
an unwieldy thing, but

446
00:27:59.080 --> 00:28:03.860
I guess that's why they can become very
valuable to a respective organization.

447
00:28:03.860 --> 00:28:07.535
>> Well, and one of the reasons why
I corrected you at the beginning,

448
00:28:07.535 --> 00:28:09.740
cuz I said, no, it's about managing this.

449
00:28:09.740 --> 00:28:11.300
Because this is a management role,

450
00:28:11.300 --> 00:28:13.980
the service integrator
role is a management role.

451
00:28:13.980 --> 00:28:16.660
But they also need to have
that technical understanding,

452
00:28:16.660 --> 00:28:20.000
because if somebody's telling me a story.

453
00:28:20.000 --> 00:28:22.920
Or I haven't done this because of x,
y and z.

454
00:28:22.920 --> 00:28:27.730
Well, no, I know that that's not true but
because then I know that that's not true,

455
00:28:27.730 --> 00:28:32.160
because I've analyzed this myself and
I know that actually this could be done.

456
00:28:32.160 --> 00:28:37.330
So, I expect my service integrator
to have a technical bias but

457
00:28:37.330 --> 00:28:40.810
I also expect my service integrator layer,
and

458
00:28:40.810 --> 00:28:44.010
that will be a team of people
invariably not just one person.

459
00:28:44.010 --> 00:28:48.680
But I expect my service integrator layer
to be able to manage, it's management.

460
00:28:48.680 --> 00:28:51.610
It's not just about implementing this,
you can implement this and

461
00:28:51.610 --> 00:28:52.990
then leave it to run.

462
00:28:52.990 --> 00:28:58.240
This has to be managed because
otherwise on a daily basis,

463
00:28:58.240 --> 00:29:02.990
every day, our targets will fail,
our incident targets will fail.

464
00:29:02.990 --> 00:29:07.110
So this is about, these words that
we've used in previous episodes such as

465
00:29:07.110 --> 00:29:12.340
collaboration and ensuring that
we've got relationships in place.

466
00:29:12.340 --> 00:29:18.260
This is about having good relationships
between our external service providers and

467
00:29:18.260 --> 00:29:20.680
the internal service providers, too.

468
00:29:20.680 --> 00:29:22.520
It's about having relationships.

469
00:29:22.520 --> 00:29:25.665
It's about having a trust amongst them.

470
00:29:25.665 --> 00:29:30.480
That if I'm passing an incident to,
say, Comcast and I'm saying, I'm sorry,

471
00:29:30.480 --> 00:29:32.468
guys, you've only got an hour and a half.

472
00:29:32.468 --> 00:29:35.708
It's having a trust that they're not
gonna turn around and say right,

473
00:29:35.708 --> 00:29:39.666
well, my contract says I've got two hours,
and therefore I'm gonna take two hours.

474
00:29:39.666 --> 00:29:42.210
So we have to have a certain
element of trust in there.

475
00:29:42.210 --> 00:29:46.114
And there also has to be
a certain element of flexibility,

476
00:29:46.114 --> 00:29:50.976
because all of these service providers,
be they internal or external,

477
00:29:50.976 --> 00:29:55.041
should be aware that the ultimate
target is for four hours and

478
00:29:55.041 --> 00:29:59.370
therefore something's got to
happen within those four hours.

479
00:30:00.380 --> 00:30:03.240
And that doesn't mean that we're
just going to sit there and

480
00:30:03.240 --> 00:30:06.550
stare at the instant until
the four hours are elapsed.

481
00:30:06.550 --> 00:30:09.400
Something has got to happen
within those four hours.

482
00:30:10.410 --> 00:30:14.280
Part of the management of this
particular role is ensuring

483
00:30:14.280 --> 00:30:16.810
that no one's pointing
the blame at anybody else.

484
00:30:16.810 --> 00:30:21.870
There is a potential, and you bring in the
human nature of this, there is a potential

485
00:30:21.870 --> 00:30:26.200
for somebody to sit down and say,
hey, look, it's not me, it's them.

486
00:30:27.650 --> 00:30:32.908
And that is gonna be one of the biggest
pitfalls within this particular

487
00:30:32.908 --> 00:30:37.900
arrangement with using
the external service integrator,

488
00:30:37.900 --> 00:30:42.090
is that it would be very, very easy for
all of our service providers to just seat

489
00:30:42.090 --> 00:30:45.590
back and say, hey look,
it's not me, it's them.

490
00:30:45.590 --> 00:30:50.088
Even so much as putting the blame back
onto the external service integrator.

491
00:30:50.088 --> 00:30:55.760
So, we gotta make sure that, that
external service integrator is empowered

492
00:30:55.760 --> 00:31:01.960
to act on behalf of the customer, but is
also in a position where they know how to,

493
00:31:01.960 --> 00:31:07.570
they have the capabilities to manage
on behalf of the customer as well.

494
00:31:09.000 --> 00:31:12.290
>> And that seems like a daunting
task in and of itself.

495
00:31:12.290 --> 00:31:17.210
But we've been talking about external
service integrators here, and

496
00:31:17.210 --> 00:31:19.676
as we've seen, it is no easy feat.

497
00:31:19.676 --> 00:31:23.577
There are pros and cons, and we talked
a little bit about those beforehand.

498
00:31:23.577 --> 00:31:28.078
But I feel like we have not even
touched the surface of service

499
00:31:28.078 --> 00:31:30.030
integrators in general.

500
00:31:30.030 --> 00:31:31.235
Where are going from here, Jo?

501
00:31:31.235 --> 00:31:33.050
>> Right, in our next episode then,

502
00:31:33.050 --> 00:31:38.430
join us again because we will be looking
at the internal service integrator and

503
00:31:38.430 --> 00:31:42.120
the role that they play
within the SIAM ecosystem.

504
00:31:42.120 --> 00:31:44.604
>> Well, I'm interested to
see how these compare and

505
00:31:44.604 --> 00:31:48.260
contrast to the external service
integrators that we just taken a look at.

506
00:31:48.260 --> 00:31:51.510
So, definitely join us back, but for now,
we're gonna go ahead and get out of here.

507
00:31:51.510 --> 00:31:54.670
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Justin Dennison.

508
00:31:54.670 --> 00:31:55.442
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

509
00:31:55.442 --> 00:31:56.758
>> And we'll see you next time.

510
00:31:56.758 --> 00:32:03.916
[MUSIC]

511
00:32:03.916 --> 00:32:06.541
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: This 2nd episode on service integrators explores further the eco-system with an external service integrator.
episodes.title: Service Integrators - Internal Service Integrator
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.553
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.553 --> 00:00:08.294
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.294 --> 00:00:11.665
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:11.665 --> 00:00:15.853
>> Greetings everyone, and welcome back
to another exciting episode of ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:15.853 --> 00:00:19.862
I'm your host, Justin Dennison, and
we're continuing on with SIAM Foundation.

6
00:00:19.862 --> 00:00:24.176
And well, we're gonna be looking
at internal service integrators,

7
00:00:24.176 --> 00:00:28.928
which is, well, a nice comparison to
our previous episode where we looked at

8
00:00:28.928 --> 00:00:31.660
external service integrators.

9
00:00:31.660 --> 00:00:33.680
Those words somehow don't
wanna come out of my mouth.

10
00:00:33.680 --> 00:00:36.974
But luckily we have someone who's a lot
more eloquent than I am about this

11
00:00:36.974 --> 00:00:38.386
very topic, Ms. Jo Peacock.

12
00:00:38.386 --> 00:00:39.241
How are you doing today Jo?

13
00:00:39.241 --> 00:00:40.650
>> I'm absolutely fine Justin.

14
00:00:40.650 --> 00:00:41.491
How are you?

15
00:00:41.491 --> 00:00:42.598
>> I am doing well as well.

16
00:00:42.598 --> 00:00:46.670
>> That was one huge assumption that
I am more eloquent than you are.

17
00:00:46.670 --> 00:00:48.140
>> Well, about this topic.

18
00:00:48.140 --> 00:00:49.006
>> Okay.
>> [LAUGH]

19
00:00:49.006 --> 00:00:50.432
>> I'll deal with that again.

20
00:00:51.500 --> 00:00:53.220
Yeah, I can tell you that.

21
00:00:53.220 --> 00:00:57.070
We are gonna be talking about
internal service integrators

22
00:00:57.070 --> 00:00:58.710
in this particular episode.

23
00:00:58.710 --> 00:01:00.045
In a previous episode,

24
00:01:00.045 --> 00:01:03.997
this is part two of our little mini
series about service integrators.

25
00:01:03.997 --> 00:01:08.160
And in our previous episode, we looked
at external service integrators, and

26
00:01:08.160 --> 00:01:12.322
we pretty much blew Justin's mind when
we started talking about service level

27
00:01:12.322 --> 00:01:16.880
targets and we talked about managing the
complexity of those service level targets.

28
00:01:16.880 --> 00:01:21.742
And you know what, the same principle
still stands when we're talking about our

29
00:01:21.742 --> 00:01:23.759
internal service integrators.

30
00:01:23.759 --> 00:01:27.755
And we're also going to talk about those
human factors that come into this as well

31
00:01:27.755 --> 00:01:30.570
because you can't just ignore them.

32
00:01:30.570 --> 00:01:35.170
One thing though that I do wanna,
how should I say it,

33
00:01:35.170 --> 00:01:38.050
I just wanna remind you of this really.

34
00:01:38.050 --> 00:01:42.810
If you noticed that in our slide that
we've got in front of us right now,

35
00:01:42.810 --> 00:01:46.690
you'll see that our service integrator
is actually internal to the customer

36
00:01:46.690 --> 00:01:48.420
organization.

37
00:01:48.420 --> 00:01:53.142
Now, that sometimes comes as a surprise to
people because they say well that is part

38
00:01:53.142 --> 00:01:54.730
of the customer then.

39
00:01:54.730 --> 00:01:55.990
Well,of course, it is.

40
00:01:55.990 --> 00:01:58.130
It's internal to the organization.

41
00:01:58.130 --> 00:02:04.110
And so an external service integrator is
external to the customer's organization,

42
00:02:04.110 --> 00:02:08.230
and therefore, internal means
internal to the organization.

43
00:02:08.230 --> 00:02:13.003
If we were in
an ITIL Service Management framework,

44
00:02:13.003 --> 00:02:17.674
we would just simply call
that a service provider.

45
00:02:17.674 --> 00:02:18.975
Nothing more than that.

46
00:02:18.975 --> 00:02:22.006
We would call it maybe
an internal service provider

47
00:02:22.006 --> 00:02:27.140
cuz it's internal perhaps to the business
unit or to the customer organization.

48
00:02:27.140 --> 00:02:28.340
But nevertheless,

49
00:02:28.340 --> 00:02:34.350
it's just simply the service integrator
that's internal to the organization.

50
00:02:34.350 --> 00:02:36.300
So this is nothing different.

51
00:02:36.300 --> 00:02:39.250
This is not something that's unique.

52
00:02:39.250 --> 00:02:43.600
This is just a service integrator
that's internal to the organization.

53
00:02:43.600 --> 00:02:52.220
We will still have agreements and
so here, I'm gonna quiz Justin now.

54
00:02:52.220 --> 00:02:57.670
In our last episode, we looked at
external service integrators and

55
00:02:57.670 --> 00:03:01.400
we looked at the fact that between our
customer, if I can found my mouse here,

56
00:03:01.400 --> 00:03:05.590
between our customer and
the service integrator we had a contract.

57
00:03:05.590 --> 00:03:08.990
So what do you think that we have
here between the customer and

58
00:03:08.990 --> 00:03:10.630
the service integrator?

59
00:03:10.630 --> 00:03:13.450
>> Because they're internal,
I'm gonna go out on a limb and say it's

60
00:03:13.450 --> 00:03:15.560
an agreement because it's internal-
>> Yep.

61
00:03:15.560 --> 00:03:16.632
>> To the company.

62
00:03:16.632 --> 00:03:19.796
>> So this would be an SLA,
a service level agreement.

63
00:03:19.796 --> 00:03:24.372
And a service level agreement is
an agreement between two parties of

64
00:03:24.372 --> 00:03:29.348
the same organization, and it is
an agreement on the level of service that

65
00:03:29.348 --> 00:03:33.070
one party will commit to
provide to the other.

66
00:03:33.070 --> 00:03:37.406
It's an agreement on what
the other party will accept.

67
00:03:37.406 --> 00:03:41.870
So a service level agreement contains
all of the targets with which

68
00:03:41.870 --> 00:03:44.190
the service provider or in this case,

69
00:03:44.190 --> 00:03:50.700
the service integrator will commit to
delivering to this costumer organization.

70
00:03:50.700 --> 00:03:54.930
So we will still have agreements in place.

71
00:03:54.930 --> 00:04:00.580
So even though we have got an integrator
here, we will still have an agreement.

72
00:04:00.580 --> 00:04:04.570
Because that agreement
outlines to the integrator

73
00:04:04.570 --> 00:04:09.450
what levels of service
are expected by the customer.

74
00:04:09.450 --> 00:04:12.790
Now, a service level agreement is
an agreement between two parties, and

75
00:04:12.790 --> 00:04:16.130
it lists the roles and
responsibilities of both parties.

76
00:04:16.130 --> 00:04:20.062
So I expect to see things like we'll
give you, from the service integrator,

77
00:04:20.062 --> 00:04:21.997
we'll give you the ability to send and

78
00:04:21.997 --> 00:04:24.979
receive email as long as you
don't download any viruses.

79
00:04:24.979 --> 00:04:28.133
So it's the roles and
responsibilities of both parties.

80
00:04:28.133 --> 00:04:31.890
It's not just one sided,
which is a common misconception.

81
00:04:31.890 --> 00:04:34.370
But it's weighted heavily
in the customer's favor.

82
00:04:34.370 --> 00:04:37.580
That's not necessarily the case at all.

83
00:04:37.580 --> 00:04:41.910
What we should be doing in that SLA is
outlining the responsibilities of both

84
00:04:41.910 --> 00:04:42.720
parties.

85
00:04:42.720 --> 00:04:47.100
So one of the examples that I gave when we
were talking about the external service

86
00:04:47.100 --> 00:04:52.100
provider is the fact that
maybe we will aim to,

87
00:04:52.100 --> 00:04:56.220
one of our service level targets was,
we will aim to resolve

88
00:04:57.390 --> 00:05:02.200
an incident, or rather I think I said
respond to an incident within four hours.

89
00:05:02.200 --> 00:05:06.350
So that's something that would still
exist within the service level agreement.

90
00:05:06.350 --> 00:05:10.310
And that's something that the internal
service integrator will commit to.

91
00:05:10.310 --> 00:05:17.220
We will aim to respond to
a incident within four hours.

92
00:05:17.220 --> 00:05:21.500
So everything that happens from here on
downwards has still got to happen within

93
00:05:21.500 --> 00:05:22.840
those four hours.

94
00:05:22.840 --> 00:05:26.090
And that discussion
that we had previously,

95
00:05:26.090 --> 00:05:31.980
in our external service
integrator episode still applies.

96
00:05:31.980 --> 00:05:39.070
The only differences here is in
this particular relationship.

97
00:05:39.070 --> 00:05:44.520
We will have a contract here with
our external service providers

98
00:05:44.520 --> 00:05:49.530
because they are external,
and here we will have an SLA.

99
00:05:50.570 --> 00:05:53.700
And that will be an SLA between
the service integrator and

100
00:05:53.700 --> 00:05:55.980
the internal service providers.

101
00:05:57.390 --> 00:06:00.360
We still get that same complexity.

102
00:06:00.360 --> 00:06:05.250
So the complexity that we took from
our external service integrator,

103
00:06:05.250 --> 00:06:07.780
which is that complexity of well,
what happens?

104
00:06:07.780 --> 00:06:12.360
We've got four hours, that means that
everything has got to happen underneath

105
00:06:12.360 --> 00:06:17.090
this particular point in those four
hours including passing around between

106
00:06:17.090 --> 00:06:22.420
all of the external service providers and
all of the internal service providers.

107
00:06:22.420 --> 00:06:24.890
All of that has got to happen
within those four hours.

108
00:06:24.890 --> 00:06:27.231
So we have to have that flexibility.

109
00:06:27.231 --> 00:06:32.647
We have to have an understanding and
a trust and collaboration between all

110
00:06:32.647 --> 00:06:38.079
of our service providers that allows
us to achieve that four hour target.

111
00:06:39.986 --> 00:06:45.326
One thing that we do know, though,
is that an internal service integrator is,

112
00:06:45.326 --> 00:06:48.290
well, they're internal to the customer.

113
00:06:48.290 --> 00:06:53.750
And therefore,
we know that they are privy to all of

114
00:06:53.750 --> 00:06:59.670
the strategy decisions and all of
the workings of the customer organization.

115
00:06:59.670 --> 00:07:06.570
They are also likely to have some
form of direct link into the internal

116
00:07:06.570 --> 00:07:11.660
service providers, possibly by way of
maybe an internal messaging system,

117
00:07:11.660 --> 00:07:18.160
maybe an internal directory, etc.

118
00:07:18.160 --> 00:07:20.726
So there will be a tendency for

119
00:07:20.726 --> 00:07:25.969
this relationship to be a very,
very mature relationship.

120
00:07:27.856 --> 00:07:32.693
That can work to a detriment as
well because it's not unusual for

121
00:07:32.693 --> 00:07:36.830
these guys to rely on
that good relationship.

122
00:07:36.830 --> 00:07:39.987
Whereas here,
we've got contractual obligations.

123
00:07:39.987 --> 00:07:43.911
And therefore, the contractual
obligations, to a certain extent,

124
00:07:43.911 --> 00:07:47.310
are easier to manage when we've
got internal obligations.

125
00:07:47.310 --> 00:07:52.257
They're not necessarily as easy to manage,
because I don't expect to see

126
00:07:52.257 --> 00:07:56.390
penalties and
incentives in service level agreements.

127
00:07:56.390 --> 00:07:59.190
I expect to see penalties and
incentives in contrast.

128
00:08:00.200 --> 00:08:05.400
And it may well be that in a contract
because we are paying in a contract so

129
00:08:05.400 --> 00:08:11.570
then we may, well, there's a danger
that we might uphold or rather

130
00:08:11.570 --> 00:08:15.410
we might hold these guys accountable,
the external, I've lost my mouse here.

131
00:08:15.410 --> 00:08:19.480
The external service providers,
they may be held to higher standards than

132
00:08:19.480 --> 00:08:24.270
say the internal service providers because
they've got penalties and incentives.

133
00:08:24.270 --> 00:08:26.740
Now, that is not something
that we would advocate.

134
00:08:26.740 --> 00:08:28.970
That is something that we would say no,

135
00:08:28.970 --> 00:08:33.980
every single one of our service provider
has to be treated exactly the same.

136
00:08:33.980 --> 00:08:38.210
And Justin is itching to ask something.

137
00:08:38.210 --> 00:08:40.810
>> So I think we're back to
this human factors, right.

138
00:08:40.810 --> 00:08:47.210
Is this kind of, well, I know you,
let's say there's some person named Bobby.

139
00:08:47.210 --> 00:08:49.850
And you're like I know you, Bobby,
I know you tried your best.

140
00:08:49.850 --> 00:08:52.600
But then, if it was an external one,
you're like,

141
00:08:52.600 --> 00:08:53.920
no this is what we agreed upon.

142
00:08:55.470 --> 00:08:58.890
I've seen people do this, not necessarily
in this context, where you have

143
00:08:58.890 --> 00:09:03.600
different facets of rigidity based
on the personal relationships.

144
00:09:03.600 --> 00:09:07.760

238
00:15:04.410 --> 00:15:09.692
talking about an internal or an external
or a hybrid or even an elite supplier.

239
00:15:09.692 --> 00:15:14.835
In any structure for service integrator,
there could possibly be tension.

240
00:15:14.835 --> 00:15:18.803
And one of the roles of the service
integrator is actually to alleviate

241
00:15:18.803 --> 00:15:19.684
that tension.

242
00:15:19.684 --> 00:15:24.260
And it's to ensure that all of
the parties, all of our service providers,

243
00:15:24.260 --> 00:15:28.000
work together in a collaborative and
cohesive way.

244
00:15:28.000 --> 00:15:29.900
Cohesive simply means joined together, but

245
00:15:29.900 --> 00:15:34.280
collaboration is more about having
that trust in that relationship.

246
00:15:34.280 --> 00:15:38.240
Now obviously,
that's not necessarily easy as it sounds.

247
00:15:38.240 --> 00:15:42.240
And if the service integrator,
which in this instance,

248
00:15:42.240 --> 00:15:45.630
the service integrator is
actually one of the suppliers,

249
00:15:45.630 --> 00:15:49.410
then that could cause that conflict
of interest that may prevent that.

250
00:15:49.410 --> 00:15:54.846
Ultimately the customer has got to, well,
they've gotta weigh out the pros and cons.

251
00:15:54.846 --> 00:15:57.734
They've gotta look at the advantages and

252
00:15:57.734 --> 00:16:03.270
the disadvantages of each particular
decision that they think about making.

253
00:16:03.270 --> 00:16:07.130
And so that's something that's got to
be mentioned in the business case.

254
00:16:07.130 --> 00:16:10.260
And it's also something that's got
to be considered in the planning and

255
00:16:10.260 --> 00:16:11.870
the implementation phases.

256
00:16:11.870 --> 00:16:18.049
Where we need to ensure that if we do
detect any elements of impartiality,

257
00:16:18.049 --> 00:16:23.044
or we detect any opportunities for
impartiality to exist.

258
00:16:23.044 --> 00:16:26.040
That we close the door on that
one pretty much straight away.

259
00:16:26.040 --> 00:16:27.330
>> And that makes perfect sense,

260
00:16:27.330 --> 00:16:30.960
right, you need to keep your finger
on the pulse of things, so to speak.

261
00:16:30.960 --> 00:16:33.770
One final question about this,
and I think I know the answer.

262
00:16:33.770 --> 00:16:37.160
Which I kind of set my self up for
a deflection question there.

263
00:16:37.160 --> 00:16:41.110
But we talked about this lead
supplier being promoted.

264
00:16:41.110 --> 00:16:45.980
Promoted, I use that word loosely,
from an external service provider.

265
00:16:45.980 --> 00:16:50.050
However, if I took all of my
service providers, internal and

266
00:16:50.050 --> 00:16:53.630
external, and I said, I want that
one to become my service integrator.

267
00:16:53.630 --> 00:16:57.532
If it's the internal, then they just
become an internal service integrator,

268
00:16:57.532 --> 00:16:59.987
are they now a lead supplier?
>> No.

269
00:16:59.987 --> 00:17:01.691
>> Okay, they're just now a service

270
00:17:01.691 --> 00:17:05.629
integrator, and that becomes their primary
role as far as the service that they

271
00:17:05.629 --> 00:17:07.746
are providing internally to the company,

272
00:17:07.746 --> 00:17:08.625
correct?
>> Yes,

273
00:17:08.625 --> 00:17:11.893
any service provider's gotta be evaluated,
it has to be.

274
00:17:11.893 --> 00:17:14.777
And they have to be evaluated
based on their merits and

275
00:17:14.777 --> 00:17:17.350
based on what they can bring to the table.

276
00:17:17.350 --> 00:17:20.610
And so,
whether we choose to remain internal or

277
00:17:20.610 --> 00:17:24.990
whether we choose to go external, or
maybe have some hybrid structure,

278
00:17:24.990 --> 00:17:30.620
it has to be whatever decision is deemed
to be the best for the organization.

279
00:17:30.620 --> 00:17:33.946
Think about this,
in the situation that we've got right now,

280
00:17:33.946 --> 00:17:36.784
if we just take a look at
that particular slide again.

281
00:17:36.784 --> 00:17:41.187
You'll see our customer has retained
capabilities, they have retained

282
00:17:41.187 --> 00:17:45.730
the decision making, and we talked
about that in a previous episode.

283
00:17:45.730 --> 00:17:50.240
But then what we've done is we've retained
the decision making and the strategy, and

284
00:17:50.240 --> 00:17:53.760
we've handed off everything
else to somebody else.

285
00:17:53.760 --> 00:17:57.770
If you're going to do that to somebody
external, no matter who that is,

286
00:17:57.770 --> 00:17:59.876
whether it's an existing supplier or

287
00:17:59.876 --> 00:18:03.784
whether it's another organization
that you've gone out to source.

288
00:18:03.784 --> 00:18:07.846
It's gotta be somebody with experience,
so you have to see evidence of that

289
00:18:07.846 --> 00:18:11.490
experience, but
it has to be somebody that you can trust.

290
00:18:11.490 --> 00:18:17.196
You see, as a customer, I just want
to be able to, I've made a decision,

291
00:18:17.196 --> 00:18:21.349
this is what I want,
this is what a perceive as value.

292
00:18:21.349 --> 00:18:26.220
And here's some money,
now deliver me value.

293
00:18:26.220 --> 00:18:30.123
That's what my customer is saying,
don't deliver me a headache,

294
00:18:30.123 --> 00:18:32.340
don't deliver me stress.

295
00:18:32.340 --> 00:18:38.505
What I want is for you to deliver me what
I value, I don't want anything else.

296
00:18:38.505 --> 00:18:41.580
And that's what the customer
is saying essentially.

297
00:18:41.580 --> 00:18:46.392
And so we really, as a customer,
we're empowering that service

298
00:18:46.392 --> 00:18:51.360
integrator to act on our behalf and
to act in our best interest.

299
00:18:51.360 --> 00:18:54.220
So it's important that we make
that decision right upfront.

300
00:18:55.400 --> 00:18:59.400
By selecting somebody who is gonna act in
our best interest and not going to act in

301
00:18:59.400 --> 00:19:02.680
their own best interest.
>> Well, these decisions are always hard

302
00:19:02.680 --> 00:19:06.688
to make, and well, I do not envy
the individuals who are making them.

303
00:19:06.688 --> 00:19:10.068
Now, Jo, we've taken a look at
all of our service integrators.

304
00:19:10.068 --> 00:19:14.325
And correct if I'm wrong, we have a pretty
good overview, do we still have more to

305
00:19:14.325 --> 00:19:17.781
cover as far as service integrators
as an individual subtopic, or

306
00:19:17.781 --> 00:19:20.194
are we going somewhere else after this?
>> No,

307
00:19:20.194 --> 00:19:25.361
now we've concluded our little miniseries
on service integtrators, and now what

308
00:19:25.361 --> 00:19:30.547
we're going to do is we're gonna get into
the the juicy bits of the SIAM practices.

309
00:19:30.547 --> 00:19:35.710
And everything, all the activities that
a SIAM ecosystem has to undertake.

310
00:19:35.710 --> 00:19:37.818
>> Well, that does sound juicy indeed, so

311
00:19:37.818 --> 00:19:39.740
definitely come on back and join us.

312
00:19:39.740 --> 00:19:43.030
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and get
out of here, so signing off for ITProTV,

313
00:19:43.030 --> 00:19:45.526
I've been your host Justin Dennison.
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

314
00:19:45.526 --> 00:19:46.580
>> And we'll see you next time.

00:19:46.580 --> 00:19:53.885

00:19:53.885 --> 00:19:56.778

Think about the challenges that we've got,

just simple little things like,

369
00:24:08.350 --> 00:24:13.980
customers prefer to use
that old legacy system.

370
00:24:13.980 --> 00:24:18.493
And then think about data transfer again,
and how do we transfer the data?

371
00:24:18.493 --> 00:24:22.455
And what portions of
the data do we transfer?

372
00:24:22.455 --> 00:24:26.190
And what about the non-compliant
service providers.

373
00:24:26.190 --> 00:24:29.730
These are the people that don't
want to necessarily use our tool.

374
00:24:29.730 --> 00:24:33.169
Or don't want to work in the same
way that we work because, and

375
00:24:33.169 --> 00:24:37.749
I've already mentioned this previously,
because they work in a different way.

376
00:24:37.749 --> 00:24:41.365
And therefore that fits in with all
of their current customers, and

377
00:24:41.365 --> 00:24:43.020
that's how they want to work.

378
00:24:43.020 --> 00:24:46.704
And they don't wanna change their
working practices just for us,

379
00:24:46.704 --> 00:24:49.811
because that's gonna be difficult for
them to manage.

380
00:24:51.790 --> 00:24:56.904
And of course, we have this architecture
of how our tool is configured and

381
00:24:56.904 --> 00:25:00.201
where our data sits and
where our servers are and

382
00:25:00.201 --> 00:25:04.840
who has access to all of this data and
who has access to the servers.

383
00:25:04.840 --> 00:25:09.114
But what if we've got differing
architecture requirements,

384
00:25:09.114 --> 00:25:14.000
things like data storage,
data archiving, backups, restores.

385
00:25:14.000 --> 00:25:18.419
If we have got different requirements
from our service provider and

386
00:25:18.419 --> 00:25:23.536
our service providers, I've got
differing requirements across the board,

387
00:25:23.536 --> 00:25:26.510
across all of these service providers.

388
00:25:26.510 --> 00:25:28.884
And how do we manage that?

389
00:25:28.884 --> 00:25:33.110
This is not just a five-minute challenge.

390
00:25:33.110 --> 00:25:35.219
>> Jo, I'm having bad flashbacks.

391
00:25:35.219 --> 00:25:37.441
So some of this I have
never interacted with.

392
00:25:37.441 --> 00:25:40.171
But this technology challenges,
I have interacted with.

393
00:25:40.171 --> 00:25:40.971
>> Mm-hm.

394
00:25:40.971 --> 00:25:44.950
>> Because I've work in the capacity
of one of the service providers.

395
00:25:44.950 --> 00:25:48.190
But then we had to work with other
internal service providers for

396
00:25:48.190 --> 00:25:49.960
our respective customer.

397
00:25:49.960 --> 00:25:52.130
And they're like, no,
we're not changing our architecture.

398
00:25:52.130 --> 00:25:54.020
Well, you're asking me
to do something that,

399
00:25:54.020 --> 00:25:58.600
given that, we need to figure
out how to make these mesh.

400
00:25:58.600 --> 00:26:00.540
And it almost seems like
you have to be careful,

401
00:26:00.540 --> 00:26:03.510
because you could have
a burgeoning landscape of, well,

402
00:26:03.510 --> 00:26:07.880
I have another service provider
that its entire existence is

403
00:26:07.880 --> 00:26:11.360
to create a connection between
these respective service providers.

404
00:26:11.360 --> 00:26:14.200
And it can just kind of snowball on you,
rIght?

405
00:26:14.200 --> 00:26:18.245
>> Well, if you take a look at this, what
we got on the slide in front of us now,

406
00:26:18.245 --> 00:26:23.230
you see, we talk about a solution there as
being a technology strategy and roadmap.

407
00:26:23.230 --> 00:26:26.120
And that sounds really,
really simple, but it's not.

408
00:26:26.120 --> 00:26:30.940
Because as you've already said, we have
got other providers that will come along

409
00:26:30.940 --> 00:26:35.730
and say, right, well, I'm gonna do, well,
I've written some API codes into this.

410
00:26:35.730 --> 00:26:39.469
And then that will take that information,
and it's gonna put it into here.

411
00:26:39.469 --> 00:26:43.624
And we're having to change the format
around slightly to make it fit into there,

412
00:26:43.624 --> 00:26:46.570
and that's all very well and
good for one relationship.

413
00:26:46.570 --> 00:26:50.430
But then when we have to then transfer
that data on to somebody else and

414
00:26:50.430 --> 00:26:54.460
then to somebody else,
then it starts getting very, very complex.

415
00:26:54.460 --> 00:26:58.738
And by the way, if you're in the process
of actually routing specific codes to get

416
00:26:58.738 --> 00:27:01.962
data from here to here and
they're not talking to each other,

417
00:27:01.962 --> 00:27:03.327
that's complex enough.

418
00:27:03.327 --> 00:27:04.776
That's one relationship.

419
00:27:04.776 --> 00:27:10.150
The last thing that you want to
do is add in other relationships.

420
00:27:10.150 --> 00:27:13.330
When I was a kid,
we used to play games at school.

421
00:27:13.330 --> 00:27:17.200
And I don't know what we call it over
here, I'll be perfectly honest, but

422
00:27:17.200 --> 00:27:18.560
it's just a common kids game.

423
00:27:18.560 --> 00:27:23.370
We call it Chinese whispers in the UK,
where somebody will whisper into your ear,

424
00:27:23.370 --> 00:27:24.690
and they'll whisper one thing.

425
00:27:24.690 --> 00:27:27.827
And then you go and whisper it to somebody
else, and then he goes and whispers, yeah?

426
00:27:27.827 --> 00:27:31.446
You know the game we have that-
>> Yeah, we call that telephone, I think.

427
00:27:31.446 --> 00:27:34.783
>> Okay.
>> Where you start, you whisper something,

428
00:27:34.783 --> 00:27:37.040
right, some innocuous phrase.

429
00:27:37.040 --> 00:27:37.761
>> Yep.

430
00:27:37.761 --> 00:27:41.424
>> And then it transforms as it kinda
moves about the circle or the line or

431
00:27:41.424 --> 00:27:42.510
whatever it may be.

432
00:27:42.510 --> 00:27:45.710
>> Well, I've seen that in IT,
I've seen that in IT.

433
00:27:45.710 --> 00:27:49.685
I have seen that where we have,
in this particular ecosystem,

434
00:27:49.685 --> 00:27:51.490
and I've seen this before.

435
00:27:51.490 --> 00:27:55.950
These ecosystems were established, in some
instances, where we've got data that's

436
00:27:55.950 --> 00:27:59.800
been moved from one toolset to another,
to another, to another.

437
00:27:59.800 --> 00:28:03.240
And each time, it's being translated.

438
00:28:03.240 --> 00:28:07.220
Sometimes it's even actually physically
being translated into different languages.

439
00:28:07.220 --> 00:28:11.710
And then by the time it gets back to you,
it is completely unrecognizable.

440
00:28:12.880 --> 00:28:15.240
So we have to have that map.

441
00:28:15.240 --> 00:28:20.630
And we may even want to use
certain industry standard methods

442
00:28:20.630 --> 00:28:25.320
to integrate our data and
to integrate out toolsets together.

443
00:28:25.320 --> 00:28:27.940
It's very, very difficult, very difficult.

444
00:28:27.940 --> 00:28:31.710
You have to get the agreement from
all of your service providers.

445
00:28:31.710 --> 00:28:36.510
And for, actually, when I look back at all
of these practices that we've discussed,

446
00:28:36.510 --> 00:28:39.440
not one of these practices
is going to work

447
00:28:39.440 --> 00:28:43.100
without the collaboration of
all of our service providers.

448
00:28:43.100 --> 00:28:48.033
And that, going back, right back to that
first question that I asked you right

449
00:28:48.033 --> 00:28:51.799
at the very beginning was,
whose responsibility is that?

450
00:28:51.799 --> 00:28:54.030
This is the service integrator.

451
00:28:54.030 --> 00:28:57.933
And now in this last sort of 30
minutes throughout this episode,

452
00:28:57.933 --> 00:29:01.915
we have just given the service
integrator a whole heap of work to do.

453
00:29:01.915 --> 00:29:07.317
>> A whole heap of work, I don't even
think that starts to cover it, Jo.

454
00:29:07.317 --> 00:29:08.356
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right,

455
00:29:08.356 --> 00:29:11.695
we talked about people practices, and
definitely correct me if I miss something,

456
00:29:11.695 --> 00:29:14.558
people practices, process practices,
measurement practices, and

457
00:29:14.558 --> 00:29:15.767
then technology practices.

458
00:29:15.767 --> 00:29:16.947
>> Yep.

459
00:29:16.947 --> 00:29:19.110
>> And you're like, well that's only four.

460
00:29:19.110 --> 00:29:20.135
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

461
00:29:20.135 --> 00:29:23.552
then each one of those has
a significant amount of considerations.

462
00:29:23.552 --> 00:29:27.310
Especially when you're trying to make
sure the service providers are connecting

463
00:29:27.310 --> 00:29:30.550
appropriately, that everybody
has the same corporate vision.

464
00:29:30.550 --> 00:29:35.860
Everybody has the same vision for the
respective subparts of those practices.

465
00:29:35.860 --> 00:29:37.936
And well,
it's starting to make my head spin, Jo.

466
00:29:37.936 --> 00:29:43.390
But I'm sure, I'm sure as we continue on,
we'll gain a little bit of clarity.

467
00:29:43.390 --> 00:29:46.690
Which brings me to the question,
we've talked about practices,

468
00:29:46.690 --> 00:29:48.130
where are we going from here?

469
00:29:48.130 --> 00:29:52.267
>> Well, in our next episode when we
come back, we're going to be looking at

470
00:29:52.267 --> 00:29:56.035
specific roles and responsibilities
within the SIAM ecosystem.

471
00:29:56.035 --> 00:29:59.450
We'll have a couple of episodes
where we're going to look at those.

472
00:29:59.450 --> 00:30:04.309
And then after that, we're gonna delve
really deep into our SIAM processes.

473
00:30:04.309 --> 00:30:05.451
>> Well, there you go.

474
00:30:05.451 --> 00:30:10.335
We're getting ready to find out who does
what and whose responsibility is whose.

475
00:30:10.335 --> 00:30:13.450
There's a lot more coming at you, so
you should definitely join us back.

476
00:30:13.450 --> 00:30:14.920
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

477
00:30:14.920 --> 00:30:17.990
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

478
00:30:17.990 --> 00:30:18.940
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

479
00:30:18.940 --> 00:30:21.284
>> And we'll see you next time.

480
00:30:21.284 --> 00:30:27.320
[MUSIC]

481
00:30:27.320 --> 00:30:30.543
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In these 2 episodes Jo and Justin discuss the various roles that required within each layer of the SIAM eco-system and the responsibilities of each layer and each defined role.
episodes.title: Roles and Responsibilities
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.200 --> 00:00:01.190
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.190 --> 00:00:04.904
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:04.904 --> 00:00:08.365
>> [CROSSTALK]
[SOUND]

4
00:00:08.365 --> 00:00:10.522
>> Your're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:10.522 --> 00:00:16.210
>> Greetings, everyone, and welcome back
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.210 --> 00:00:19.597
I'm your host, Justin Dennison, and
we're continuing on with Siam Foundation.

7
00:00:19.597 --> 00:00:24.210
And well, we're going to be diving
into the roles and responsibilities.

8
00:00:24.210 --> 00:00:27.493
And luckily I'm not the one that
that's telling us all about roles and

9
00:00:27.493 --> 00:00:31.219
responsibilities, but instead we have
an expert in studio with us today, Ms.

10
00:00:31.219 --> 00:00:31.844
Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:31.844 --> 00:00:33.640
How are you doing today, Jo?

12
00:00:33.640 --> 00:00:35.330
>> I'm absolutely great,
thank you, Justin.

13
00:00:35.330 --> 00:00:36.040
How are you?

14
00:00:36.040 --> 00:00:37.960
>> I am doing fantastic as well.

15
00:00:37.960 --> 00:00:43.680
Now, last episode we talked about the four
practices, right, the SIAM practices.

16
00:00:43.680 --> 00:00:45.850
And I remember them, that's the trick.

17
00:00:45.850 --> 00:00:50.095
We have technology, we have people
practices, we have process practices and

18
00:00:50.095 --> 00:00:51.910
we have measurement practices.

19
00:00:51.910 --> 00:00:52.840
>> That's right, yeah.

20
00:00:52.840 --> 00:00:53.840
>> I got them all.

21
00:00:53.840 --> 00:00:57.775
But now we're gonna dive into,
correct me if I'm wrong.

22
00:00:57.775 --> 00:01:01.089
Who does what and what their ultimate
responsibility or groups of people,

23
00:01:01.089 --> 00:01:01.885
I guess, right?

24
00:01:01.885 --> 00:01:05.315
>> Right, we're gonna look
at the roles that we have.

25
00:01:05.315 --> 00:01:07.195
Well, we're gonna look at planning roles,
first of all.

26
00:01:07.195 --> 00:01:11.745
And we're gonna look at the activities
that certain roles will perform,

27
00:01:11.745 --> 00:01:14.285
bearing in mind that we're
in the SIAM ecosystem.

28
00:01:14.285 --> 00:01:18.468
In the SIAM ecosystem we have
a service integrator, and

29
00:01:18.468 --> 00:01:21.680
then we have multiple service providers.

30
00:01:21.680 --> 00:01:23.090
And we also have customers as well.

31
00:01:23.090 --> 00:01:26.450
And customers have some
retained capabilities, too.

32
00:01:26.450 --> 00:01:30.890
So we're looking at nonspecific roles,

33
00:01:30.890 --> 00:01:36.750
because obviously each service provider is
going to have their own level of skills.

34
00:01:36.750 --> 00:01:40.180
They're going to have their own role,
their own responsibilities

35
00:01:40.180 --> 00:01:44.440
within that particular contract that
they have with the service integrator.

36
00:01:44.440 --> 00:01:48.150
And then I refer to it as a contract
because I'm just making that assumption.

37
00:01:48.150 --> 00:01:51.390
Just a generic sort of sweeping comment

38
00:01:51.390 --> 00:01:54.710
that all of our service providers are
going to be external service providers.

39
00:01:54.710 --> 00:01:58.640
Of course, that's not the truth, but
then, we don't know whether the service

40
00:01:58.640 --> 00:02:01.680
integrator is going to be internal or
external, and

41
00:02:01.680 --> 00:02:04.790
whether our service providers
are going to be internal or external.

42
00:02:04.790 --> 00:02:05.990
Of course, if they're internal,

43
00:02:05.990 --> 00:02:08.500
then we're gonna be talking
about service level agreements.

44
00:02:08.500 --> 00:02:12.470
But for external suppliers, then we're
gonna be talking about contracts.

45
00:02:12.470 --> 00:02:16.060
So I just use the generic term,
contract, really,

46
00:02:16.060 --> 00:02:20.490
just to help clarify that,
just to simplify the explanation.

47
00:02:21.930 --> 00:02:26.060
So what we need to do, when we are, no.

48
00:02:26.060 --> 00:02:29.450
I'm gonna ask you, actually,
Justin, just because I can.

49
00:02:31.310 --> 00:02:39.145
When do you think we define the activities
that we expect each role and

50
00:02:39.145 --> 00:02:43.945
responsibility to undertake,
or each role to undertake?

51
00:02:43.945 --> 00:02:45.585
>> Maybe during the planning phase?

52
00:02:45.585 --> 00:02:52.100
>> Right, now during a previous episode,
I mentioned a RACI matrix.

53
00:02:52.100 --> 00:02:55.290
And I know that that was something
in the previous episode that

54
00:02:55.290 --> 00:02:59.010
you didn't know about, or
that you'd never heard of.

55
00:02:59.010 --> 00:03:01.240
Did you remember any of that?

56
00:03:01.240 --> 00:03:05.770
>> I remember the words RACI matrix,
and if I'm not mistaken,

57
00:03:05.770 --> 00:03:12.220
isn't it a matrix of individual
strengths or capabilities?

58
00:03:12.220 --> 00:03:14.412
Nope, I'm seeing the shake of a head, no.

59
00:03:14.412 --> 00:03:16.960
I know it's a matrix for
check boxes and that's all I got.

60
00:03:18.670 --> 00:03:20.810
It's a matrix for check boxes?

61
00:03:20.810 --> 00:03:22.010
It has check boxes.

62
00:03:22.010 --> 00:03:23.270
>> No, it doesn't.

63
00:03:23.270 --> 00:03:23.850
>> I was wrong.

64
00:03:23.850 --> 00:03:26.330
Did we talk about another matrix?

65
00:03:26.330 --> 00:03:26.960
>> [LAUGH] No.

66
00:03:26.960 --> 00:03:29.280
>> I'm pretty sure we did, Jo.

67
00:03:29.280 --> 00:03:30.910
>> No, we didn't, we didn't.

68
00:03:30.910 --> 00:03:31.876
>> Okay.
>> No, no,

69
00:03:31.876 --> 00:03:36.654
what we'll do is with any RACI matrix,
what we do is we'll just take a grid,

70
00:03:36.654 --> 00:03:41.760
a table, and across the top we'll
denote who our stakeholders are.

71
00:03:41.760 --> 00:03:44.920
And then for any given process,
down on one side,

72
00:03:44.920 --> 00:03:49.571
we list all of the activities
that exist within that process.

73
00:03:49.571 --> 00:03:53.650
And then, in the corresponding box,

74
00:03:53.650 --> 00:03:57.900
the one that links that stakeholder
to that particular process activity,

75
00:03:57.900 --> 00:04:02.197
then we'll put a letter in there and
we'll either put an R or an A,

76
00:04:02.197 --> 00:04:07.910
potentially both, or a C, or an I, RACI.

77
00:04:07.910 --> 00:04:13.530
And responsible, accountable for
that task, consulted and informed.

78
00:04:14.710 --> 00:04:16.769
There's only one rule in a RACI matrix,

79
00:04:16.769 --> 00:04:20.172
that only one person could be
accountable for any given activity.

80
00:04:20.172 --> 00:04:22.120
But that's the only rule.

81
00:04:22.120 --> 00:04:25.610
Anybody can be responsible, as many
people as you want can be responsible for

82
00:04:25.610 --> 00:04:28.370
undertaking, completing an activity.

83
00:04:28.370 --> 00:04:32.010
Consulted, well as many people
as you want can be consulted and

84
00:04:32.010 --> 00:04:33.970
you can ask their opinions.

85
00:04:33.970 --> 00:04:37.840
And then informed means to inform
about a particular activity or

86
00:04:37.840 --> 00:04:39.970
about the outcome of
a particular activity.

87
00:04:41.160 --> 00:04:43.480
I do always tell people
to get the balance right.

88
00:04:43.480 --> 00:04:48.290
You don't want too many people
responsible for a particular activity.

89
00:04:48.290 --> 00:04:52.560
But you don't want to consult
too many people, either.

90
00:04:52.560 --> 00:04:55.660
If you consult too many people,
well, the more opinions you ask for,

91
00:04:55.660 --> 00:04:57.300
the more opinions you're going to get,
right?

92
00:04:57.300 --> 00:05:01.630
But then you don't want to come
across as too dictatorial either, so

93
00:05:01.630 --> 00:05:04.800
you don't want to inform too many people.

94
00:05:04.800 --> 00:05:08.720
You want to ensure that you
involve all of our stakeholders.

95
00:05:08.720 --> 00:05:13.580
So we defined the RACI matrix for
any given process and

96
00:05:13.580 --> 00:05:18.760
for any given procedure that's
defined during the planning.

97
00:05:18.760 --> 00:05:19.370
You know what?

98
00:05:19.370 --> 00:05:20.610
We even have a RACI matrix for

99
00:05:20.610 --> 00:05:24.708
the actual implementation
itself of the SIAM ecosystem.

100
00:05:24.708 --> 00:05:28.050
So a RACI matrix is
something that's really,

101
00:05:28.050 --> 00:05:32.150
really useful when you're planning out
specific roles, when you're planning out

102
00:05:32.150 --> 00:05:36.230
specific processes, when you're
planning out specific projects as well.

103
00:05:36.230 --> 00:05:39.169
We'll use a RACI matrix for all of those.

104
00:05:39.169 --> 00:05:41.620
>> And that makes a lot of sense,
but I have to ask.

105
00:05:41.620 --> 00:05:43.840
If I have both RACI or

106
00:05:43.840 --> 00:05:47.080
all of them, not both, all of them,
can I just put a check mark?

107
00:05:47.080 --> 00:05:49.622
>> No, you can't have all of them,
can you?

108
00:05:49.622 --> 00:05:54.540
>> I was trying to find a in around
about that check mark comment.

109
00:05:54.540 --> 00:05:59.800
I mean, I can see the validity or how this
can be helpful when making a plan, right?

110
00:05:59.800 --> 00:06:02.900
You're creating some kind of
visualization that gives you

111
00:06:02.900 --> 00:06:07.580
a broad brush kind of overlook of,
okay, this person is accountable.

112
00:06:07.580 --> 00:06:11.030
These people are responsible,
cuz you only get one accountable, right?

113
00:06:11.030 --> 00:06:11.730
>> Right.

114

each of the layers of our ecosystem.

342
00:19:06.570 --> 00:19:09.750
So for instance,
within our customer organization,

343
00:19:09.750 --> 00:19:12.340
and we call these our
retained capabilities.

344
00:19:12.340 --> 00:19:16.140
We have typical roles such as head of IT,
head of services,

345
00:19:16.140 --> 00:19:18.760
the actual service owners themselves.

346
00:19:18.760 --> 00:19:22.770
They may be doing sort of contract
management and demand management,

347
00:19:22.770 --> 00:19:24.560
financial management.

348
00:19:24.560 --> 00:19:30.300
And in fact we actually look at
the customers' roles specifically here and

349
00:19:30.300 --> 00:19:31.845
what that role does.

350
00:19:31.845 --> 00:19:34.130
And they are responsible for

351
00:19:34.130 --> 00:19:38.990
defining exactly what they value,
what they want to achieve.

352
00:19:38.990 --> 00:19:41.140
They also define
the end-to-end budget as well,

353
00:19:41.140 --> 00:19:43.440
which is how much money
have they got to spend.

354
00:19:44.590 --> 00:19:47.730
Then let's take a look at
the service integrator.

355
00:19:47.730 --> 00:19:49.230
And the service integrator role,

356
00:19:49.230 --> 00:19:53.510
well, we should have somebody who is
in charge of the service integrator.

357
00:19:53.510 --> 00:19:57.977
We should have maybe a service delivery
manager or service managers and

358
00:19:57.977 --> 00:20:00.445
we should have process owners as well.

359
00:20:00.445 --> 00:20:06.958
That's somebody who takes accountability,
not responsibility but accountability for

360
00:20:06.958 --> 00:20:12.186
the individual processes including
the process managers that they take

361
00:20:12.186 --> 00:20:17.706
the responsibilities for managing
the processes on a day-to-day basis.

362
00:20:17.706 --> 00:20:24.840
And so look at the responsibilities
of a service integrator as a whole,

363
00:20:24.840 --> 00:20:30.630
not just one person, but
looking at the layer as whole,

364
00:20:30.630 --> 00:20:35.450
things like reporting for
instance and performance management.

365
00:20:35.450 --> 00:20:39.420
And I love where it says,
acting as the customer's agent,

366
00:20:39.420 --> 00:20:43.640
ensuring that we've got the right
communication methods, and we're using

367
00:20:43.640 --> 00:20:48.089
the right communication language
between all of our service providers.

368
00:20:49.100 --> 00:20:51.500
And then you've got
the providers themselves.

369
00:20:51.500 --> 00:20:52.720
And these are people that,

370
00:20:52.720 --> 00:20:57.950
well I expect to have account managers
within each individual service provider.

371
00:20:57.950 --> 00:21:01.300
You may also have process managers
within each service provider.

372
00:21:01.300 --> 00:21:04.080
Be careful where it says process owner.

373
00:21:04.080 --> 00:21:07.760
But there maybe a process on a for
the service provider.

374
00:21:07.760 --> 00:21:12.710
But for your process in the SIAM
ecosystem, the owner is within,

375
00:21:12.710 --> 00:21:16.220
unless we gotta lead supplier situation,
but

376
00:21:16.220 --> 00:21:21.180
other than that, the process
owner with within the integrator.

377
00:21:21.180 --> 00:21:26.520
Because they have the accountability for
defining the process and

378
00:21:26.520 --> 00:21:31.170
defining what the process looks like and
certainly the improvement of the process.

379
00:21:32.770 --> 00:21:35.490
And then we just got some

380
00:21:35.490 --> 00:21:39.430
examples here of some typical
responsibilities of the service provider.

381
00:21:39.430 --> 00:21:42.740
Ultimately, these are the people that
are actually doing the development work.

382
00:21:42.740 --> 00:21:44.520
They're the people doing the support work.

383
00:21:45.580 --> 00:21:51.260
One of the responsibilities we mentioned
things like adhering to policies etc.

384
00:21:51.260 --> 00:21:55.229
One of the responsibilities
of any service provider and

385
00:21:55.229 --> 00:21:58.950
any role in any service
provider is collaboration.

386
00:22:00.050 --> 00:22:01.980
And collaboration is key.

387
00:22:03.020 --> 00:22:05.580
The SIAM ecosystem is not

388
00:22:05.580 --> 00:22:10.820
going to work without collaboration
across all our service provider roles.

389
00:22:10.820 --> 00:22:13.880
And so if Justin decides that
he doesn't want to do his work,

390
00:22:13.880 --> 00:22:19.160
it is not going to be down to another
service provider to pick up the slack.

391
00:22:19.160 --> 00:22:21.584
If Justin decides that he
doesn't wanna play ball,

392
00:22:21.584 --> 00:22:24.960
that he doesn't care what's in his
contract, he's not going to do it.

393
00:22:24.960 --> 00:22:30.360
Then I, as a service integrator,
it's my role to pick up the pieces and

394
00:22:30.360 --> 00:22:34.140
to, I was just gonna say
take just into tasks, but

395
00:22:34.140 --> 00:22:40.345
maybe I'm gonna perform some sort of
service review, a performance review.

396
00:22:40.345 --> 00:22:46.135
First of all, to find out exactly where
we can improve and what can be done about

397
00:22:46.135 --> 00:22:50.915
the fact that, well quite simply, Justin
doesn't want to talk to anybody else.

398
00:22:50.915 --> 00:22:53.165
>> Well you know Jo, I can't help it.

399
00:22:53.165 --> 00:22:57.236
I mean, you actually said something a
little while ago where we're talking about

400
00:22:57.236 --> 00:23:01.680
you're going above and beyond your
contract or maybe it's not written down.

401
00:23:01.680 --> 00:23:05.370
And these are the things that I've,
granted this is my baggage,

402
00:23:05.370 --> 00:23:08.030
as you said, that I've been burnt by.

403
00:23:08.030 --> 00:23:11.980
Where you go above and beyond, and
you're setting unrealistic expectations

404
00:23:11.980 --> 00:23:15.350
to where it becomes a normal expectation,
right?

405
00:23:16.370 --> 00:23:19.580
And then now the perception
is if I stop doing that then

406
00:23:19.580 --> 00:23:20.590
I'm not providing the value.

407
00:23:20.590 --> 00:23:23.600
But that's not what I was
brought on to provide value for.

408
00:23:23.600 --> 00:23:25.980
>> Right.
>> At the respective time.

409
00:23:25.980 --> 00:23:27.360
So I'm all about clarity.

410
00:23:27.360 --> 00:23:32.120
Whether it's, we're outside of SIAM here,
whether it's like family or friend or

411
00:23:32.120 --> 00:23:34.300
whatever it may be,
they get all weirded out.

412
00:23:34.300 --> 00:23:36.000
They're like,
what do you mean you want it in writing?

413
00:23:36.000 --> 00:23:40.700
I was like I wanna make sure we have
an appropriate, clarified set of

414
00:23:40.700 --> 00:23:45.530
expectations that we can all just
kind of convene on and agree upon.

415
00:23:45.530 --> 00:23:46.960
That's why I would have an issue with,

416
00:23:46.960 --> 00:23:51.220
like, here's the things you're going to
do, because it's based on assumptions.

417
00:23:51.220 --> 00:23:51.940
>> Right.
>> And

418
00:23:51.940 --> 00:23:54.550
those assumptions
are based on perception of

419
00:23:54.550 --> 00:23:56.620
something that you may not
necessarily know about.

420
00:23:56.620 --> 00:23:59.590
>> What you were talking about there is
what we'd call assumed responsibilities.

421
00:23:59.590 --> 00:24:03.525
An assumed responsibility is a
responsibility That you have assumed that

422
00:24:03.525 --> 00:24:08.200
you haven't actually signed up for, but
it's something that you have assumed.

423
00:24:08.200 --> 00:24:10.570
On whether it's because I've
assumed that you're doing it or

424
00:24:10.570 --> 00:24:13.620
whether because you're doing it
out of the kindness of your heart.

425
00:24:13.620 --> 00:24:15.730
It's an assumed responsibility.

426
00:24:15.730 --> 00:24:19.390
And you'll be surprised how
often that actually happens and

427
00:24:19.390 --> 00:24:23.360
that a lot of service providers
undertake assumed responsibilities

428
00:24:23.360 --> 00:24:26.310
without even realizing
that they're doing that.

429
00:24:26.310 --> 00:24:32.170
And it's only when those particular
activity stop that the customer and

430
00:24:32.170 --> 00:24:37.130
the service integrator, but
most notably the customer is actually,

431
00:24:37.130 --> 00:24:41.630
is in a position where the service
value has been degraded.

432
00:24:41.630 --> 00:24:45.150
And sometimes it can take
the service integrated quite a while

433
00:24:45.150 --> 00:24:48.660
to figure out why service
has been degraded.

434
00:24:48.660 --> 00:24:52.550
And so that's really important from the
service integrator perspective as well,

435
00:24:52.550 --> 00:24:55.320
is that any assumed
responsibilities are documented.

436
00:24:55.320 --> 00:24:58.440
And it's not just about protecting
you as the service provider,

437
00:24:58.440 --> 00:25:00.260
it's also about protecting the customer.

438
00:25:00.260 --> 00:25:04.330
And so the service integrator
needs to ensure that we've got

439
00:25:04.330 --> 00:25:06.310
all of those responsibilities documented.

440
00:25:06.310 --> 00:25:10.290
So we know what we're paying for and
we also know what we can expect.

441
00:25:10.290 --> 00:25:13.770
So we know what the level
of service that we

442
00:25:13.770 --> 00:25:16.740
can assure the customer
that they are going to get.

443
00:25:16.740 --> 00:25:18.610
>> And that makes perfect sense.

444
00:25:18.610 --> 00:25:21.570
And I wanna make sure that I
understand one part of this.

445
00:25:21.570 --> 00:25:25.150
We looked at those respective roles, but
we had the grand title for each layer.

446
00:25:25.150 --> 00:25:28.490
We had the customer organization,
we had the service integrator,

447
00:25:28.490 --> 00:25:31.090
and then we had the service provider.

448
00:25:31.090 --> 00:25:34.750
But we could have multiple of
those roles and probably will be

449
00:25:34.750 --> 00:25:38.470
with the associated responsibilities
at each one of those layers, correct?

450
00:25:38.470 --> 00:25:43.860
>> Right, and we can't give you a
difinitive list of what roles are gong to

451
00:25:43.860 --> 00:25:49.210
exist in every single layer
of the Sayan ecosystem.

452
00:25:49.210 --> 00:25:53.490
When we come back in our part two episode,
we're gonna look further at governance and

453
00:25:53.490 --> 00:25:57.870
the roles that the existing governments
and the decisions that have to be made.

454
00:25:57.870 --> 00:26:02.455
But for you and
your organisations within that ecosystem.

455
00:26:02.455 --> 00:26:04.880
I mean, we can use some examples there and

456
00:26:04.880 --> 00:26:09.480
I'll give you some examples that
I'd certainly be expecting you to

457
00:26:09.480 --> 00:26:14.250
take a look at certainly in
preparation for your foundation test.

458
00:26:14.250 --> 00:26:17.600
But these are just there just to give
you a little bit of a prompt, so

459
00:26:17.600 --> 00:26:21.770
that when you are in a position
where you're in a SIAM ecosystem and

460
00:26:21.770 --> 00:26:26.700
you are looking to implement and
to evolve into that ecosystem.

461
00:26:26.700 --> 00:26:29.380
And then,
these are just some considerations.

462
00:26:29.380 --> 00:26:33.010
But there is no definitive
guide as to what roles and

463
00:26:33.010 --> 00:26:34.910
responsibilities you're going to have.

464
00:26:34.910 --> 00:26:38.020
Because quite simply, we don't know
what your environment's gonna look like,

465
00:26:38.020 --> 00:26:40.710
and every single environment is unique.

466
00:26:40.710 --> 00:26:43.120
>> And well Jo,
I think you've hit the nail on the head.

467
00:26:43.120 --> 00:26:47.220
Decisions a lot of times are context
specific and while we've just started

468
00:26:47.220 --> 00:26:51.530
diving into roles and responsibilities,
but you said the G word, yes, governance.

469
00:26:51.530 --> 00:26:56.504
And we're gonna have to come back for
a part two in order to.

470
00:26:56.504 --> 00:27:00.280
It could be a bad time, but we're gonna
have to come back to a part two to

471
00:27:00.280 --> 00:27:04.110
actually give it its full time to explore.

472
00:27:04.110 --> 00:27:05.570
So definitely come back, but for

473
00:27:05.570 --> 00:27:07.100
right now, we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

474
00:27:07.100 --> 00:27:10.180
So signing off for ITPro.TV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

475
00:27:10.180 --> 00:27:11.010
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

476
00:27:11.010 --> 00:27:13.240
>> And we'll see you next time.

477
00:27:13.240 --> 00:27:19.354
[MUSIC]

478
00:27:19.354 --> 00:27:22.667
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In these 2 episodes Jo and Justin discuss the various roles that required within each layer of the SIAM eco-system and the responsibilities of each layer and each defined role.
episodes.title: Roles and Responsibilities Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.093 --> 00:00:02.355
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.355 --> 00:00:06.585
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.585 --> 00:00:08.423
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.423 --> 00:00:11.961
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.961 --> 00:00:15.280
>> Greetings everyone and welcome to
another exciting episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.280 --> 00:00:19.211
I'm your host Justin Dennison and
well, we're in part two for

7
00:00:19.211 --> 00:00:23.828
roles and responsibilities which is
part of our SIAM Foundation Course.

8
00:00:23.828 --> 00:00:28.100
And well, you should definitely go watch
part one because we gave an overview.

9
00:00:28.100 --> 00:00:30.780
But we're coming back to talk
a little more about governance.

10
00:00:30.780 --> 00:00:35.050
And luckily we have someone who's gonna
tell us all about it, Ms. Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:35.050 --> 00:00:36.150
How are you doing today, Jo?

12
00:00:36.150 --> 00:00:38.410
>> Absolutely great, thank you,
Justin, how are you?

13
00:00:38.410 --> 00:00:42.710
>> I am doing fantastic as well and
I've heard the g word, governance.

14
00:00:42.710 --> 00:00:46.640
I know there's a few other things but
that's what I kinda fixated on because

15
00:00:46.640 --> 00:00:50.330
It's both I think important, yet
terrifying to me, personally.

16
00:00:51.660 --> 00:00:53.360
>> Why are you frightened, Governor?

17
00:00:53.360 --> 00:00:55.690
Should I ask or maybe I shouldn't ask.

18
00:00:55.690 --> 00:00:57.570
Maybe it's just something
I don't need to know.

19
00:00:58.640 --> 00:01:00.855
>> It is probably something.

20
00:01:00.855 --> 00:01:02.853
>> Well, let's just carry on, I guess.

21
00:01:02.853 --> 00:01:06.895
[LAUGH]
>> Well, governance means,

22
00:01:06.895 --> 00:01:11.705
well, in ITIL terms we refer to governance
as being controlled but with fairness and

23
00:01:11.705 --> 00:01:12.682
transparency.

24
00:01:12.682 --> 00:01:16.942
Dominants are all of the policies
that give us direction.

25
00:01:16.942 --> 00:01:22.542
As an IT service provider environment,
as an IT service integrator,

26
00:01:22.542 --> 00:01:30.500
we have to decide on policies for
governance, for direction, for strategies.

27
00:01:30.500 --> 00:01:34.666
And so we have governance at
absolutely every single layer, and

28
00:01:34.666 --> 00:01:38.520
we'll see that we've got on
a diagram here in front of us.

29
00:01:38.520 --> 00:01:43.129
We have got our governance layers there,
both customer and service integrator,

30
00:01:43.129 --> 00:01:45.080
and service provider layer.

31
00:01:45.080 --> 00:01:49.720
And governance is said
about setting direction.

32
00:01:49.720 --> 00:01:54.780
And so we've got governance that at our
customer and our service integrator layer,

33
00:01:54.780 --> 00:01:58.750
they are set in the direction for
our service providers.

34
00:01:58.750 --> 00:01:59.860
So they are directing.

35
00:01:59.860 --> 00:02:03.360
They're monitoring what our
service providers are doing.

36
00:02:03.360 --> 00:02:06.920
They're evaluating what our service
providers are doing, and then they

37
00:02:06.920 --> 00:02:12.700
are directing, directing adjustments to
the way that our service providers work.

38
00:02:12.700 --> 00:02:16.300
Now, from our service provider
perspective, their governance is all about

39
00:02:16.300 --> 00:02:22.090
planning, building, running and
monitoring our services.

40
00:02:22.090 --> 00:02:25.330
So our service providers are managing.

41
00:02:25.330 --> 00:02:28.850
But they still have to have
policies to be able to do that.

42
00:02:28.850 --> 00:02:32.140
And so this is what governance does.

43
00:02:32.140 --> 00:02:38.700
And we have various governance boards
that will manage each individual layer.

44
00:02:38.700 --> 00:02:41.863
So let's take a look at examples.

45
00:02:41.863 --> 00:02:43.761
And again, these are just examples,

46
00:02:43.761 --> 00:02:47.715
very similar to in our part one where we
looked at roles and responsibilities.

47
00:02:47.715 --> 00:02:49.555
I gave you some examples.

48
00:02:49.555 --> 00:02:51.155
And in this particular episode,

49
00:02:51.155 --> 00:02:53.545
we're gonna look at examples
of governance roles.

50
00:02:53.545 --> 00:02:57.662
And we're also going to look at a couple
of things that are sort of common

51
00:02:57.662 --> 00:03:02.912
activities that happen
within IT in general and

52
00:03:02.912 --> 00:03:07.322
something that has to be considered
across all of our service providers.

53
00:03:07.322 --> 00:03:11.392
So first of all we're gonna take a look
at our executive governance roles, and

54
00:03:11.392 --> 00:03:14.400
our executive governance roles I expect

55
00:03:14.400 --> 00:03:18.120
sort of steering groups to
meet on a quarterly basis.

56
00:03:19.420 --> 00:03:23.040
I say quarterly, every three months,
every four months,

57
00:03:23.040 --> 00:03:27.850
it could be, and I don't expect
a steering group to meet every week.

58
00:03:27.850 --> 00:03:32.150
I don't expect a steering
group to meet every month.

59
00:03:32.150 --> 00:03:38.270
I expect them to meet at a frequent basis,
but nevertheless I expect them to meet

60
00:03:38.270 --> 00:03:43.218
at an interval that is well,
realistic should we say?

61
00:03:43.218 --> 00:03:45.400
They're setting direction.

62
00:03:45.400 --> 00:03:51.090
Think about how often we need to
make decisions on setting direction.

63
00:03:51.090 --> 00:03:56.170
We don't need to make decisions on
setting direction every single week.

64
00:03:57.590 --> 00:04:03.300
If your steering group within your
governance model is meeting every single

65
00:04:03.300 --> 00:04:08.720
week or even every single month, and
you're operating on a tactical level and

66
00:04:08.720 --> 00:04:11.580
perhaps you're getting too
involved into the minutiae.

67
00:04:11.580 --> 00:04:14.700
Perhaps you're getting too
involved in the micromanaging.

68
00:04:14.700 --> 00:04:17.840
You're most definitely not
at that governance level.

69
00:04:17.840 --> 00:04:19.710
This is something that I see quite often.

70
00:04:19.710 --> 00:04:25.930
When I go into organizations in week
before a maturity assessment, the steering

71
00:04:25.930 --> 00:04:32.500
group that meets at a frequency that
is way too great, every single week.

72
00:04:32.500 --> 00:04:37.570
And what they're actually doing is they're
discussing elements of the management of

73
00:04:37.570 --> 00:04:39.290
the ecosystem.

74
00:04:40.330 --> 00:04:43.260
And these are elements that
they shouldn't be discussing.

75
00:04:43.260 --> 00:04:46.590
These are elements that
management should be discussing.

76
00:04:46.590 --> 00:04:49.090
And so be very, very careful.

77
00:04:49.090 --> 00:04:52.010
We should always have an agenda and

78
00:04:52.010 --> 00:04:57.190
have a well let's just
say we should have some

79
00:04:57.190 --> 00:05:02.020
form of vision for each steering group.

80
00:05:02.020 --> 00:05:05.380
We should understand what
it is that that vision or

81
00:05:05.380 --> 00:05:08.200
that that steering group
is there to achieve.

82
00:05:08.200 --> 00:05:12.040
And we should stick to that vision, and
if the steering group or the vision for

83
00:05:12.040 --> 00:05:16.130
the steering group Is just to very simply,
well,

84
00:05:16.130 --> 00:05:21.164
decide on direction, or to decide
on new endeavors, a new innovation,

85
00:05:21.164 --> 00:05:26.500
and new services for
our customer for the next six months.

86
00:05:26.500 --> 00:05:31.516
Well, that's all the steering group
should be convened to discuss.

87
00:05:31.516 --> 00:05:34.270
So decide on the vision on the charter for

88
00:05:34.270 --> 00:05:38.890
that particular steering group or
for the board and stick to it.

89
00:05:38.890 --> 00:05:44.540
If you get into the individual management
of certain operational factors,

90
00:05:44.540 --> 00:05:47.830
it's no longer a steering a group,
