strategies for the organization.

502
00:28:49.254 --> 00:28:53.951
We should be in a position as a service
integrator, as a service provider

503
00:28:53.951 --> 00:28:57.727
we should be in a position to
be able to say to our business.

504
00:28:57.727 --> 00:29:01.924
Hey look, I see that you're
struggling with a certain thing,

505
00:29:01.924 --> 00:29:03.515
with a certain aspect.

506
00:29:03.515 --> 00:29:08.859
Looks to me like you would need something
a little bit more portable to do your job,

507
00:29:08.859 --> 00:29:10.881
let me see what I can do for you.

508
00:29:10.881 --> 00:29:16.087
So much, but I was gonna say the word
better but that's not the right word.

509
00:29:16.087 --> 00:29:21.147
It adds much more value,
if we can do that to our customers rather

510
00:29:21.147 --> 00:29:25.752
than we wait for our customer
to say to us, I want a tablet.

511
00:29:25.752 --> 00:29:28.631
Because you see when a customer
comes to us and says,

512
00:29:28.631 --> 00:29:33.028
we need tablets then we've then gotta
go back to potential service providers.

513
00:29:33.028 --> 00:29:37.255
We might have to evaluate different
service providers to see which option is

514
00:29:37.255 --> 00:29:37.988
best for us.

515
00:29:37.988 --> 00:29:40.887
And then we go back to the customer and
we say okay,

516
00:29:40.887 --> 00:29:45.258
this is the option that's available for
you, that could be three months.

517
00:29:45.258 --> 00:29:49.529
Three months could have happened in
that point, by the time we've gone back.

518
00:29:49.529 --> 00:29:51.189
Well, that doesn't make any sense.

519
00:29:51.189 --> 00:29:54.493
So much better for me to have looked and
seen what Justin was doing, and

520
00:29:54.493 --> 00:29:58.146
said, that thing could really do with
something a little bit more portable.

521
00:29:58.146 --> 00:30:00.654
Let me go and
have a word with our service providers.

522
00:30:00.654 --> 00:30:03.479
Let's see what's available,
and then, yeah,

523
00:30:03.479 --> 00:30:05.844
it might take another two months, or so.

524
00:30:05.844 --> 00:30:09.603
But now in two months' time,
Justin hasn't said anything to me yet.

525
00:30:09.603 --> 00:30:14.144
And then in two months I can go to
Justin and say, Justin, you know what,

526
00:30:14.144 --> 00:30:18.484
I see you struggling with that
l;laptop how about if i gave you this?

527
00:30:18.484 --> 00:30:19.928
You would perceive so

528
00:30:19.928 --> 00:30:25.225
much more value in me being proactive than
in you having to ask for something and

529
00:30:25.225 --> 00:30:29.573
then me not responding to you for
three months, wouldn't you?

530
00:30:29.573 --> 00:30:30.626
>> I definitely would and

531
00:30:30.626 --> 00:30:33.237
I think this comes back to
having that high sample rate.

532
00:30:33.237 --> 00:30:37.539
Keeping you kind of your finger in
the pulse of what's going on, whereas

533
00:30:37.539 --> 00:30:42.066
not only are you listening to things
that you need to fix, you're looking.

534
00:30:42.066 --> 00:30:44.300
Okay, well maybe a tablet would help here.

535
00:30:44.300 --> 00:30:51.010
Maybe a better network would help over in
this area, or whatever it may be, right.

536
00:30:51.010 --> 00:30:51.804
>> Yeah.

537
00:30:51.804 --> 00:30:54.780
>> And that makes sense, because if
you come to me and you're like, hey,

538
00:30:54.780 --> 00:30:57.293
I noticed that these things,
I'm trying to help you.

539
00:30:57.293 --> 00:31:00.409
You're solving a problem that I
didn't even know I had- [CROSSTALK]

540
00:31:00.409 --> 00:31:01.071
>> Exactly.

541
00:31:01.071 --> 00:31:02.100
>> Before it became a problem.

542
00:31:02.100 --> 00:31:03.447
>> Yep, exactly.

543
00:31:03.447 --> 00:31:08.180
And that's exactly what business
relationship management should be doing.

544
00:31:08.180 --> 00:31:12.101
They should be managing that
relationship with the business and

545
00:31:12.101 --> 00:31:15.889
it should be an interactive
relationship with the business.

546
00:31:15.889 --> 00:31:18.246
It should not be a one way relationship.

547
00:31:18.246 --> 00:31:22.249
And it should not exist
based purely on interviews.

548
00:31:22.249 --> 00:31:26.671
Is everything all right with your meal,
that's not what the relationship is.

549
00:31:26.671 --> 00:31:29.745
That's not a relationship,
that's an interview.

550
00:31:29.745 --> 00:31:33.679
And you know what, with that type
of interview as we like to call it,

551
00:31:33.679 --> 00:31:37.352
I don't know whether he's lying to me or
not, let's face it.

552
00:31:37.352 --> 00:31:40.729
And this is Justin we're talking about,
right?

553
00:31:40.729 --> 00:31:42.032
>> I am not a good liar.

554
00:31:42.032 --> 00:31:43.118
I do not feign emotions well.

555
00:31:43.118 --> 00:31:46.088
>> [LAUGH]
>> Or maybe I'm lying about that.

556
00:31:46.088 --> 00:31:46.836
Who knows, right?

557
00:31:46.836 --> 00:31:50.647
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, let's not go there.

558
00:31:50.647 --> 00:31:54.011
Okay, well for now,
I wanna really wrap this out for BRM,

559
00:31:54.011 --> 00:31:56.424
unless you've got any other questions.

560
00:31:56.424 --> 00:32:00.122
I'm sure there's gonna be a plethora
of questions that crop up as we kind of

561
00:32:00.122 --> 00:32:01.776
explore these other processes.

562
00:32:01.776 --> 00:32:05.195
I may come back to BRM,
because I'm like these are related things.

563
00:32:05.195 --> 00:32:08.363
But for now, I think I'm pretty good.

564
00:32:08.363 --> 00:32:10.367
Well, I think I'm pretty good.

565
00:32:10.367 --> 00:32:12.916
[LAUGH] I don't know if I actually am,
though.

566
00:32:12.916 --> 00:32:16.973
>> I'm not saying anything,
I'm saying nothing at all.

567
00:32:16.973 --> 00:32:19.288
>> But Jo,
where are we actually gonna go from here?

568
00:32:19.288 --> 00:32:22.329
What are the other processes
that are kinda coming up next?

569
00:32:22.329 --> 00:32:26.215
>> Well, you mentioned the word plethora,
that's exactly what we've got.

570
00:32:26.215 --> 00:32:29.372
But what we're gonna do in our next
episode is we're gonna look at change

571
00:32:29.372 --> 00:32:30.003
management.

572
00:32:30.003 --> 00:32:33.529
We're going to look at release
management in our next episode.

573
00:32:33.529 --> 00:32:38.004
We like to combine those two together
in one episode just purely because

574
00:32:38.004 --> 00:32:40.475
the synergy between them and the flow.

575
00:32:40.475 --> 00:32:42.755
So we'll take a look at
that when we come back.

576
00:32:42.755 --> 00:32:44.742
>> All right,
well that sounds like a plan Jo.

577
00:32:44.742 --> 00:32:48.244
I'm definitely looking forward to
finding out all the thing I don't know.

578
00:32:48.244 --> 00:32:52.813
And then feeling good about myself when I
actually go, hey that make sense to me.

579
00:32:52.813 --> 00:32:56.444
So definitely come on back, we've got
more SIAM Processes coming at you but

580
00:32:56.444 --> 00:32:58.782
for now we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

581
00:32:58.782 --> 00:33:01.862
So signing off for ITPro.TV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

582
00:33:01.862 --> 00:33:02.683
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

583
00:33:02.683 --> 00:33:04.896
>> And we'll see you next time.

584
00:33:04.896 --> 00:33:10.917
[MUSIC]

585
00:33:10.917 --> 00:33:14.067
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: An explanation of the purpose and objectives of the SIAM Change Management and Release Management processes.
episodes.title: SIAM Processes - Change Mgmt. and Release Mgmt.
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.401
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.401 --> 00:00:05.829
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.829 --> 00:00:07.650
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.650 --> 00:00:11.564
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.564 --> 00:00:15.340
>> Greetings everyone and welcome back
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.340 --> 00:00:16.894
I'm your host Justin Dennison and

7
00:00:16.894 --> 00:00:19.424
we're continuing on with
our SIAM foundation series.

8
00:00:19.424 --> 00:00:23.141
And well, we're gonna be looking
at change and release management.

9
00:00:23.141 --> 00:00:25.115
Well, change management and
release management.

10
00:00:25.115 --> 00:00:28.447
Let me make sure we know those
are actually two separate processes.

11
00:00:28.447 --> 00:00:31.211
And here to help us along in that
very endeavor is Miss Jo Peacock,

12
00:00:31.211 --> 00:00:32.383
how are you doing today Jo?

13
00:00:32.383 --> 00:00:34.647
>> Absolutely great, thank you,
Justin, how are you?

14
00:00:34.647 --> 00:00:40.976
>> I'm doing well, as well, and so
we've combined these two things.

15
00:00:40.976 --> 00:00:44.269
And I guess that's because they relate,
our change management and

16
00:00:44.269 --> 00:00:47.863
release management interrelated or
do they make sister group together.

17
00:00:47.863 --> 00:00:51.830
Or are we just saying well,
these two things are processes and

18
00:00:51.830 --> 00:00:54.411
we now have about 15 minutes for reach.

19
00:00:56.864 --> 00:00:58.140
>> Well,
I don't know what to say that really.

20
00:00:58.140 --> 00:01:00.226
>> [LAUGH]
>> Do we have 15 minutes for reach?

21
00:01:00.226 --> 00:01:02.522
I don't think we have 15 minutes for each.

22
00:01:02.522 --> 00:01:06.946
We like to combine them cuz it makes sense
to combine them because depending on

23
00:01:06.946 --> 00:01:09.884
the scale, and
it's gonna take some explaining.

24
00:01:09.884 --> 00:01:14.945
But depending on the scale change might
then evolve into release management.

25
00:01:14.945 --> 00:01:18.778
Might, there's a might to this but
they are linked.

26
00:01:18.778 --> 00:01:21.983
And so, we can't really separate them.

27
00:01:21.983 --> 00:01:25.451
Put it this way, we can't have release
management without change management,

28
00:01:25.451 --> 00:01:26.731
we have to have change first.

29
00:01:26.731 --> 00:01:29.541
But we can have change management
without release management.

30
00:01:29.541 --> 00:01:33.268
See, I told you it wasn't gonna
be that simple, didn't I?

31
00:01:33.268 --> 00:01:37.611
>> [LAUGH] Most of you can't see, but
most of the time when she says something.

32
00:01:37.611 --> 00:01:42.398
And I get this real inquisitive look, I'm
trying to like, noodle around in my brain,

33
00:01:42.398 --> 00:01:43.985
okay, change management.

34
00:01:43.985 --> 00:01:47.724
How could I not have release management
but I have a very particular bias?

35
00:01:47.724 --> 00:01:51.621
I think that's part of the issue, is I
have a bias where I'm like, changes and

36
00:01:51.621 --> 00:01:52.692
then I have releases.

37
00:01:52.692 --> 00:01:55.201
And that's based on my background,
that's not always the case.

38
00:01:55.201 --> 00:01:57.777
>> Yeah, but then you're asking
the questions that most people will

39
00:01:57.777 --> 00:01:58.289
ask anyway.

40
00:01:58.289 --> 00:02:05.371
And that's really whatâ€™s important here
is that I can answer a lot of questions.

41
00:02:05.371 --> 00:02:07.503
Or I can try and
pre-empt a lot of questions but

42
00:02:07.503 --> 00:02:09.597
I can't pre-empt absolutely everything.

43
00:02:09.597 --> 00:02:12.813
And so you're answering the questions
that most people are answering,

44
00:02:12.813 --> 00:02:13.981
they're asking anyway.

45
00:02:13.981 --> 00:02:16.039
So I wouldn't worry too much about that.

46
00:02:16.039 --> 00:02:22.237
Change management is about controlling
changes to our environment.

47
00:02:22.237 --> 00:02:26.181
And what we've got to remember
is that in this ecosystem,

48
00:02:26.181 --> 00:02:28.840
this is critically important.

49
00:02:28.840 --> 00:02:31.439
Because, can I use those two
words together, I'm going to.

50
00:02:31.439 --> 00:02:33.848
Because I wanna really highlight
the severity of this and

51
00:02:33.848 --> 00:02:35.364
highlight the importance of this.

52
00:02:35.364 --> 00:02:38.108
Change management is critically important,

53
00:02:38.108 --> 00:02:42.550
because change management controls
change to the customer environment.

54
00:02:42.550 --> 00:02:45.406
Let's take a look at the purpose
of change management.

55
00:02:45.406 --> 00:02:51.336
It's to ensure that changes are made
with minimal amounts of disruption.

56
00:02:51.336 --> 00:02:55.224
And yes, we're kind of combined
with release management but

57
00:02:55.224 --> 00:02:57.627
I'm gonna come on to that in a second.

58
00:02:57.627 --> 00:03:03.334
So change management is about ensuring
that the changes to the live environment.

59
00:03:03.334 --> 00:03:10.602
That a live customer environment have
very, very little negative impact.

60
00:03:10.602 --> 00:03:13.837
All right,
I wanna put this in another way,

61
00:03:13.837 --> 00:03:17.785
that the impact to the live
environment is positive.

62
00:03:17.785 --> 00:03:22.700
And that the positive impact of any
change outweighs the negative impact of

63
00:03:22.700 --> 00:03:23.566
any change.

64
00:03:23.566 --> 00:03:24.889
Does that make more sense?

65
00:03:24.889 --> 00:03:28.210
>> That makes sense at an abstract level.

66
00:03:28.210 --> 00:03:32.674
>> [LAUGH]
>> It makes sense based on my experiences,

67
00:03:32.674 --> 00:03:33.284
right?

68
00:03:33.284 --> 00:03:37.293
As a developer you're like, okay,
I'm trying to make this update, and

69
00:03:37.293 --> 00:03:40.668
I'm getting a positive set of features or
whatever it may be.

70
00:03:40.668 --> 00:03:43.466
But I'm not taking down
the system in order to do that.

71
00:03:43.466 --> 00:03:44.572
>> And that's exactly it,

72
00:03:44.572 --> 00:03:47.843
we've gotta make sure that positive
impact outweighs negative impact.

73
00:03:47.843 --> 00:03:51.287
So the feature that we're adding
will have a positive impact, but

74
00:03:51.287 --> 00:03:55.366
we don't wanna have a detrimental impact
on any of our other services as well.

75
00:03:55.366 --> 00:03:59.451
This is generally, and
the reason why change is so

76
00:03:59.451 --> 00:04:05.294
important because this is generally
where we realize, as a business.

77
00:04:05.294 --> 00:04:10.990
This is where we realize when things
haven't gone quite the way we planned it,

78
00:04:10.990 --> 00:04:14.978
or this is when we realize
that we're in a bit of a mess.

79
00:04:14.978 --> 00:04:20.155
If we go back to some previous episodes,
and right at the very beginning

80
00:04:20.155 --> 00:04:25.614
of this particular series, we looked
at why we would need SIAM ecosystem.

81
00:04:25.614 --> 00:04:29.796
And one of the justifications for
the SIAM ecosystem is when we had

82
00:04:29.796 --> 00:04:34.357
a lot of customers, a lot of business
units that would be going directly

83
00:04:34.357 --> 00:04:39.314
to supplies themselves directly to
service providers for whatever reason.

84
00:04:39.314 --> 00:04:43.054
Maybe they didn't feel that internal
IT was meeting their needs or

85
00:04:43.054 --> 00:04:46.213
maybe they didn't feel that
IT was responsive enough.

86
00:04:46.213 --> 00:04:48.325
Whatever those reasons may be,

87
00:04:48.325 --> 00:04:52.088
business units went directly
to the service providers.

88
00:04:52.088 --> 00:04:57.678
And it's generally because of fail
changes, that's what a drives

89
00:04:57.678 --> 00:05:03.082
a business to realize that we need
to manage our services better.

90
00:05:03.082 --> 00:05:05.996
Because one business unit has
got a service provider and

91
00:05:05.996 --> 00:05:09.039
they have a relationship with
this one service provider.

92
00:05:09.039 --> 00:05:12.830
And that one service provider made
a change to that application and

93
00:05:12.830 --> 00:05:15.888
then it effect did the whole
entire infrastructure.

94
00:05:15.888 --> 00:05:21.763
And that's why the business then said,
we can't have that happen again.

95
00:05:21.763 --> 00:05:23.992
So it's generally change.

96
00:05:23.992 --> 00:05:27.225
It's either that or it's an incident
where something's gone wrong and

97
00:05:27.225 --> 00:05:30.300
nobody wants to resolve it because
everybody's pointing fingers.

98
00:05:30.300 --> 00:05:34.097
That's what tells the business
that something's got to happen.

99
00:05:34.097 --> 00:05:38.916
We've got to get more organized because
we've got so many suppliers now,

100
00:05:38.916 --> 00:05:41.913
that they're starting
to impact each other.

101
00:05:41.913 --> 00:05:47.073
So it's really critical in this
SIAM eco-structure that change

102
00:05:47.073 --> 00:05:52.435
is managed efficiently and
effectively, and that it's managed.

103
00:05:52.435 --> 00:05:55.643
Because if one service
provider makes a change here,

104
00:05:55.643 --> 00:05:58.863
it will potentially affect
absolutely everything.

105
00:05:58.863 --> 00:06:03.820
But how come these particular service
provider here see what the impact will

106
00:06:03.820 --> 00:06:08.706
be if none of the other service providers
at these levels will talk to them?

107
00:06:11.816 --> 00:06:12.953
Doesn't happen, does it?

108
00:06:12.953 --> 00:06:15.038
So then just make the change, and

109
00:06:15.038 --> 00:06:20.105
that's when we realize that the impact
is there, the negative impact is there.

110
00:06:20.105 --> 00:06:22.869
So this is why we need SIAM.

111
00:06:22.869 --> 00:06:27.397
So this is why, this is our justification,
quite often, for that SIAM

112
00:06:27.397 --> 00:06:32.696
ecostructure that says look, we've got
to control all of our service providers.

113
00:06:32.696 --> 00:06:36.017
And we've got to do this
is a consistent manner.

114
00:06:36.017 --> 00:06:38.212
This is quite often the driver.

115
00:06:38.212 --> 00:06:45.178
Change management is about ensuring that
change is made into the right environment.

116
00:06:45.178 --> 00:06:49.973
And that's our customer environment
in a controlled manner.

117
00:06:49.973 --> 00:06:56.172
So the change is assessed, it's evaluated.

118
00:06:56.172 --> 00:07:01.025
It's prioritized according to
the needs of the organization.

119
00:07:01.025 --> 00:07:06.381
And then we are able to test and

120
00:07:06.381 --> 00:07:12.171
deploy in a controlled manner.

121
00:07:12.171 --> 00:07:16.947
I said right at the very beginning that
release and change probably won't gonna

122
00:07:16.947 --> 00:07:21.238
get about 50%, 50-50 of the time
in this particular episode.

123
00:07:21.238 --> 00:07:27.299
Because they're not release management
comes into play when we have medium and

124
00:07:27.299 --> 00:07:29.027
large scale changes.

125
00:07:29.027 --> 00:07:34.712
Release management doesn't come into play
for small changes, small implementations.

126
00:07:34.712 --> 00:07:38.793
So for small implementations, like can
I have a new laptop please, we wouldn't

127
00:07:38.793 --> 00:07:42.586
necessarily bring in release management
for one person with a new laptop.

128
00:07:42.586 --> 00:07:47.434
But if we had to deploy an entire suite of
laptops across the customer organization,

129
00:07:47.434 --> 00:07:51.138
then most definitely release
management would come into play.

130
00:07:51.138 --> 00:07:54.123
So change management is
about managing change.

131
00:07:54.123 --> 00:08:00.375
The importance here is to remember that
change management authorizes the change.

132
00:08:00.375 --> 00:08:05.640
And once the change has been authorized,
it's at that point in time when either

133
00:08:05.640 --> 00:08:10.670
change management carry on and then do
the bill test and implement, or it's

134
00:08:10.670 --> 00:08:16.470
handed over to release management, and
they then do the bill test and implement.

135
00:08:16.470 --> 00:08:18.520
And it's all really down to the scale.

136
00:08:19.680 --> 00:08:22.490
The scale will tell you whether
we use release management, or

137
00:08:22.490 --> 00:08:24.480
whether we don't use release management.

138
00:08:24.480 --> 00:08:27.330
Ultimately we've got to manage
every single release, but

139
00:08:27.330 --> 00:08:29.370
whether we need form of process for
that or

140
00:08:29.370 --> 00:08:34.052
not, well, that's the scale it's
going to help you to determine that.

00:07:44.470 --> 00:07:48.710
So if we've got certain jobs,
let's say that we've got a print job and

141
00:07:48.710 --> 00:07:53.210
we were your utility company, and we are
printing out invoices every single month.

142
00:07:53.210 --> 00:07:55.910
We're printing out bills to
be sent off to the customer.

143
00:07:55.910 --> 00:08:00.160
But the printing of those
bills is entirely dependent on

144
00:08:00.160 --> 00:08:03.940
the processing of the job to
actually calculate the bills.

145
00:08:03.940 --> 00:08:06.750
But if the printing of the bills
is done by one service provider,

146
00:08:06.750 --> 00:08:08.840
cuz sometimes that's outsourced.

147
00:08:08.840 --> 00:08:13.610
And the calculating of the jobs is
done by another service provider,

148
00:08:13.610 --> 00:08:16.050
then we have a dependency here.

149
00:08:16.050 --> 00:08:19.920
And these guys who are printing out
the bills will fail their service level

150
00:08:19.920 --> 00:08:23.770
targets, will fail in their contracts,
if they don't print out the bills.

151
00:08:23.770 --> 00:08:28.326
But if the bills aren't available for them
to be printed out because these guys here

152
00:08:28.326 --> 00:08:31.780
have had some problem with
event management here.

153
00:08:31.780 --> 00:08:36.369
[SOUND] We've got a knock on effect And
then if the bills get sent out and

154
00:08:36.369 --> 00:08:38.967
the customers are expected
to pay them within, well,

155
00:08:38.967 --> 00:08:43.185
two hours of receiving the bill, because
they didn't get the bills quick enough.

156
00:08:43.185 --> 00:08:45.785
You can see how this can compound itself.

157
00:08:45.785 --> 00:08:48.505
So event management, whilst we say well,

158
00:08:48.505 --> 00:08:53.575
it can be fully automated, when we're
talking across service providers,

159
00:08:53.575 --> 00:08:55.975
then of course we have that
added complexity as well.

160
00:08:57.170 --> 00:09:00.670
So even management might
seem quite simple but

161
00:09:00.670 --> 00:09:05.850
on the surface, the principle and
the concept is incredibly simple.

162
00:09:05.850 --> 00:09:08.950
However, when we're talking about
individual service providers then

163
00:09:08.950 --> 00:09:13.400
obviously that can, across these service
providers, that can be a challenge.

164
00:09:13.400 --> 00:09:16.580
>> And it seems like we have
to make considerations for

165
00:09:16.580 --> 00:09:18.960
whole versus individual pieces.

166
00:09:18.960 --> 00:09:20.950
I mean,
we've talked about these dependencies.

167
00:09:20.950 --> 00:09:22.130
But if I go back to the temperature,

168
00:09:22.130 --> 00:09:24.010
I was thinking more about that
temperature example, right.

169
00:09:24.010 --> 00:09:26.970
Our individual studios,
let's say those are at 20.

170
00:09:26.970 --> 00:09:30.036
But, excuse me, let's say those are at 15.

171
00:09:30.036 --> 00:09:33.313
Number one, that would be,
that will be fairly cool looking.

172
00:09:33.313 --> 00:09:34.384
>> [LAUGH] Maybe a little bit, yeah.

173
00:09:34.384 --> 00:09:37.507
>> But let's say that the building needs
to maintain an average temperature of

174
00:09:37.507 --> 00:09:38.960
20 degrees.

175
00:09:38.960 --> 00:09:42.876
If the compensation for the remainder
of the rooms in the building,

176
00:09:42.876 --> 00:09:47.687
other than our studios, was to increase
that temperature, then that can possibly

177
00:09:47.687 --> 00:09:52.313
have an unforeseen effect in the people
that reside in those respective rooms.

178
00:09:52.313 --> 00:09:56.141
Is that something we need to consider when
we have kind of this tiered structure

179
00:09:56.141 --> 00:10:00.550
of let's monitor this, that's monitoring
these sub-monitoring stations then making

180
00:10:00.550 --> 00:10:02.110
decisions based on that?

181
00:10:02.110 --> 00:10:02.700
>> Yeah, and

182
00:10:02.700 --> 00:10:08.300
it also depends on how we're actually
controlling that overall temperature.

183
00:10:08.300 --> 00:10:11.620
Because, if we're controlling
the temperature in each room and

184
00:10:11.620 --> 00:10:16.990
we're looking for say,
the median point across every single

185
00:10:16.990 --> 00:10:21.850
room, the median of which so we've
got five thermostats at each room and

186
00:10:21.850 --> 00:10:24.040
then we're just gonna add it all out and
divide it by five,

187
00:10:24.040 --> 00:10:25.450
then that's one way of looking at it.

188
00:10:25.450 --> 00:10:30.440
But then that can cause a problem because
if one of us has got it up to sort of

189
00:10:30.440 --> 00:10:35.610
13 degrees then everybody else is gonna
have to be lower to accommodate for that.

190
00:10:35.610 --> 00:10:39.320
Or maybe what we want to do is
find that sort of sweet spot and

191
00:10:39.320 --> 00:10:41.930
put some thresholds in the individual

192
00:10:41.930 --> 00:10:46.720
thermostats themselves to ensure that
we remain at a consistent temperature.

193
00:10:46.720 --> 00:10:48.270
There's lots of ways of doing that.

194
00:10:49.710 --> 00:10:52.590
You were thinking something about
that word there, I see that.

195
00:10:52.590 --> 00:10:56.320
>> Yeah, so,
I can see limiting thresholds, but

196
00:10:56.320 --> 00:11:00.550
I can also see choosing how
you're going to measure.

197
00:11:00.550 --> 00:11:04.390
What I mean is, you said add them all
up and divide by five, if we had five.

198
00:11:04.390 --> 00:11:08.370
Cool, that is a measure of
kinda where everything is.

199
00:11:08.370 --> 00:11:10.820
But don't know the spread though.

200
00:11:10.820 --> 00:11:12.638
>> Right.
>> Right, we got, wait a minute.

201
00:11:12.638 --> 00:11:17.164
What if ones' at 30, one's at 10,
and then the other three are at 20.

202
00:11:17.164 --> 00:11:20.555
Will that actually gives you-
>> You're 20 degrees.

203
00:11:20.555 --> 00:11:23.040
>> You're 20 degrees and nothing changes.

204
00:11:23.040 --> 00:11:27.021
A 30 degrees C,
pretty toasty inside of a room.

205
00:11:27.021 --> 00:11:29.188
>> [LAUGH]
>> And then 10 degrees C,

206
00:11:29.188 --> 00:11:32.120
it's getting on the cool side,
not gonna lie to you.

207
00:11:32.120 --> 00:11:36.040
>> I think it's been on legal minimum or
something.

208
00:11:36.040 --> 00:11:39.660
>> It's probably your freezer, [LAUGH]
it's getting close to there, right.

209
00:11:39.660 --> 00:11:40.569
Some kind of refrigerant.

210
00:11:42.160 --> 00:11:45.460
It may be better to pick
a different metric at that point

211
00:11:45.460 --> 00:11:47.065
that will give you more insight, right?

212
00:11:47.065 --> 00:11:51.400
Instead of the mean, maybe you
actually do take the mode, right.

213
00:11:51.400 --> 00:11:53.840
Where you say,
what is the most common one?

214
00:11:53.840 --> 00:11:56.570
In this case, the example I just gave,
actually still fails.

215
00:11:56.570 --> 00:11:57.140
>> Yeah.

216
00:11:57.140 --> 00:11:59.150
>> Because the mode is still 20.

217
00:11:59.150 --> 00:12:02.558
But, there's some considerations
of how you measure and

218
00:12:02.558 --> 00:12:08.610
then do you impose thresholds in order to
alleviate issues with that measurement?

219
00:12:08.610 --> 00:12:11.650
If we come back and say mean,
median or mode, whatever.

220
00:12:12.900 --> 00:12:17.150
But, you can't go above 25 and
you can't go below 15,

221
00:12:17.150 --> 00:12:20.520
then we can still pick one
of those metrics, right.

222
00:12:20.520 --> 00:12:23.930
But we can also impose thresholds
that make it easier for

223
00:12:23.930 --> 00:12:26.120
us to reason about what's going on.

224
00:12:26.120 --> 00:12:27.450
>> Yes, yes.

225
00:12:27.450 --> 00:12:31.468
There's no, and
I know I say this quite a lot, but

226
00:12:31.468 --> 00:12:34.837
when it comes to this type of management.

227
00:12:34.837 --> 00:12:38.349
There's no right or wrong because it
really depends on what it is you're

228
00:12:38.349 --> 00:12:42.570
managing and in this instance, there is no
right or wrong in that particular example.

229
00:12:42.570 --> 00:12:45.920
Because some people might like the studios
to be a little bit on the toasty side,

230
00:12:45.920 --> 00:12:49.770
and some people might like the studios
to be a little bit on the cool side.

231
00:12:49.770 --> 00:12:53.580
Personally I like it to be a little bit on
the cool side because I don't want Justin

232
00:12:53.580 --> 00:12:56.350
falling asleep and starting to snore
in the middle of it all, you know.

233
00:12:57.370 --> 00:12:58.530
It's just simple as that.

234
00:12:58.530 --> 00:13:02.750
But nevertheless, it also depends on and
I have to say this when we talk about

235
00:13:02.750 --> 00:13:05.650
temperature, I mean, it could depend
on the number of people in the room.

236
00:13:05.650 --> 00:13:08.510
The more people that you've got in the
room the warmer the room's going to be.

237
00:13:09.620 --> 00:13:12.810
And therefore even though
the thermostat itself might measure

238
00:13:12.810 --> 00:13:16.780
that it's on 20 degrees nevertheless
it might not actually be 20 degrees,

239
00:13:16.780 --> 00:13:18.990
it might feel more like 35 in here.

240
00:13:18.990 --> 00:13:21.610
Because you've got 15 people in here.

241
00:13:21.610 --> 00:13:24.740
So it depends on a number of factors,
and that was just an example,

242
00:13:24.740 --> 00:13:28.380
but this is what event
management is doing.

243
00:13:28.380 --> 00:13:31.040
Event management is
monitoring those events and

244
00:13:31.040 --> 00:13:33.770
then deciding what to do about it.

245
00:13:35.930 --> 00:13:39.350
And of course, then we have to spread that
complexity and manage that complexity

246
00:13:39.350 --> 00:13:42.240
across all of the relationships
with all of our service providers.

247
00:13:43.680 --> 00:13:47.770
That brings us into our second process for
this particular episode,

248
00:13:47.770 --> 00:13:50.410
and that process is financial management.

249
00:13:50.410 --> 00:13:53.860
Now, financial management,
I like to use the word stewardship.

250
00:13:54.920 --> 00:13:59.550
It's about the efficient and
effective stewardship of our money.

251
00:14:00.560 --> 00:14:04.900
No, it's not about you having more
money to spend, Justin, definitely not.

252
00:14:04.900 --> 00:14:06.570
>> But that sounded so amazing,

253
00:14:06.570 --> 00:14:10.160
I was all aboard until you told
me that's not what it was.

254
00:14:10.160 --> 00:14:11.780
>> No, sorry, no.

255
00:14:11.780 --> 00:14:14.950
This is about how much money have
we got to spend, that's budgeting.

256
00:14:14.950 --> 00:14:19.940
How much have we as a service
integrator got to spend.

257
00:14:19.940 --> 00:14:24.890
And how much money do we have to
spend with our service providers.

258
00:14:24.890 --> 00:14:29.020
Of course, all of that comes in to our
contracts, but we still have to budget for

259
00:14:29.020 --> 00:14:31.680
our contracts of our service providers.

260
00:14:31.680 --> 00:14:34.170
And then we have to perform accounting.

261
00:14:34.170 --> 00:14:37.900
How much money have we spent and
where have we spent it?

262
00:14:37.900 --> 00:14:42.270
And then of course this charging as well,
and of course there's always going to be

263
00:14:42.270 --> 00:14:46.060
charging goes on in this
particular ecosystem.

264
00:14:46.060 --> 00:14:52.530
Because each service provider could
be charging another service provider.

265
00:14:52.530 --> 00:14:58.320
It really depends on how
the contracts are actually set up.

266
00:14:58.320 --> 00:15:02.680
If everybody's contract is
with the service integrator,

267
00:15:02.680 --> 00:15:05.450
which is what would make the most sense.

268
00:15:05.450 --> 00:15:10.330
Then obviously, each service provider
is charging the service integrator and

269
00:15:10.330 --> 00:15:13.500
the service integrator is
then charging the customer.

270
00:15:14.630 --> 00:15:16.380
That's what would make most sense.

271
00:15:17.510 --> 00:15:22.755
But the customer, believe it or
not, owns all the contracts.

272
00:15:23.965 --> 00:15:26.785
>> That tends to put
a little bit of wrinkle in,

273
00:15:26.785 --> 00:15:28.735
in kind of how this is all managed, right?

274
00:15:28.735 --> 00:15:29.755
You have an ownership but

275
00:15:29.755 --> 00:15:33.345
then you have these interdependent
relationships that may be charging.

276
00:15:33.345 --> 00:15:38.276
[SOUND] Just when I thought
things were gonna get simple, Jo.

277
00:15:38.276 --> 00:15:40.620
>> Well, it's not a difficult concept.

278
00:15:40.620 --> 00:15:45.091
Who are we actually
providing a service to?

279
00:15:45.091 --> 00:15:46.980
>> I would say the customer.

280
00:15:46.980 --> 00:15:48.840
>> Right, the organization.

281
00:15:48.840 --> 00:15:55.300
And so the organization has a contract
with the service integrator.

282
00:15:55.300 --> 00:15:58.730
So everything else is a sub-contract.

283
00:15:58.730 --> 00:16:03.420
All the contracts between the service
integrator and each service provider, but

284
00:16:03.420 --> 00:16:05.320
that's a sub-contract.

285
00:16:05.320 --> 00:16:09.130
And so of course the customer has
to have oversight of all of this,

286
00:16:09.130 --> 00:16:11.760
even though the customer doesn't
necessarily want to be bothered with

287
00:16:11.760 --> 00:16:12.950
the management of all of that.

288
00:16:12.950 --> 00:16:15.830
That's why they're paying
the service integrator.

289
00:16:15.830 --> 00:16:18.360
Nevertheless, they need to have
oversight over all of this,

290
00:16:18.360 --> 00:16:19.950
because ultimately
they're paying the bill.

291
00:16:21.320 --> 00:16:25.650
So, that makes sense, really,
when you think about it.

292
00:16:25.650 --> 00:16:29.543
Financial management not only has
to manage all of the accounting and

293
00:16:29.543 --> 00:16:30.490
the budgeting.

294
00:16:30.490 --> 00:16:35.665
Financial management also has to
manage data and confidentiality and

295
00:16:35.665 --> 00:16:40.540
security of financial data,
right across the ecosystem.

296
00:16:40.540 --> 00:16:43.510
So if we take a look at the purpose
of financial management,

297
00:16:43.510 --> 00:16:46.950
you say that there are activities
to do with collating and

298
00:16:46.950 --> 00:16:51.450
investigating and analyzing and
presenting information to the customer.

299
00:16:51.450 --> 00:16:56.980
When we talk about an end-to-end financial
function and what we mean by end-to-end

300
00:16:56.980 --> 00:17:02.940
is we made collation of the information
from all of our services providers.

301
00:17:02.940 --> 00:17:06.150
And of course,
that's the key with the ecosystem,

302
00:17:06.150 --> 00:17:10.320
is that when SIAM,
we've got many service providers.

303
00:17:10.320 --> 00:17:15.040
In a traditional approach, and
a traditional approach to IT,

304
00:17:15.040 --> 00:17:20.870
we've got one service provider, and
then we may have multiple sub-vendors,

305
00:17:20.870 --> 00:17:23.860
but we got one service
provider that's part of IT.

306
00:17:23.860 --> 00:17:25.530
We don't have this.

307
00:17:25.530 --> 00:17:29.480
So, we're managing across
multiple contracts.

308
00:17:29.480 --> 00:17:31.450
And because we've got multiple contracts,

309
00:17:31.450 --> 00:17:36.250
that means the financial management is
gonna have to manage relationships and

310
00:17:36.250 --> 00:17:39.790
also penalties and
incentives across those contracts as well.

311
00:17:39.790 --> 00:17:40.400
>> So generally,

312
00:17:40.400 --> 00:17:43.890
that thus seem like a very important
process that we need to consider.

313
00:17:43.890 --> 00:17:46.520
However, where does this
process actually leave us?

314
00:17:46.520 --> 00:17:49.670
Is in the service integrator layer or
will this be at the customer layer.

315
00:17:49.670 --> 00:17:51.670
>> Well,
it's a bit of both because as I've said,

316
00:17:51.670 --> 00:17:54.770
the contracts themselves
are owned by the customer.

317
00:17:54.770 --> 00:18:00.410
So the customer's going to do
a modicum of financial management,

318
00:18:00.410 --> 00:18:03.720
and a modicum of the management
of all of the finance processes.

319
00:18:03.720 --> 00:18:06.680
They own the budget, they own the money.

320
00:18:06.680 --> 00:18:11.108
However, the management of
the actual contracts themselves, and

321
00:18:11.108 --> 00:18:16.546
actually accounting for the money that we
spent and ensuring that all of our working

322
00:18:16.546 --> 00:18:21.458
practices, well, they are all followed
by all of our service providers.

323
00:18:21.458 --> 00:18:23.951
That's going to lie with
the service integrator layer.

324
00:18:23.951 --> 00:18:26.692
That's definitely their
responsibility to do.

325
00:18:26.692 --> 00:18:29.520
>> Though I can definitely
see how that makes sense for

326
00:18:29.520 --> 00:18:34.130
that leaving both of those layers
depending on respective considerations.

327
00:18:34.130 --> 00:18:38.440
Now, we've talked about event management,
we've talked about financial management,

328
00:18:38.440 --> 00:18:42.010
and I'm kind of interested
on where do we go from here?

329
00:18:42.010 --> 00:18:46.080
>> Right, well in our next episode we're
gonna be taking a look at security

330
00:18:46.080 --> 00:18:50.900
management and we're also gonna take a
look at some knowledge management as well.

331
00:18:50.900 --> 00:18:55.765
>> Well Jo, I'm very interested to see
what knowledge management actually is.

332
00:18:55.765 --> 00:18:58.890
It's one of those terms with,
maybe I know what it is,

333
00:18:58.890 --> 00:19:01.145
but I've never just actually
called it knowledge management.

334
00:19:01.145 --> 00:19:02.700
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm starting to see

335
00:19:02.700 --> 00:19:03.630
another pattern here.

336
00:19:03.630 --> 00:19:06.404
A lot of these are kind of interdependent,
and security management,

337
00:19:06.404 --> 00:19:09.940
financial management, there's probably
security in financial management, right?

338
00:19:09.940 --> 00:19:10.520
>> Yep.

339
00:19:10.520 --> 00:19:13.900
>> Making sure you have
financial data secure, but

340
00:19:13.900 --> 00:19:16.630
you have to make considerations for
those respective domains.

341
00:19:16.630 --> 00:19:19.780
So, definitely join us back as we
continue looking at SIAM processes.

342
00:19:19.780 --> 00:19:21.470
But, for now we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

343
00:19:21.470 --> 00:19:24.370
So, signing off for ITPro.TV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

344
00:19:24.370 --> 00:19:25.290
>> And, I'm Jo Peacock.

345
00:19:25.290 --> 00:19:27.489
>> And, we'll see you next time.

347
00:19:33.621 --> 00:19:36.840
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

What service we're providing but

fantastical here, but if the agreement for

424
00:23:01.880 --> 00:23:07.150
restoration of service was I should be
able to walk and run, in this case,

425
00:23:07.150 --> 00:23:12.700
if you've got crutches, then I would not
have a restoration of services, per se.

426
00:23:13.800 --> 00:23:16.750
And that's where getting too specific
could cause problems, right?

427
00:23:18.250 --> 00:23:21.090
>> Well, I wouldn't say that
getting specific causes problems,

428
00:23:21.090 --> 00:23:25.640
because it really depends on
we're kinda getting silly here.

429
00:23:25.640 --> 00:23:30.590
But yes, if your estimation of
service is the ability to run,

430
00:23:30.590 --> 00:23:34.080
then giving you crutches, unless
they were some sort of super, duper,

431
00:23:34.080 --> 00:23:38.740
bionic man type crutches, then giving you
crutches is not going to help you run, no.

432
00:23:40.470 --> 00:23:43.700
So in that case,
then service wouldn't be restored.

433
00:23:43.700 --> 00:23:45.850
But it depends on what's
defined as service.

434
00:23:46.920 --> 00:23:50.824
If service is defined then as just your
walking across that road, then yes,

435
00:23:50.824 --> 00:23:52.787
crutches will restore your service.

436
00:23:54.830 --> 00:23:56.690
Yeah, does that make sense?

437
00:23:56.690 --> 00:23:57.510
>> That makes sense.

438
00:23:57.510 --> 00:24:00.470
I think that's actually
brought some clarity to me

439
00:24:00.470 --> 00:24:02.870
about how these all intertwine.

440
00:24:02.870 --> 00:24:07.540
Because originally I was like service is,
seems like kind of an abstract thing.

441
00:24:07.540 --> 00:24:11.650
But for an incident,
my main goal is to restore service

442
00:24:11.650 --> 00:24:15.850
through the use of workarounds, whatever
it may be, to get you back up running.

443
00:24:15.850 --> 00:24:20.550
>> Right, and the complexity that
we have here, in this ecosystem,

444
00:24:20.550 --> 00:24:25.690
is the fact that we are trying to
restore service across, or using,

445
00:24:25.690 --> 00:24:30.530
the resources of potentially a number
of different service providers.

446
00:24:31.550 --> 00:24:36.120
And so, whilst the process of
incident management remains the same,

447
00:24:36.120 --> 00:24:38.850
we also have to consider the complexity.

448
00:24:39.880 --> 00:24:44.275
But then of course problem
management could help us with that.

449
00:24:44.275 --> 00:24:47.795
And we're gonna talk about
that in our next episode.

450
00:24:47.795 --> 00:24:49.675
>> Well, you're leaving us hanging Jo.

451
00:24:49.675 --> 00:24:53.165
But these are intertwined, so
you should definitely come on back.

452
00:24:53.165 --> 00:24:54.765
Not necessarily a part two.

453
00:24:54.765 --> 00:25:00.672
I think of it as a corresponding
episode that looks at the other side.

454
00:25:00.672 --> 00:25:02.232
So hope to see you there.

455
00:25:02.232 --> 00:25:04.042
But for now, we're going to go ahead and
get out of here.

456
00:25:04.042 --> 00:25:07.062
So signing out for ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

457
00:25:07.062 --> 00:25:08.352
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

458
00:25:08.352 --> 00:25:10.674
>> And I'll see you next time.

459
00:25:10.674 --> 00:25:16.525
[MUSIC]

460
00:25:16.525 --> 00:25:19.798
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: An explanation of the purpose and objectives of the SIAM Problem Management process and how it relates to Incident Management.
episodes.title: SIAM Processes - Problem Mgmt.
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.003 --> 00:00:01.210
>> Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.210 --> 00:00:05.889
I'm your host Don Pezet coming
at you live from San Francisco,

3
00:00:05.889 --> 00:00:10.710
California.
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:10.710 --> 00:00:12.010
>> Greetings everyone and

5
00:00:12.010 --> 00:00:16.690
welcome back to another exciting episode
of ITProTV, I'm your host Justin Dennison

6
00:00:16.690 --> 00:00:21.181
and we're coming back at you with kind of
a continuation of intimate management.

7
00:00:21.181 --> 00:00:25.250
But in particular, we're gonna be talking
about problem management in this episode.

8
00:00:25.250 --> 00:00:26.012
They're intertwined.

9
00:00:26.012 --> 00:00:26.750
But luckily,

10
00:00:26.750 --> 00:00:30.817
we have someone in the studio that's
gonna help piece those two pieces apart.

11
00:00:30.817 --> 00:00:32.750
The one, the only, Ms. Jo Peacock.

12
00:00:32.750 --> 00:00:34.810
How you doing today, Jo?
>> Absolutely great.

13
00:00:34.810 --> 00:00:36.300
Thank you, Justin.
How are you?

14
00:00:36.300 --> 00:00:38.090
>> I am doing fantastic and

15
00:00:38.090 --> 00:00:40.950
I think I'm starting to get a little
bit of a hold on the difference between

16
00:00:40.950 --> 00:00:43.030
an incident, and a problem.

17
00:00:43.030 --> 00:00:46.899
And incident management is making sense,
but I'm kinda seeing if you're gonna throw

18
00:00:46.899 --> 00:00:49.765
me a curve ball when we start
talking about problem management.

19
00:00:49.765 --> 00:00:51.491
>> Well, not so much a curve ball, but

20
00:00:51.491 --> 00:00:54.210
we're gonna expand certainly
on problem management.

21
00:00:54.210 --> 00:00:56.881
So, so far,
we've looked in our previous episode.

22
00:00:56.881 --> 00:00:59.150
We've looked at incident management.

23
00:00:59.150 --> 00:01:04.017
An incident is an interruption to or
reduction in the quality of a service.

24
00:01:04.017 --> 00:01:09.101
So it's an event that has caused
a reduction in the quality

25
00:01:09.101 --> 00:01:15.221
of the service that's maybe a failure and
it is an event that has well,

26
00:01:15.221 --> 00:01:20.390
cause disruption to
the services defining the SLA.

27
00:01:20.390 --> 00:01:22.071
So the importance here,

28
00:01:22.071 --> 00:01:26.399
what's of paramount importance
is what's defined in the SLA.

29
00:01:26.399 --> 00:01:31.474
That's how we do know whether
services being interrupted or

30
00:01:31.474 --> 00:01:35.055
not, but a problem is what's caused it and

31
00:01:35.055 --> 00:01:39.843
a problem can occur whether
there's an incident or not.

32
00:01:39.843 --> 00:01:42.749
A problem is what causes an incident, but

33
00:01:42.749 --> 00:01:46.870
a problem doesn't necessarily
cause an incident.

34
00:01:46.870 --> 00:01:50.230
Let's go back to that example that
we used in a previous episode and

35
00:01:50.230 --> 00:01:51.920
we were talking about potholes.

36
00:01:51.920 --> 00:01:56.200
We were talking about
getting the paramedics out.

37
00:01:56.200 --> 00:02:01.040
But essentially, the pothole was a problem
and the broken leg was the incident.

38
00:02:02.560 --> 00:02:04.460
We're okay with that, but

39
00:02:04.460 --> 00:02:07.820
that problem is going to occur whether
anybody breaks their legs or not.

40
00:02:08.820 --> 00:02:10.640
So the problem is still there.

41
00:02:10.640 --> 00:02:15.174
The problem is the underlying cause
of one or more incidents, but

42
00:02:15.174 --> 00:02:18.730
a problem can still be there and
can still be fixed.

43
00:02:18.730 --> 00:02:23.486
It can still be rectified without actually

44
00:02:23.486 --> 00:02:27.474
causing an incident.
>> Hold on a second and

45
00:02:27.474 --> 00:02:32.448
to some extent, this makes sense,
so where we could either find

46
00:02:32.448 --> 00:02:37.790
a problem after an incident has
occurred in order to remedy that.

47
00:02:37.790 --> 00:02:41.157
But a problem regardless of
whether an incident occurred or

48
00:02:41.157 --> 00:02:45.680
not is something that is underlying that
has the capacity to cause incidences.

49
00:02:45.680 --> 00:02:51.008
Incidences that we want to fix.
>> You are not

50
00:02:51.008 --> 00:02:53.828
the first person I've heard call it that.
>> [LAUGH]

51
00:02:53.828 --> 00:02:55.061
>> It's an incident.

52
00:02:55.061 --> 00:02:58.370
It feels weird kind of off the tongue,
but like the pothole.

53
00:02:58.370 --> 00:03:02.691
Even if no one broke their leg, it still
has the capacity to cause a leg break.

54
00:03:02.691 --> 00:03:07.669
So we want to be proactive in
addressing that instead of reactive.

55
00:03:07.669 --> 00:03:09.070
>> I love the word.

56
00:03:09.070 --> 00:03:11.224
No, we're not just talking
about instead of reactive.

57
00:03:11.224 --> 00:03:14.550
Take a quick look at the purpose
of problem management.

58
00:03:15.970 --> 00:03:17.489
You will see that it's split into two.

59
00:03:17.489 --> 00:03:24.430
It's split into both reactive and
proactive, that second bullet point.

60
00:03:24.430 --> 00:03:29.664
It's responsible for preventing
incidents from occurring or recurring.

61
00:03:29.664 --> 00:03:31.937
So problem management,

62
00:03:31.937 --> 00:03:37.575
one of their jobs is to identify
potential causes of failure.

63
00:03:37.575 --> 00:03:40.881
You've heard of a SPOF?
>> A what?

64
00:03:40.881 --> 00:03:42.680
>> A SPOF.

65
00:03:42.680 --> 00:03:43.959
>> How do you spell that?

66
00:03:43.959 --> 00:03:48.640
>> S-P-O-F, single point of failure.

67
00:03:48.640 --> 00:03:51.256
We love acronyms.
>> For some reason,

68
00:03:51.256 --> 00:03:53.304
all I could think of was a loofa sponge.

69
00:03:53.304 --> 00:03:55.250
But that's not a single point of failure.

70
00:03:55.250 --> 00:03:57.493
I gotcha, that's a four letter acronym.

71
00:03:57.493 --> 00:04:01.005
I'm only good at three letter acronyms.
>> [LAUGH]

72
00:04:01.005 --> 00:04:02.574
>> So a single point of failure

73
00:04:02.574 --> 00:04:03.467
then, a SPOF.

74
00:04:03.467 --> 00:04:06.910
What problem management split into two.

75
00:04:06.910 --> 00:04:11.685
Problem management's job is to,
well, fix problems.

76
00:04:11.685 --> 00:04:16.640
But problem management's job is also to
prevent incidents from happening as well.

77
00:04:16.640 --> 00:04:17.768
So problem management is split into tow.

78
00:04:17.768 --> 00:04:20.800
It's the reactive and the proactive.

79
00:04:20.800 --> 00:04:23.932
So I like to look at
the reactive as the why.

80
00:04:23.932 --> 00:04:26.076
If you call up the service desk and

81
00:04:26.076 --> 00:04:29.760
remember that example that we
had from our last episode?

82
00:04:29.760 --> 00:04:33.120
And in that example,
you called up the service desk and

83
00:04:33.120 --> 00:04:37.868
because your report wasn't coming out
of that printer that was over there and

84
00:04:37.868 --> 00:04:40.660
we defined your service
as just that report.

85
00:04:40.660 --> 00:04:45.484
And at that point in time, then I just
diverted you to another printer somewhere

86
00:04:45.484 --> 00:04:49.560
else and you've got your report and
service was restored.

87
00:04:49.560 --> 00:04:50.426
But we still had a problem.
Now,

88
00:04:50.426 --> 00:04:53.160
there are two things that could happen.

89
00:04:54.450 --> 00:04:59.870
One is that you could say to me,
why is this happening?

90
00:05:00.970 --> 00:05:07.221
And if you said to me why didn't I get
my report, then what I should do at that

91
00:05:07.221 --> 00:05:13.590
point in time is raise a problem record
to find the root cause to find out why.

92
00:05:13.590 --> 00:05:14.479
But you might not.

93
00:05:14.479 --> 00:05:18.913
You might have been happy with the fact
that you've gotta drive a little way and

94
00:05:18.913 --> 00:05:21.328
you can go and
get your report that way, but

95
00:05:21.328 --> 00:05:22.766
don't shake your head.

96
00:05:22.766 --> 00:05:23.551
>> [LAUGH]
>> I said

97
00:05:23.551 --> 00:05:24.360
might.
>> [LAUGH]

98
00:05:24.360 --> 00:05:26.632
>> So what might happen is that somebody

99
00:05:26.632 --> 00:05:29.416
else might come in and
they might come in, and

100
00:05:29.416 --> 00:05:34.050
he might want a report of that printer,
and he doesn't get his report.

101
00:05:34.050 --> 00:05:35.030
So he calls up the service desk.

102
00:05:35.030 --> 00:05:38.620
And again, they divert him and
then Cherokee might come in and

103
00:05:38.620 --> 00:05:42.780
she might try and print something to
that printer and it doesn't work.

104
00:05:42.780 --> 00:05:46.893
But it gets diverted somewhere else,
so her incident's closed as well.

105
00:05:46.893 --> 00:05:50.874
And then what happens then in
that instance is that proactive

106
00:05:50.874 --> 00:05:52.904
problem management kicks in,

107
00:05:52.904 --> 00:05:58.459
because proactive problem management is
performing trend analysis of incidence.

108
00:05:58.459 --> 00:06:03.218
And proactive problem management will
look at all of these incidents and

109
00:06:03.218 --> 00:06:07.060
go, there's something
suspicious going on here.

110
00:06:07.060 --> 00:06:11.150
I need to investigate why.

111
00:06:11.150 --> 00:06:15.640
So the question why can either
be proactive or reactive.

112
00:06:15.640 --> 00:06:20.535
You could ask me why, then I'd
raise a problem and investigate or

113
00:06:20.535 --> 00:06:23.390
I could be doing some trend analysis.

114
00:06:23.390 --> 00:06:28.023
I could be doing some monitoring of
my own which I should be as proactive

115
00:06:28.023 --> 00:06:31.792
project management and
then I should be identifying that

116
00:06:31.792 --> 00:06:35.810
there's been a number of incidents,
and identifying why.

117
00:06:37.260 --> 00:06:42.710
So problem management is really about
not just identifying the root cause,

118
00:06:42.710 --> 00:06:46.400
but it's also about preventing
incidents from happening too.

119
00:06:47.650 --> 00:06:51.978
Now problem management is something
that well, it's gonna be quite

120
00:06:51.978 --> 00:06:56.393
a challenge when we're doing it
across multiple service providers.

121
00:06:56.393 --> 00:06:59.707
Because of course,
then we have to raise the problem and

122
00:06:59.707 --> 00:07:04.081
potentially pass that problem across
multiple service providers to find

123
00:07:04.081 --> 00:07:07.209
the root cause you're thinking.
>> I am thinking.

124
00:07:07.209 --> 00:07:12.124
So when I think of being proactive
like I don't know for some and

125
00:07:12.124 --> 00:07:18.390
I understand why this wouldn't
necessarily work in all capacities.

126
00:07:18.390 --> 00:07:22.140
Proactive doesn't mean to me, I'm
looking at trends that are occurring and

127
00:07:22.140 --> 00:07:24.100
I'm proactively trying to find a problem.

128
00:07:25.360 --> 00:07:30.559
I would think proactive would be let
me make sure to prevent any incidences.

129
00:07:32.330 --> 00:07:35.050
It's hard to explain,
security, for instance.

130
00:07:35.050 --> 00:07:39.398
I'm going to proactively
like update security

131
00:07:39.398 --> 00:07:44.181
patches to prevent issues
with like data breaches or

132
00:07:44.181 --> 00:07:51.799
whatever as best I can that wasn't due to
an incident that was caused necessarily.

133
00:07:51.799 --> 00:07:55.220
Like I don't wanna go well, there's been
three data breaches in the last week.

134
00:07:55.220 --> 00:07:57.727
I should probably go figure out why.

135
00:07:57.727 --> 00:08:01.045
Is that still considered proactive
even if no incidences have

136
00:08:01.045 --> 00:08:02.075
occurred?
>> Yeah,

137
00:08:02.075 --> 00:08:05.160
it's about identifying
single points of failure.

138
00:08:05.160 --> 00:08:10.289
It's about identifying potential failures
and identifying potential incidents.

139
00:08:10.289 --> 00:08:15.228
And if something we think is going
to cause an incident like we've seen

140
00:08:15.228 --> 00:08:17.250
the pothole out there.

141
00:08:17.250 --> 00:08:18.685
Now nobody has had an incident yet.

142
00:08:18.685 --> 00:08:22.520
Nobody has broken a leg yet, but we could.

143
00:08:22.520 --> 00:08:26.810
So what we would do and prior to problem
management is we would actually put our

144
00:08:26.810 --> 00:08:29.055
hands up and say, hang on a minute.

145
00:08:29.055 --> 00:08:30.430
There is a problem.

146
00:08:31.510 --> 00:08:35.519
I'm going to raise it as a problem and
I'm going to record it,

147
00:08:35.519 --> 00:08:40.311
and then what I'm also going to do is
I am going to implement a workaround.

148
00:08:40.311 --> 00:08:42.837
And in that instance,
I'm gonna get out there and

149
00:08:42.837 --> 00:08:46.087
I'm gonna put some cones out to
make sure that nobody knows it.

150
00:08:46.087 --> 00:08:47.211
Nobody falls down that pothole.

151
00:08:47.211 --> 00:08:52.260
So I'm gonna implement a workaround and
I'm gonna let everybody

152
00:08:52.260 --> 00:08:58.170
know that this is happening whilst
I work on fixing the problem.

153
00:08:58.170 --> 00:09:02.343
So problem management identifies potential
points of failure and also has that

154
00:09:02.343 --> 00:09:06.899
responsibility for doing something about
that potential point of failure, as well.

155
00:09:06.899 --> 00:09:10.723
So it's not just about doing
trend analysis of incidents.

156
00:09:10.723 --> 00:09:11.905
Yes, they do.

157
00:09:11.905 --> 00:09:15.650
But it's also about
identifying potential failures.

158
00:09:15.650 --> 00:09:18.558
Because if it's a potential failure,

159
00:09:18.558 --> 00:09:22.530
something might fail than
the potentiality of that.

160
00:09:22.530 --> 00:09:26.273
Well, there is an incident
waiting to happen, isn't there?

161
00:09:26.273 --> 00:09:28.710
And we wanna prevent
incidents from happening.

162
00:09:30.810 --> 00:09:33.000
>> Sorry, I have an additional question.

163
00:09:34.360 --> 00:09:36.918
So if someone asks why.
>> Yeah.

164
00:09:36.918 --> 00:09:38.449
>> When they call in,

165
00:09:38.449 --> 00:09:41.611
we need to call a, what did you call it?

166
00:09:41.611 --> 00:09:42.947
A problem record.
>> Yes.

167
00:09:42.947 --> 00:09:45.905
>> So let me go find out what calls this

168
00:09:45.905 --> 00:09:47.640
incident.

169
00:09:47.640 --> 00:09:49.232
Cool, I'm good with that one.

170
00:09:49.232 --> 00:09:54.600
Trend analysis based on
previous instances in ends.

171
00:09:54.600 --> 00:09:57.140
Man, that is hard to say incidences.

172
00:09:57.140 --> 00:09:58.750
That makes sense.

173
00:09:58.750 --> 00:10:03.460
Seeing things that could cause problems
and maybe this is an unattachment of that.

174
00:10:03.460 --> 00:10:07.920
Let's talk about data and
making sure we have appropriate backups.

175
00:10:07.920 --> 00:10:11.126
Would this part of problem
management if I go you know what?

176
00:10:11.126 --> 00:10:14.618
The average failure time for
a hard drive is five years and

177
00:10:14.618 --> 00:10:18.570
we have this large raid array that
we do backups, and all these.

178
00:10:18.570 --> 00:10:25.207
I want to keep an inventory and since
it's five years, would I apply that trend

179
00:10:25.207 --> 00:10:30.147
to to keep an incident from occurring?
>> A nd this is where the line gets

180
00:10:30.147 --> 00:10:31.304
a little bit blurry,

181
00:10:31.304 --> 00:10:35.690
because problem management is about
identifying potential points of failure.

182
00:10:35.690 --> 00:10:39.461
And if you've got a that's a little
bit sort of rusty getting on a bit and

183
00:10:39.461 --> 00:10:42.870
you wanna swap out a disc, would that
be considered problem management?

184
00:10:42.870 --> 00:10:45.700
Or would that be considered
availability management?

185
00:10:45.700 --> 00:10:48.380
The lines are a little bit tenuous there.

186
00:10:48.380 --> 00:10:51.216
They're a little bit blurred,
but it doesn't matter.

187
00:10:51.216 --> 00:10:55.152
The fact is that you've identified it and
whether you log it as a problem,

188
00:10:55.152 --> 00:10:57.130
because it could cause an incident.

189
00:10:57.130 --> 00:10:58.147
So technically,

190
00:10:58.147 --> 00:11:03.330
it's a problem or whether you consider
that as part of your availability plan.

191
00:11:03.330 --> 00:11:06.440
It doesn't matter as long
as it's considered and

192
00:11:06.440 --> 00:11:09.370
the short answer to that is
I don't care how you do it.

193
00:11:09.370 --> 00:11:11.844
However, I do care that you do it and

194
00:11:11.844 --> 00:11:16.059
I do care that there's some
consistency in the way you do it.

195
00:11:16.059 --> 00:11:20.796
And this is obviously where the challenge
is, because you've got so many different

196
00:11:20.796 --> 00:11:25.150
service providers that one service
provider might record that as a problem.

197
00:11:26.210 --> 00:11:29.679
Another service provider might include
that in their availability plan.

198
00:11:29.679 --> 00:11:32.170
So there has to be some consistency.

199
00:11:32.170 --> 00:11:34.268
There has to be an agreement.

200
00:11:34.268 --> 00:11:38.890
There has to be that collaboration
in place between all of your service

201
00:11:38.890 --> 00:11:43.432
providers where you will agree on
how you'll go in to approach that to

202
00:11:43.432 --> 00:11:47.898
ensure that you capture all of that
information and that you capture

203
00:11:47.898 --> 00:11:52.000
potential failures before they happen.
>> And that makes sense.

204
00:11:52.000 --> 00:11:55.576
I don't know, Jo, it kinda scares me.
>> We don't wanna be

205
00:11:55.576 --> 00:11:58.288
rigid.
>> I think I'm starting to gain clarity

206
00:11:58.288 --> 00:12:00.500
here.
>> Yeah, we don't wanna be rigid.

207
00:12:00.500 --> 00:12:03.216
We're trying to implement
a framework that works.

208
00:12:03.216 --> 00:12:07.020
We are trying to help you
manage your services.

209
00:12:07.020 --> 00:12:11.056
We're not trying to impose lots of rules
and regulations here that say well,

210
00:12:11.056 --> 00:12:13.240
you must manage your services like this.

211
00:12:13.240 --> 00:12:16.220
We're trying to help you
manage your services.

212
00:12:16.220 --> 00:12:17.386
So this is not about being rigid.

213
00:12:17.386 --> 00:12:21.290
This is just about ensuring
that these things are captured.

214
00:12:24.484 --> 00:12:26.263
>> Followup question and

215
00:12:26.263 --> 00:12:31.504
I've asked this about some other things,
cuz I'm trying to think

216
00:12:31.504 --> 00:12:38.070
about we have this process for
managing problems or a set of processes.

217
00:12:38.070 --> 00:12:39.592
Where did these originate from?

218
00:12:39.592 --> 00:12:44.180
Is this service integrator level or would
this be individual service providers?

219
00:12:44.180 --> 00:12:46.138
Or would this be a combination of the two?

220
00:12:46.138 --> 00:12:50.498
And I guess the service integrator
would make sure that everything is

221
00:12:50.498 --> 00:12:55.170
uniformly applied and everybody does
their due diligence, so to speak.

222
00:12:55.170 --> 00:12:58.237
Or [LAUGH] I feel like you're about to
throw a collection question back at me.

223
00:12:58.237 --> 00:12:59.663
>> No, I'm not, no.

224
00:12:59.663 --> 00:13:03.300
What we've gotta make sure is that
we've got that collaboration.

225
00:13:03.300 --> 00:13:06.360
And so problem management itself,

226
00:13:06.360 --> 00:13:12.277
the activities are going to be
performed by many service providers.

227
00:13:12.277 --> 00:13:15.984
However, the service integrator's
got a role to ensure that

228
00:13:15.984 --> 00:13:20.049
problem management happens and
this is where your challenges are,

229
00:13:20.049 --> 00:13:24.275

are gonna have different tools.

230
00:13:24.275 --> 00:13:27.991
And therefore, potentially you could
have a problem logged in this tool with

231
00:13:27.991 --> 00:13:29.550
this service provider.

232
00:13:29.550 --> 00:13:33.454
And we don't want duplication in this
tour with this service provider,

233
00:13:33.454 --> 00:13:37.686
but we want to make sure that they're
aware of the fact that there is a problem.

234
00:13:37.686 --> 00:13:42.075
So this is where the service
integrator layer really has to manage,

235
00:13:42.075 --> 00:13:48.020
because they have to have that, what was
it that you called that 10,000-foot view.

236
00:13:48.020 --> 00:13:50.229
They have to have a view of everything.

237
00:13:50.229 --> 00:13:53.959
Everything that's going on, which is
why collaboration is so important.

238
00:13:53.959 --> 00:13:57.977
We're depending on collaboration
across the suppliers, but

239
00:13:57.977 --> 00:14:03.512
also we're dependent on the communication
channel between the service providers and

240
00:14:03.512 --> 00:14:10.912
that service integrator layer.
>> [LAUGH]

241

>> I feel like every time in any of these

episodes, there's a steam

243

Because there's a lot to consider.
>> Yep.

244
00:14:19.841 --> 00:14:22.010
>> These are not easy questions to answer

245
00:14:22.010 --> 00:14:26.626
and I think if we lull ourselves into
a false sense of security saying.

246
00:14:26.626 --> 00:14:31.743
Well, obviously, you just do this, then
we're probably not going to deliver or

00:14:31.743 --> 00:14:36.371

>> And it's not just about the tools that

the consistency in our data and

things like, for instance,
our asset numbers.

250

The asset number of one laptop might

One of the disks in the read array
we might know it by it's, well,

253
00:14:55.123 --> 00:14:57.750

254
00:14:57.750 --> 00:15:01.639
But the manufacture, in other words,
your service provider might know it

255
00:15:01.639 --> 00:15:05.787

provided my know it by a different number.

256
00:15:05.787 --> 00:15:08.590
They might know it by
the serial number for instance.

257
00:15:08.590 --> 00:15:10.883
So what do you use?

258
00:15:10.883 --> 00:15:13.620
You've got to have standards in your data.

259
00:15:13.620 --> 00:15:17.180
You've got to walk out before
we signed any contracts.

260
00:15:17.180 --> 00:15:20.120
We've got to look at how
this is going to work.

261
00:15:20.120 --> 00:15:25.624
How was this collaboration on
the consistency going to be

262

put into place across all of our supplies.
>> So

263
00:15:29.928 --> 00:15:35.010
much to consider, Jo, but that begs
question have we done a deep enough

264
00:15:35.010 --> 00:15:40.433
dive inside of problem management and
we're ready to move on or are there any

265
00:15:40.433 --> 00:15:44.025
other issues that we need to think about?
>> We have and

266
00:15:44.025 --> 00:15:47.310
we have to bare in mind that
we're on new foundation level.

267
00:15:47.310 --> 00:15:52.460
And so yes, we've done a deep enough dive
into incident and problem management.

268
00:15:52.460 --> 00:15:56.686
The thing that you have to remember is
that even though incident and problem

269
00:15:56.686 --> 00:16:01.470
management have two separate areas of
responsibility, you can't separate them.

270
00:16:01.470 --> 00:16:04.690
Because you can't have
an incident without a problem.

271
00:16:04.690 --> 00:16:07.336
A problem is what causes the incident.

272
00:16:07.336 --> 00:16:10.120
But for our foundation level, yes.

273
00:16:10.120 --> 00:16:12.045
We have to and
I could talk for days on this.

274
00:16:12.045 --> 00:16:15.678
But no, we've done enough for this level.
>> Well, Jo,

275
00:16:15.678 --> 00:16:18.120
I'm kind of interested where
are we going from here.

276

284
00:16:43.098 --> 00:16:44.995

00:16:44.995 --> 00:16:46.483

>> Greetings everyone,

4
00:00:12.919 --> 00:00:16.020
and welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:16.020 --> 00:00:17.220
I'm your host Justin Dennison, and

6
00:00:17.220 --> 00:00:20.400
we're coming back at you with more
SIAM Foundation and well, we're gonna be

7
00:00:20.400 --> 00:00:24.910
looking at service level management and
supplier management in this episode.

8
00:00:24.910 --> 00:00:26.622
And here to help us along
is Miss Jo Peacock.

9
00:00:26.622 --> 00:00:28.760
How you doing today Jo?
>> Absolutely great.

10
00:00:28.760 --> 00:00:29.420

11
00:00:29.420 --> 00:00:31.720

12
00:00:31.720 --> 00:00:35.900

of my wheelhouse on these two topics.

13
00:00:35.900 --> 00:00:39.500
So [LAUGH] I feel like we're about
to have a little bit of fun.

14
00:00:39.500 --> 00:00:43.800
Service level management,
is that typically abbreviated as SLM?

15
00:00:43.800 --> 00:00:44.620
>> It is, yeah.

16
00:00:44.620 --> 00:00:48.180
I mean, apart from the fact that you can
never write it out in full because it

17
00:00:48.180 --> 00:00:49.141
takes too long.

18
00:00:49.141 --> 00:00:53.313
[LAUGH] But other than that, service level
management is one of the most sort of

19
00:00:53.313 --> 00:00:56.152
commonly abbreviated
processes in the whole of IT.

20
00:00:56.152 --> 00:01:01.350
And we put service level management and
supplier management together,

21
00:01:01.350 --> 00:01:06.207
purely because they're pretty much
doing exactly the same thing,

22
00:01:06.207 --> 00:01:09.020
especially in a SIAM Ecosystem.

23
00:01:09.020 --> 00:01:11.520
So service level management is about,

24
00:01:11.520 --> 00:01:14.340
if we take a look at the purpose of
service level management, it's about

25
00:01:14.340 --> 00:01:20.150
ensuring that the performance of
the service meets the agreed requirements.

26
00:01:20.150 --> 00:01:23.240
And these requirements are set
out to a service level target.

27
00:01:23.240 --> 00:01:25.390
So the first thing that
I wanted to cover is,

28
00:01:25.390 --> 00:01:29.530
it mentions the word contract there and
we've already had an episode.

29
00:01:29.530 --> 00:01:32.830
If you've been following the episodes
through in chronological order,

30
00:01:32.830 --> 00:01:35.900
then you'll see that we've
already had an episode where

31
00:01:35.900 --> 00:01:39.010
we talked about contract management.

32
00:01:39.010 --> 00:01:43.790
And contract management is specifically
about managing the nuances

33
00:01:43.790 --> 00:01:44.670
of the contract.

34
00:01:44.670 --> 00:01:46.410
It's about all of the legal stuff.

35
00:01:47.680 --> 00:01:48.860
Supply management,

36
00:01:48.860 --> 00:01:53.320
on the other hand, well, it's tied
in with service level management.

37
00:01:53.320 --> 00:01:58.360
And they're pretty much the same process,
it just depends

38
00:01:58.360 --> 00:02:02.680
on whether we're talking about internal or
external providers, and whether we're

39
00:02:02.680 --> 00:02:06.560
talking about the agreement with
the service integrator and the customer.

40
00:02:08.510 --> 00:02:12.470
Now that I've completely lost you because
I can see the look on Justin's face.

41
00:02:12.470 --> 00:02:15.011
Right?
[LAUGH] Straight away.

42
00:02:15.011 --> 00:02:18.200
[LAUGH] Yup, that was it
>> [LAUGH]

43
00:02:18.200 --> 00:02:20.557
>> Let's go into this a little bit more in

44
00:02:20.557 --> 00:02:21.250
depth.

45
00:02:21.250 --> 00:02:26.020
The purpose said that it ensures
that service performance meets or

46
00:02:26.020 --> 00:02:28.460
exceeds the agreed requirements.

47
00:02:28.460 --> 00:02:29.870
And I add in those words or

48
00:02:29.870 --> 00:02:34.830
exceeds because that's what we're
aiming to do, is we're aiming to exceed

49
00:02:34.830 --> 00:02:39.360
the service level targets that
are required by the organization.

50
00:02:41.070 --> 00:02:44.960
So I'm gonna go back
right to the very start.

51
00:02:44.960 --> 00:02:49.720
And right to the very start of any
given service we, the customer,

52
00:02:49.720 --> 00:02:53.590
sets out the definition or
their requirements.

53
00:02:53.590 --> 00:02:55.270
We call them service level requirements.

54
00:02:55.270 --> 00:03:01.339
And the service level requirements
are the requirements of that service.

55
00:03:02.940 --> 00:03:08.090
So ordinarily, the customer would
say to the service integrator,

56
00:03:09.720 --> 00:03:11.550
I want the ability to send and
to see the email.

57
00:03:13.030 --> 00:03:14.620
So now I'm gonna involve Justin.

58
00:03:16.050 --> 00:03:20.480
What's wrong with that statement?
>> Seems like there's kind of a load of

59
00:03:20.480 --> 00:03:22.370
I want to send and receive email.

60
00:03:22.370 --> 00:03:24.050
It doesn't seem specific enough.

61
00:03:24.050 --> 00:03:27.870
What times do you want send and
receive email?

62
00:03:27.870 --> 00:03:33.310
What are the guarantees?
>> Sorry, wait a minute, let me back up.

63
00:03:33.310 --> 00:03:35.374
I used her bad word.

64
00:03:35.374 --> 00:03:40.206
What are the expectations?

65
00:03:40.206 --> 00:03:45.496
I know we've talked about timing before,
making sure we know about maintenance

66
00:03:45.496 --> 00:03:49.419
periods and things of that nature.
>> When we've looked at things like

67
00:03:49.419 --> 00:03:52.509
incident management and
we've looked at problem management and

68
00:03:52.509 --> 00:03:56.280
we've understood that the service
description is so important.

69
00:03:56.280 --> 00:03:58.920
How do you know if you've had
an incident to your service,

70
00:03:58.920 --> 00:04:02.140
an interruption to your service,
if you don't know what your service is?

71
00:04:02.140 --> 00:04:06.210
And the example that we used when we
talked about incident management,

72
00:04:06.210 --> 00:04:10.520
if you take a look at that episode,
was the example of a printer.

73
00:04:10.520 --> 00:04:16.190
And if you remember, is my service that
printer, well, is it just that report,

74
00:04:16.190 --> 00:04:20.220
or is my service that report from
that printer over there specifically.

75
00:04:20.220 --> 00:04:24.480
What's in the SLA is incredibly important.

76
00:04:24.480 --> 00:04:27.380
How we start off when we
are defining a new service,

77
00:04:27.380 --> 00:04:32.860
when the customer comes to us and says, we
want to ability to send and receive email.

78
00:04:32.860 --> 00:04:34.090
That's what they're starting off with.

79
00:04:34.090 --> 00:04:36.150
And Justin used the word ambiguous.

80
00:04:36.150 --> 00:04:38.610
It's not particularly specific.

81
00:04:38.610 --> 00:04:42.110
But invariably,
the customer doesn't know what they want.

82
00:04:42.110 --> 00:04:45.900
Invariably, the customer will come to us
and say I want the ability to send and

83
00:04:45.900 --> 00:04:50.070
receive email without actually
understanding the requirements.

84
00:04:50.070 --> 00:04:56.420
So the first thing the service level
management has got to do as a process,

85
00:04:56.420 --> 00:05:00.466
is sit down and
actually add in service-level targets.

86
00:05:00.466 --> 00:05:04.550
And those service-level targets
will add in the specifics.

87
00:05:04.550 --> 00:05:09.970
So things like, I want the ability to
send and receive email 24 hours a day.

88
00:05:09.970 --> 00:05:15.290
I want my email to, once I press send,
to actually disappear and

89
00:05:15.290 --> 00:05:19.990
be sent within a minute,
or within 30 seconds.

90
00:05:19.990 --> 00:05:25.580
Or, and
I want the ability to have 5,000 licenses.

91
00:05:25.580 --> 00:05:31.260
So service level management
most of all works out.

92
00:05:31.260 --> 00:05:35.660
It takes the statement of requirements
from business relationship management,

93
00:05:35.660 --> 00:05:36.980
from the customer, and

94
00:05:36.980 --> 00:05:41.260
then works out exactly what our
service level targets would be.

95
00:05:42.580 --> 00:05:44.970
I use the word targets,

96
00:05:44.970 --> 00:05:49.830
remember Justin used the word guarantee.
>> I've backed up just so we're clear,

97
00:05:49.830 --> 00:05:53.030
I've backed up and I said expectations
>> [LAUGH]

98
00:05:53.030 --> 00:05:54.772
>> And I think I know where you're going

99
00:05:54.772 --> 00:05:55.960
with this right?

100
00:05:55.960 --> 00:05:59.550
It's kinda one of those things
where I say guarantees and

101
00:05:59.550 --> 00:06:03.630
my guarantee isn't quite as concrete.

102
00:06:03.630 --> 00:06:07.680
But targets, I guess,
are what we're striving for, but

103
00:06:07.680 --> 00:06:09.780
there could be some variability in that.

104
00:06:09.780 --> 00:06:14.750
And that's kind of assumed,
or not necessarily assumed,

105
00:06:14.750 --> 00:06:18.410
but maybe even made explicit.
>> Right, they've gotta be made explicit.

106
00:06:18.410 --> 00:06:22.280
We can't assume anything, and
we've gotta have everything written down.

107
00:06:22.280 --> 00:06:29.050
But it's not just as simple as gathering
the requirements and writing them down.

108
00:06:29.050 --> 00:06:31.550
Because what has to happen, and

109
00:06:31.550 --> 00:06:37.120
this is where it gets complicated
especially in the SIAM ecosystem.

110
00:06:37.120 --> 00:06:39.500
Is we first of all,
we've got three layers.

111
00:06:39.500 --> 00:06:42.830
If you remember these three layers, we've
got our customer layer, we've got our

112
00:06:42.830 --> 00:06:47.310
service integrator layer, and then
we've got our service provider layers.

113
00:06:47.310 --> 00:06:51.220
And those service providers could
be either internal or external.

114
00:06:51.220 --> 00:06:54.930
So when we talk about internal service
providers, we talk about agreements.

115
00:06:54.930 --> 00:06:57.230
And when we talk about
external service providers,

116
00:06:57.230 --> 00:07:01.620
we talk about contracts which is
where supply management comes in.

117
00:07:03.100 --> 00:07:06.970
So what we're doing right
now is we're agreeing

118
00:07:06.970 --> 00:07:10.000
between the service integrator and
the customer.

119
00:07:10.000 --> 00:07:13.140
We're agreeing what the customer will see.

120
00:07:14.260 --> 00:07:17.140
We've not gone down to
this lower layer yet.

121
00:07:17.140 --> 00:07:19.760
We're agreeing what the customer will see.

122
00:07:19.760 --> 00:07:25.350
So here we're talking about the targets
that the customer wants to achieve.

123
00:07:25.350 --> 00:07:29.709
And they've got to be incredibly specific
because you see, we can't start to,

124
00:07:29.709 --> 00:07:33.828
if the customer is here, and our layer
here is with the service integrated.

125
00:07:33.828 --> 00:07:36.689
We can't start to negotiate these targets

126
00:07:36.689 --> 00:07:40.909
until we understand what these
targets are going to look like.

127
00:07:42.060 --> 00:07:47.039
So the customer tells us that they
want the ability to send an email

128
00:07:47.039 --> 00:07:48.404
24 hours a day.

129
00:07:48.404 --> 00:07:53.257
So now, the service integrator,
service level management, and

130
00:07:53.257 --> 00:07:58.718
supply management as well, has now
got to work out There's the customer,

131
00:07:58.718 --> 00:08:01.337
