designed then it's very,

360
00:23:10.901 --> 00:23:14.504
very difficult to deviate
from that contract.

361
00:23:14.504 --> 00:23:17.727
It's very difficult to make
changes to that contract.

362
00:23:17.727 --> 00:23:22.266
And this is why supply management
also has to get involved and

363
00:23:22.266 --> 00:23:27.339
say right, well, we're going to
tentatively sign the contract,

364
00:23:27.339 --> 00:23:32.145
but we have to have a period where
we can make changes dependent on

365
00:23:32.145 --> 00:23:38.050
the reaction of the service in the live
environment once it goes live.

366
00:23:38.050 --> 00:23:40.650
Dependent on things like workload.

367
00:23:40.650 --> 00:23:43.518
Dependent on bandwidth utilization.

368
00:23:43.518 --> 00:23:49.388
Dependent on the utilization of our
customer, bearing in mind as well,

369
00:23:49.388 --> 00:23:54.874
when we first deploy a new service
utilization of that new service,

370
00:23:54.874 --> 00:23:58.257
whatever it may be, is not at it's norm.

371
00:23:58.257 --> 00:24:00.935
What happens is when you
deploy a new service,

372
00:24:00.935 --> 00:24:04.106
you will see a peak of
utilization from your customer.

373
00:24:04.106 --> 00:24:08.193
And that's because, that's the curiosity
factor, and that curiosity factor

374
00:24:08.193 --> 00:24:11.512
has everybody logging in and
everybody seeing what it's about.

375
00:24:11.512 --> 00:24:13.701
But then immediately following that, and

376
00:24:13.701 --> 00:24:16.510
that curiosity factor can
last literally a day or two.

377
00:24:16.510 --> 00:24:21.430
And then immediately following
that you get a deflation,

378
00:24:21.430 --> 00:24:24.720
you get a trough in utilization.

379
00:24:24.720 --> 00:24:28.807
Where your customer goes through what we
call the emotional cycle of change, and

380
00:24:28.807 --> 00:24:33.610
where your customer looks at it and says,
yeah, I don't wanna be dealing with that.

381
00:24:34.690 --> 00:24:36.230
Yeah, let's leave that.

382
00:24:36.230 --> 00:24:40.090
And so for the first couple of weeks
you're going to get a huge fluctuation

383
00:24:40.090 --> 00:24:41.460
in usage.

384
00:24:41.460 --> 00:24:46.360
And so it's not until that
has started to even out.

385
00:24:46.360 --> 00:24:49.500
That's when we look to sign
our service level Agreements.

386
00:24:49.500 --> 00:24:53.930
We don't want to sign before
that early life support period.

387
00:24:53.930 --> 00:24:59.100
Because we want to ensure that we've
reached our sort of optimum performance.

388
00:24:59.100 --> 00:25:03.180
And it's at that point in time when we
ensure that we get everything else signed.

389
00:25:03.180 --> 00:25:05.942
Does that makes sense?
>> That does make sense.

390
00:25:05.942 --> 00:25:10.395
And this may, as I said, originally I
was like, that's counterintuitive, but

391
00:25:10.395 --> 00:25:14.020
the more I think about it,
as you said, we kinda get this wiggle.

392
00:25:14.020 --> 00:25:18.170
But it's going to dampen out and lead to
this, what I would call a steady state.

393
00:25:18.170 --> 00:25:21.010
Where you're like,
I'm gonna know about utilization,

394
00:25:21.010 --> 00:25:23.870
I'm gonna know about usage
in a more accurate manner,

395
00:25:23.870 --> 00:25:26.440
instead of trying to figure out
where all this noise is coming from.

396
00:25:26.440 --> 00:25:28.366
Where people are like, this is amazing.

397
00:25:28.366 --> 00:25:29.380
This is hard.

398
00:25:29.380 --> 00:25:30.610
This is cool again.

399
00:25:30.610 --> 00:25:32.830
This is all right, I guess.

400
00:25:32.830 --> 00:25:35.710
But, I do want to clarify something, Jo.

401
00:25:35.710 --> 00:25:37.740
We are doing this in a live environment,
but

402
00:25:37.740 --> 00:25:41.750
we're not advocating that you do not
do any type of test environment.

403
00:25:41.750 --> 00:25:45.040
Even though we're gonna have differences.

404
00:25:45.040 --> 00:25:48.920
We're just making sure.
>> We are not talking about testing.

405
00:25:48.920 --> 00:25:51.040
This has got nothing to do with testing.

406
00:25:51.040 --> 00:25:53.790
Testing has to happen
in a test environment.

407
00:25:53.790 --> 00:25:57.820
But what I'm saying to you is that we
don't know the service is going to perform

408
00:25:57.820 --> 00:25:59.907
until we get it in the live environment.

409
00:25:59.907 --> 00:26:02.753
And it doesn't matter how
good our test environment is,

410
00:26:02.753 --> 00:26:05.430
it does not mimic identically
our live environment.

411
00:26:05.430 --> 00:26:06.724
You don't have the same users.

412
00:26:06.724 --> 00:26:11.859
It doesn't matter what simulation
programs we have on our test environment,

413
00:26:11.859 --> 00:26:14.140
we don't mimic our users.

414
00:26:14.140 --> 00:26:15.675
You can't mimic me.

415
00:26:15.675 --> 00:26:20.100
[LAUGH] Actually no one can predict
what I'm gonna do with any service.

416
00:26:21.140 --> 00:26:24.030
Stop looking at me like that.
>> [LAUGH] It

417
00:26:24.030 --> 00:26:26.400
sounds a little bit like a challenge, Jo.
>> [LAUGH]

418
00:26:26.400 --> 00:26:27.770
>> But I don't know if it would

419
00:26:27.770 --> 00:26:32.690
necessarily be, I don't know if
we have time in this episode,

420
00:26:32.690 --> 00:26:34.620
in order to see that come to fruition.

421
00:26:34.620 --> 00:26:37.180
Now, Jo, we've been talking
about service level management.

422
00:26:37.180 --> 00:26:40.430
We haven't really talked about
supplier management too much,

423
00:26:40.430 --> 00:26:41.037
have we?
>> Well, we have.

424
00:26:41.037 --> 00:26:42.611
>> Or is it kind of been there steeped in

425
00:26:42.611 --> 00:26:43.720
there?
>> It is.

426
00:26:43.720 --> 00:26:44.860
We have.

427
00:26:44.860 --> 00:26:48.320
What we're gonna do now is up till now all
we've talked about is the proactive part

428
00:26:48.320 --> 00:26:50.570
of service level management and
supplier management.

429
00:26:50.570 --> 00:26:54.180
You see,
what we're looking at is right now if

430
00:26:54.180 --> 00:26:58.300
we take this service integrator layer and
we have our customer layer up here,

431
00:26:58.300 --> 00:27:02.070
then supplier management is managing
those service level agreements and

432
00:27:02.070 --> 00:27:05.350
contracts with the external
service providers.

433
00:27:05.350 --> 00:27:09.720
So supplier management manages
the external service providers, and

434
00:27:09.720 --> 00:27:13.455
service level management manages
the internal service providers.

435
00:27:13.455 --> 00:27:15.415
But they're doing exactly the same thing.

436
00:27:15.415 --> 00:27:18.255
It's just that with supplies,
we're talking about contracts.

437
00:27:18.255 --> 00:27:21.685
With service level management,
we're talking about agreements.

438
00:27:21.685 --> 00:27:23.425
So right now, what we've done is,

439
00:27:23.425 --> 00:27:27.585
we've got our service levels to
the point where they've been signed.

440
00:27:28.880 --> 00:27:32.260
Now we've gotta carry on
with the business as usual.

441
00:27:32.260 --> 00:27:33.560
But we're not gonna do that right now.

442
00:27:33.560 --> 00:27:34.970
We're actually gonna come back.

443
00:27:34.970 --> 00:27:39.140
Because in our part two, in our next
episode, we're gonna look at the business

444
00:27:39.140 --> 00:27:43.700
as usual side of service level management.
>> So a part two?

445
00:27:43.700 --> 00:27:47.570
I tell you what, you would do a disservice
to yourself if you miss this.

446
00:27:47.570 --> 00:27:50.548
So definitely come on back as we continue
looking at service level management and

447
00:27:50.548 --> 00:27:51.440
supplier management.

448
00:27:51.440 --> 00:27:54.930
And well,
we'll be here with business as usual.

449
00:27:54.930 --> 00:27:56.820
But for now we're gonna go ahead and
get outta here.

450
00:27:56.820 --> 00:27:58.094
So signing off for ITPRO.TV,

451
00:27:58.094 --> 00:27:59.902
I've been your host Justin Dennison.
>> And

452
00:27:59.902 --> 00:28:01.170
I'm Jo Peacock.
>> And we'll see you next time.

453
00:28:01.170 --> 00:28:08.960
[MUSIC]

454
00:28:08.960 --> 00:28:11.274
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.200 --> 00:00:02.155
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.155 --> 00:00:05.859
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.859 --> 00:00:07.523
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.523 --> 00:00:12.620
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Greetings everyone,

5
00:00:12.620 --> 00:00:16.060
and welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.060 --> 00:00:17.670
I'm your host Justin Dennison, and, well,

7
00:00:17.670 --> 00:00:22.800
welcome back to a part two of service
level management and supplier management.

8
00:00:22.800 --> 00:00:26.670
Yeah, you should definitely go watch that
part one if you haven't checked that out.

9
00:00:26.670 --> 00:00:31.590
And luckily, we were able to get her back
to help us navigate this part two, Ms.

10
00:00:31.590 --> 00:00:34.410
Jo Peacock, how you doing today, Jo?
>> Absolutely great, thank you Justin,

11
00:00:34.410 --> 00:00:37.045
how are you?
>> I am doing fantastic other than

12
00:00:37.045 --> 00:00:40.390
the times where I find
out I don't actually know

13
00:00:40.390 --> 00:00:41.990
anything that I thought I did.

14
00:00:41.990 --> 00:00:44.770
And then there's other times that
I'm victorious where I'm like,

15
00:00:44.770 --> 00:00:45.790
yeah that kind of makes sense.

16
00:00:45.790 --> 00:00:51.340
And one of the things in the part one that
made sense is we don't set these service

17
00:00:51.340 --> 00:00:55.840
level targets kind of in stone until
we've hit more or less this steady state.

18
00:00:55.840 --> 00:01:00.248
And that's a summation by me, definitely
make it right if I got it wrong.

19
00:01:00.248 --> 00:01:03.180
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, you're kind of there,

20
00:01:03.180 --> 00:01:08.250
I mean, I like the way you said more or
less hit the steady state.

21
00:01:08.250 --> 00:01:12.730
We have this early life support period or
this hyper care or

22
00:01:12.730 --> 00:01:17.250
intensive care period after
we have deployed a service.

23
00:01:17.250 --> 00:01:20.631
And it's only when we have
exited that particular phase,

24
00:01:20.631 --> 00:01:24.842
that's when we sign our service level
agreements and their contracts.

25
00:01:24.842 --> 00:01:29.243
Now, you may want to tentatively
sign them or you may wanna sign,

26
00:01:29.243 --> 00:01:31.250
especially with a contract.

27
00:01:31.250 --> 00:01:32.768
You may wanna sign it, but

28
00:01:32.768 --> 00:01:37.400
with the conditions that you can change
within the first, say, three months.

29
00:01:38.860 --> 00:01:44.130
And of course, that then gives
a level of assurance to both your

30
00:01:44.130 --> 00:01:46.660
supplier and to you.

31
00:01:46.660 --> 00:01:51.578
Ultimately what we're saying is that it
would not be best practice to agree on

32
00:01:51.578 --> 00:01:53.393
a service level agreement or

33
00:01:53.393 --> 00:01:56.963
a contract before you put it
into the live environment.

34
00:01:56.963 --> 00:02:01.933
Because you simply do not know how
that service is going to behave

35
00:02:01.933 --> 00:02:04.460
in that live environment.

36
00:02:04.460 --> 00:02:09.570
So we don't want to set expectations and
make promises,

37
00:02:09.570 --> 00:02:13.562
make assurances to the customer,
only to find that we can't achieve that.

38
00:02:13.562 --> 00:02:18.490
Quite often, our test environment,
despite the fact that it mimics our live

39
00:02:18.490 --> 00:02:22.610
environment and we will say, yes,
the test environment is really good.

40
00:02:22.610 --> 00:02:26.180
Quite often, there's something in our test
environment that is slightly different.

41
00:02:26.180 --> 00:02:29.908
There's something in our test
environment that's not exactly the same.

42
00:02:29.908 --> 00:02:31.858
And as I said in a previous episode,

43
00:02:31.858 --> 00:02:35.050
you haven't got the same users
in your test environment.

44
00:02:35.050 --> 00:02:36.630
Even though you might have some really,

45
00:02:36.630 --> 00:02:41.560
really good programs to mimic users,
you can't always mimic all your users.

46
00:02:41.560 --> 00:02:45.430
Nobody can mimic me, and
don't even try it, Justin.

47
00:02:45.430 --> 00:02:49.496
And nobody can mimic Justin either,
we wouldn't want it, no, he's unique.

48
00:02:49.496 --> 00:02:51.459
>> [LAUGH] I don't know, Jo,

49
00:02:51.459 --> 00:02:53.790
I feel like some people might.

50
00:02:53.790 --> 00:02:57.280
But it could be even
something as simple as

51
00:02:57.280 --> 00:03:01.240
other services that are running in the
live environment that you're not in that.

52
00:03:01.240 --> 00:03:04.652
You're like, yeah, I forgot,
that's running in the live environment,

53
00:03:04.652 --> 00:03:06.400
that I have to resource share.

54
00:03:06.400 --> 00:03:10.003
And then things are now
inherently different, so

55
00:03:10.003 --> 00:03:12.330
you just try your best, right?

56
00:03:12.330 --> 00:03:14.830
You should test out things,
have a test environment.

57
00:03:14.830 --> 00:03:18.563
Get as close as possible with full
realization that things still may be

58
00:03:18.563 --> 00:03:21.181
different.
>> Well, you have to bear in mind that

59
00:03:21.181 --> 00:03:25.081
you've got all of your services
running on the same infrastructure,

60
00:03:25.081 --> 00:03:28.100
they're all running on the same network.

61
00:03:28.100 --> 00:03:30.130
And so, as you just mentioned there,

62
00:03:30.130 --> 00:03:34.210
you've got services that you may
not have in your test environment.

63
00:03:34.210 --> 00:03:39.770
Or you've gotta say, what if a service
fails in the live environment and

64
00:03:39.770 --> 00:03:45.200
that failure actually impacts that
service that you have just deployed?

65
00:03:45.200 --> 00:03:48.240
You have absolutely no way
of predicting that, and

66
00:03:48.240 --> 00:03:52.810
it doesn't matter how,
what do I wanna say?

67
00:03:52.810 --> 00:03:57.240
I wanna say it doesn't matter how well
your suppliers at this particular level,

68
00:03:57.240 --> 00:03:58.810
at the service provider level,

69
00:03:58.810 --> 00:04:01.620
it doesn't matter how well they
communicate with each other.

70
00:04:01.620 --> 00:04:05.130
There's still no predicting
those types of failures.

71
00:04:05.130 --> 00:04:07.770
Now, I agree with you,
I know what you're saying.

72
00:04:07.770 --> 00:04:10.360
You're thinking to yourself, well,
this could happen at any point in time,

73
00:04:10.360 --> 00:04:10.920
though, couldn't it?

74
00:04:10.920 --> 00:04:15.774
And it could, yes, but let's not try and

75
00:04:15.774 --> 00:04:23.973
agree thing before we've got as big
a picture as we possibly can have.

76
00:04:23.973 --> 00:04:31.101
And you can't have things cast
in stone when you simply have so

77
00:04:31.101 --> 00:04:35.087
much that is, well, uncertain.

78
00:04:35.087 --> 00:04:40.048
So let's wait until we
have a bedding in period,

79
00:04:40.048 --> 00:04:46.715
until we have a period in time where
we can establish a status quo.

80
00:04:46.715 --> 00:04:49.050
I'm not gonna say maintain a status quo,

81
00:04:49.050 --> 00:04:52.798
I'm gonna establish a business
as usual operating performance.

82
00:04:52.798 --> 00:04:57.725
That's when we can safely say,
okay, under normal circumstances,

83
00:04:57.725 --> 00:05:00.850
this is how the service would operate.

84
00:05:00.850 --> 00:05:03.300
Therefore, let's sign our
service level agreements and

85
00:05:03.300 --> 00:05:05.940
let's sign our service level targets.

86
00:05:05.940 --> 00:05:10.350
And it's that point in time that we

87
00:05:10.350 --> 00:05:14.580
can start to enforce penalties,
and we can start to

88
00:05:14.580 --> 00:05:19.650
enforce all of the other incentives that
we might have put into our contract.

89
00:05:19.650 --> 00:05:21.280
It's at that point in time, but

90
00:05:21.280 --> 00:05:25.210
before that,
we're still having this burgeoning period.

91
00:05:25.210 --> 00:05:28.240
And before that,
we want to ensure that we're still

92
00:05:28.240 --> 00:05:32.960
able to negotiate the targets in the SLAs,
because they could change.

93
00:05:32.960 --> 00:05:34.830
We might realize, and by the way, I mean,

94
00:05:34.830 --> 00:05:37.070
this doesn't work in
a negative way all the time.

95
00:05:37.070 --> 00:05:41.910
We might actually consider that for
some of our services, and I've seen

96
00:05:41.910 --> 00:05:46.310
this happen as well, that the service
actually performs better than we expected.

97
00:05:46.310 --> 00:05:50.757
And in fact, negotiating our service
level targets means that we can

98
00:05:50.757 --> 00:05:55.140
negotiate our service level targets
to be the better performance.

99
00:05:55.140 --> 00:05:59.460
To actually deliver a better performance,
because when we put it into

100
00:05:59.460 --> 00:06:03.140
the live environment, it worked a lot
better than what we expected it to.

101
00:06:03.140 --> 00:06:04.868
So it doesn't always work badly, and

102
00:06:04.868 --> 00:06:07.306
I know that that's the way
that a lot of people think.

103
00:06:07.306 --> 00:06:11.463
And that's the way there are a lot of
customers think is that, well, you might

104
00:06:11.463 --> 00:06:15.522
not be able to meet those targets,
that's why we don't wanna agree just yet.

105
00:06:15.522 --> 00:06:20.380
Well, no, cuz we might exceed those
targets, so let's adjust them accordingly.

106
00:06:21.450 --> 00:06:26.060
So now we looked at what happens when
we are negotiating our service level

107
00:06:26.060 --> 00:06:27.370
agreements.

108
00:06:27.370 --> 00:06:31.310
I've just got one question,
actually, before we just move on.

109
00:06:31.310 --> 00:06:34.966
How long do you think we should
agree a service level agreement for?

110
00:06:34.966 --> 00:06:37.476
>> All right, so how long of a duration

111
00:06:37.476 --> 00:06:42.499
should we say, this is an acceptable,
we're going to maintain this,

112
00:06:42.499 --> 00:06:47.472
it's that what you're asking?
>> Not just about maintaining it,

113
00:06:47.472 --> 00:06:51.771
but if you were to agree a contract,
how long would you agree it for?

114
00:06:51.771 --> 00:06:55.036
>> Jo, this is not my area of expertise,

115
00:06:55.036 --> 00:06:59.843
I'm gonna guess a year,
I'm gonna say a year at a time.

116
00:06:59.843 --> 00:07:00.900
>> [LAUGH]

117
00:07:00.900 --> 00:07:03.242
>> Or maybe the first time is a year, and

118
00:07:03.242 --> 00:07:08.231
then, if things kind of settle out,
maybe you have a longer extended option or

119
00:07:08.231 --> 00:07:11.370
whatever it may be.
>> I'm not sure about the longer extended

120
00:07:11.370 --> 00:07:13.557
option.
>> I'm gonna go with a year then, Jo,

121
00:07:13.557 --> 00:07:15.673
I'm gonna go with a year [LAUGH].
>> Yeah,

122
00:07:15.673 --> 00:07:21.040
I mean best practice simply tells
you that it needs to be a year.

123
00:07:21.040 --> 00:07:25.660
We want to have stability, but
we also want to ensure that we can,

124
00:07:25.660 --> 00:07:29.070
well, meet the needs of the organization.

125
00:07:29.070 --> 00:07:31.587
And the needs of the organization
will change, they simply will.

126
00:07:31.587 --> 00:07:33.979
Nothing remains static for five years,

127
00:07:33.979 --> 00:07:37.297
your requirements do not remain static for
five years.

128
00:07:37.297 --> 00:07:41.019
Your organization will change,
whether it will grow,

129
00:07:41.019 --> 00:07:47.150
whether it will change the way it does
business, whether technology will change.

130
00:07:47.150 --> 00:07:52.935
There are so many different factors in
there, so a service level agreement,

131
00:07:52.935 --> 00:07:57.389
and a contract as well,
should be reevaluated every year.

00:20:39.258 --> 00:20:43.300
And then in another subsequent episode
we're gonna look at project management

303
00:20:43.300 --> 00:20:45.500
frameworks as well or methodologies.
>> Well,

304
00:20:45.500 --> 00:20:49.930
I tell you what Jo, I'm kind of interested
to see what COBIT actually stands for

305
00:20:49.930 --> 00:20:53.290
and, well, hopefully you'll come
on back and find that with me.

306
00:20:53.290 --> 00:20:55.180
But for now we're gonna go ahead and
get outta here.

307
00:20:55.180 --> 00:20:58.630
So signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

308
00:20:58.630 --> 00:20:59.570
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

309
00:20:59.570 --> 00:21:01.637
>> And we'll see you next time.

310
00:21:01.637 --> 00:21:07.516
[MUSIC]

311
00:21:07.516 --> 00:21:10.972
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Jo and Justin explore the synergy between the SIAM eco-system and the Lean methodology for process improvement and the COBIT management framework.
episodes.title: SIAM and Other Frameworks: Lean and COBIT
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.593
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.593 --> 00:00:03.334
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.334 --> 00:00:04.101
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:04.101 --> 00:00:04.983
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:04.983 --> 00:00:09.814
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Greetings,

6
00:00:09.814 --> 00:00:16.250
everyone and welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.250 --> 00:00:17.390
I'm your host, Justin Dennison and

8
00:00:17.390 --> 00:00:21.090
we're continuing on with
our SIAM foundation course.

9
00:00:21.090 --> 00:00:24.330
And we're looking at how SIAM
fits in with other frameworks.

10
00:00:24.330 --> 00:00:27.400
In particular,
we're gonna be looking at Lean and COBITS.

11
00:00:27.400 --> 00:00:29.050
I tell you what, that is fun to say.

12
00:00:29.050 --> 00:00:29.952
I'm not gonna lie.
[LAUGH] And

13
00:00:29.952 --> 00:00:32.810
here to help us along in that
endeavor is Miss Jo Peacock.

14
00:00:32.810 --> 00:00:34.420
How you doing today, Jo?
>> Absolutely great.

15
00:00:34.420 --> 00:00:35.020
Thank you, Justin.

16
00:00:35.020 --> 00:00:37.330
How are you?
>> I am doing fantastic.

17
00:00:37.330 --> 00:00:41.060
And COBITS,
had to say it again cuz it's fun.

18
00:00:41.060 --> 00:00:47.540
It probably stands for something but
these are not three letter acronyms.

19
00:00:47.540 --> 00:00:50.980
Can you just give us a brief
overview of Lean and COBITS just so

20
00:00:50.980 --> 00:00:55.640
we all have a level playing ground
before we actually see how SIAM kind of

21
00:00:55.640 --> 00:00:57.040
intertwines with this?
>> Right.

22
00:00:57.040 --> 00:01:00.553
Well, you need to first of all
drop the f's on that COBIT thing.

23
00:01:00.553 --> 00:01:01.390
>> That's right.

24
00:01:01.390 --> 00:01:06.573
There's just one COBIT, Control Objectives
for Information Technology for IT.

25
00:01:06.573 --> 00:01:13.525
And Lean Sigma is an evolution
from Six Sigma of, well,

26
00:01:13.525 --> 00:01:18.895
it's about process maturity but it's
also about process efficiency as well.

27
00:01:18.895 --> 00:01:24.015
And so what we're going to do is we're
gonna look at those two frameworks,

28
00:01:24.015 --> 00:01:27.620
those two methodologies, concepts,
if you want to call them that.

29
00:01:27.620 --> 00:01:30.770
And how they link into
this SIAM ecosystem, and

30
00:01:30.770 --> 00:01:35.180
we're actually gonna start off with Lean
as opposed to the Control Objectives.

31
00:01:35.180 --> 00:01:38.310
So let's take a look at Lean then.

32
00:01:38.310 --> 00:01:43.510
So Lean is, as you can see from these
particular bullet points, Lean's

33
00:01:43.510 --> 00:01:50.080
objectives are to minimize waste
by maximizing customer value.

34
00:01:50.080 --> 00:01:54.790
It's about doing more
with less you could say.

35
00:01:54.790 --> 00:02:00.760
So what we want to do here with Lean is we
want to continually improve our efficiency

36
00:02:00.760 --> 00:02:07.020
and we want to do this by reducing
what we call our Muda or waste.

37
00:02:07.020 --> 00:02:11.310
And you'll see that bottom bullet
point talks about zero waste there.

38
00:02:11.310 --> 00:02:14.980
So what we want to do
in the next particular

39
00:02:14.980 --> 00:02:17.490
slide tells us a little bit more.

40
00:02:17.490 --> 00:02:22.332
But I see you looking confused already.
>> [LAUGH] All right, so all right,

41
00:02:22.332 --> 00:02:26.243
running theme, the S that I add
on things that I don't need to.

42
00:02:26.243 --> 00:02:28.871
But besides that,
you said the word Muda and

43
00:02:28.871 --> 00:02:31.077
I thought you were making up words.
>> [LAUGH]

44
00:02:31.077 --> 00:02:32.115
>> But then it's

45
00:02:32.115 --> 00:02:33.840
on the slide.
>> Yep.

46
00:02:33.840 --> 00:02:37.200
>> So Muda is just waste?

47
00:02:37.200 --> 00:02:38.606
>> Yeah, it's Japanese word for

48
00:02:38.606 --> 00:02:41.300
waste.
>> Okay, that makes sense.

49
00:02:41.300 --> 00:02:42.945
I was like, here we go,
are you all right, Jo?

50
00:02:42.945 --> 00:02:44.802
You're making up words now?
>> [LAUGH]

51
00:02:44.802 --> 00:02:47.335
>> But Muda, that's kinda fun to say as

52
00:02:47.335 --> 00:02:52.288
well, I like this episode already.
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, we wanna remove waste.

53
00:02:52.288 --> 00:02:56.515
We wanna reduce Muda and
reducing or eliminating waste,

54
00:02:56.515 --> 00:03:01.269
eliminating Muda and I'm just
gonna keep saying that now just to

55
00:03:01.269 --> 00:03:04.390
keep Justin happy.
>> I tell you what, it puts a smile on my

56
00:03:04.390 --> 00:03:06.145
face every time you say it.
>> [LAUGH]

57
00:03:06.145 --> 00:03:07.079
>> I'm like-

58
00:03:07.079 --> 00:03:08.125
>> [LAUGH]

59
00:03:08.125 --> 00:03:08.721
>> [LAUGH]

60
00:03:08.721 --> 00:03:10.445
>> This is it, we're gonna start and

61
00:03:10.445 --> 00:03:13.774
make up our own language now,
but it's gonna be really, really,

62
00:03:13.774 --> 00:03:16.220
that's gonna be quite terrifying,
isn't it?

63
00:03:16.220 --> 00:03:20.430
It's gonna be a mixture
of sort of British and-

64
00:03:20.430 --> 00:03:23.155
>> And hillbilly, I don't know.

65
00:03:23.155 --> 00:03:26.420
[LAUGH]
>> British redneck, okay,

66
00:03:26.420 --> 00:03:29.210
that's my new title.
>> There you go.

67
00:03:29.210 --> 00:03:33.395
But Muda, anyway, we're removing waste--
>> We're removing Muda, yes.

68
00:03:33.395 --> 00:03:34.890
>> Inside of Lean.

69
00:03:34.890 --> 00:03:35.890
>> We are removing Muda.

70
00:03:35.890 --> 00:03:40.490
Do you remember when we looked at ITIL and

71
00:03:40.490 --> 00:03:44.870
we looked at efficiencies,
I talked about minimizing waste.

72
00:03:44.870 --> 00:03:49.400
And I actually talked about efficiency as
removing waste in three distinct areas.

73
00:03:49.400 --> 00:03:51.270
Do you remember what those areas were?

74
00:03:53.030 --> 00:03:54.840
>> Time.
>> Right.

75
00:03:54.840 --> 00:03:55.930
>> Money.

76
00:03:55.930 --> 00:03:56.430
>> Yeah.

77
00:03:56.430 --> 00:04:00.824
>> And wait, Time,

78
00:04:00.824 --> 00:04:04.950
money, I can't remember the third.
>> Skill.

79
00:04:06.140 --> 00:04:06.930
>> Skill, skill,

80
00:04:06.930 --> 00:04:09.149
for some reason I wanted to say people.
>> Right.

81
00:04:09.149 --> 00:04:11.009
>> But I'm not removing people, but

82
00:04:11.009 --> 00:04:15.410
removing waste of people skills.
>> Right, yeah, so in ITIL,

83
00:04:15.410 --> 00:04:19.380
we look at waste as, or
efficiencies as being

84
00:04:20.670 --> 00:04:25.440
as doing something as
quick as we possibly can.

85
00:04:25.440 --> 00:04:28.790
So with minimal wasted time,

86
00:04:28.790 --> 00:04:34.430
with minimal wasted money, and
with minimal wasted skills.

87
00:04:34.430 --> 00:04:37.050
So minimal waste in terms of time,
money and skills.

88
00:04:38.330 --> 00:04:42.970
That doesn't mean that we've got to
do everything as quick as possible

89
00:04:44.000 --> 00:04:48.510
just to get to an end goal, because
sometimes then, well, we miss things.

90
00:04:48.510 --> 00:04:52.010
Minimal waste is about doing
everything that we need to do, but

91
00:04:52.010 --> 00:04:54.900
doing it in an efficient way.

92
00:04:54.900 --> 00:04:58.790
So it's about making the best
use of our money also.

93
00:04:58.790 --> 00:05:03.170
So you don't necessarily want to buy
the most expensive item when you go

94
00:05:03.170 --> 00:05:06.490
into the store, but you don't
necessarily wanna buy the cheapest.

95
00:05:06.490 --> 00:05:11.630
You want to buy the one that is the most
cost-effective for what you need.

96
00:05:12.970 --> 00:05:16.774
And in terms of scale width, when we
talk about ITIL, we'll talk about having

97
00:05:16.774 --> 00:05:19.959
the right person with the right
skills to do that particular job.

98
00:05:19.959 --> 00:05:23.422
If somebody's overskilled,
they're not gonna work at 100%.

99
00:05:23.422 --> 00:05:27.287
And if somebody's underskilled,
then obviously, they're not going to be as

100
00:05:27.287 --> 00:05:31.085
efficient as somebody who's got
the appropriate number of skills.

101
00:05:31.085 --> 00:05:36.335
And we also talk about here in Lean,
we'll talk about quality too.

102
00:05:36.335 --> 00:05:41.732
So it's about delivering for
any service In a Lean environment,

103
00:05:41.732 --> 00:05:46.747
it's about delivering the right
amount of functionality.

104
00:05:46.747 --> 00:05:49.580
So you don't wanna over
deliver on the functionality.

105
00:05:49.580 --> 00:05:53.290
Ensuring that what we deliver
in a service is right.

106
00:05:53.290 --> 00:05:55.740
It meets the needs of the organization.

107
00:05:55.740 --> 00:05:57.870
But as I said,
you don't wanna over deliver, but

108
00:05:57.870 --> 00:06:00.060
you don't wanna under deliver either.

109
00:06:00.060 --> 00:06:02.980
So this is what we mean by minimal waste.

110
00:06:02.980 --> 00:06:07.360
Lean looks at process
improvements specifically, but

111
00:06:07.360 --> 00:06:12.300
ensuring that we have minimal waste
in terms of our processes, so

112
00:06:12.300 --> 00:06:16.210
ensuring that our
processes have consistency.

113
00:06:16.210 --> 00:06:20.940
That means that we deliver
the same objective every time,

114
00:06:20.940 --> 00:06:25.010
that we deliver the right objective.

115
00:06:25.010 --> 00:06:26.570
Not necessarily just the same but

116
00:06:26.570 --> 00:06:29.500
it's gotta be the right
outcome from every process.

117
00:06:29.500 --> 00:06:31.850
But we also want to do
it in an efficient way.

118
00:06:31.850 --> 00:06:35.230
So we might implement things that in ITIL,
we call models.

119
00:06:35.230 --> 00:06:39.310
And models, well,
they are predefined sets of steps.

120
00:06:39.310 --> 00:06:44.590
So they're predefined ways of
delivering a particular process or

121
00:06:44.590 --> 00:06:47.210
of achieving a specific objective.

122
00:06:47.210 --> 00:06:50.110
So in other words, I've seen this before.

123
00:06:50.110 --> 00:06:53.900
I've come across this
particular request before.

124
00:06:53.900 --> 00:06:56.610
So I don't need to go through
all of these steps again.

125
00:06:56.610 --> 00:06:58.950
I'm going to expedite these steps.

126
00:06:58.950 --> 00:07:00.660
And I'll give you an example.

127
00:07:00.660 --> 00:07:03.780
The first time somebody requests
a particular type of laptop,

128
00:07:03.780 --> 00:07:07.890
we're going to go through a full
evaluation process to ensure

129
00:07:07.890 --> 00:07:13.070
that that laptop does not have
a negative impact on our infrastructure.

130
00:07:13.070 --> 00:07:18.045
So the first time somebody comes to,
well, Nate, our IT guy.

131
00:07:18.045 --> 00:07:19.819
First time somebody goes to Nate and says,

132
00:07:19.819 --> 00:07:22.540
can I have this particular
laptop on our infrastructure?

133
00:07:22.540 --> 00:07:25.740
He's gonna do a full evaluation of that
laptop to make sure it's not gonna bring

134
00:07:25.740 --> 00:07:26.690
the infrastructure down.

135
00:07:28.000 --> 00:07:33.457
But then the next time somebody wants
exactly the same model make of laptop,

136
00:07:33.457 --> 00:07:37.990
then Nate doesn't need to go
through all of those steps again.

137
00:07:37.990 --> 00:07:41.106
All he needs to do is just say,
okay then, well,

138
00:07:41.106 --> 00:07:43.850
I can fill out this particular paperwork.

139
00:07:43.850 --> 00:07:48.060
I can ensure that we've got
all of our call logs, etc.

140
00:07:48.060 --> 00:07:51.260
And then I can just say, right,
well, I can build this laptop.

141
00:07:51.260 --> 00:07:52.030
It's not a problem.

142
00:07:52.030 --> 00:07:54.300
It's all because I've done it before.

143
00:07:54.300 --> 00:07:57.080
So it's about having minimal waste.

144
00:07:57.080 --> 00:08:01.615
The one thing that Nate's not going to do
though is to reinvent the wheel every time

145
00:08:01.615 --> 00:08:03.466
because that's not efficient.

146
00:08:03.466 --> 00:08:07.906
So he doesn't need to evaluate everything
every single time somebody puts in

147
00:08:07.906 --> 00:08:08.680
a request.

148
00:08:08.680 --> 00:08:10.690
It's not efficient.

149
00:08:10.690 --> 00:08:13.984
So what Nate's going to do is ensure
that he's going to document what he did

150
00:08:13.984 --> 00:08:14.730
the first time.

151
00:08:14.730 --> 00:08:20.250
And then the next time,
he's got those steps predefined.

152
00:08:20.250 --> 00:08:23.210
So what we're removing are things
like the duplication and

153
00:08:23.210 --> 00:08:27.220
the red tape and any constraints as well.

154
00:08:27.220 --> 00:08:30.110
So this is what Lean is all about.

155
00:08:30.110 --> 00:08:33.850
So let's think about Lean and
in terms of SIAM.

156
00:08:34.870 --> 00:08:39.960
And in terms of the SIAM ecosystem, well,
of course everything that we should

157
00:08:39.960 --> 00:08:45.450
be doing, across all of our service
providers, should be in an efficient way.

158
00:08:45.450 --> 00:08:48.380
That's what we're aiming for,
efficiency and effectiveness.

159
00:08:48.380 --> 00:08:52.130
We're aiming for
that delivery of value to our customers.

160
00:08:52.130 --> 00:08:58.290
So when you think about Lean and
you think about SIAM, well I expect that

161
00:08:58.290 --> 00:09:05.060
the Siam ecosystem should be implemented
in a lean manner, in a lean way.

162
00:09:05.060 --> 00:09:08.450
It should be implemented in
a way that reduces waste.

163
00:09:08.450 --> 00:09:13.562
We want to aim for efficiency in
absolutely everything that we do,

164
00:09:13.562 --> 00:09:17.851
so there is a perfect synergy
between lean and Siam, and

165
00:09:17.851 --> 00:09:21.703
in fact I expect us to
implement Siam In a lean way.

166
00:09:21.703 --> 00:09:25.670
I don't expect us to implement
SIAM in any other way.

167
00:09:25.670 --> 00:09:29.950
If we are implementing
this SIAM ecostructure

168
00:09:29.950 --> 00:09:33.560
in a way that's not efficient,
then we're implementing it wrong.

169
00:09:34.990 --> 00:09:40.070
Now, I do want to bring in the complexity,
though.

170
00:09:40.070 --> 00:09:45.400
And with our ecosystem we have that
complexity of multiple service providers.

171
00:09:47.030 --> 00:09:53.860
How do we ensure that each of our
service providers act in a lean way?

172
00:09:53.860 --> 00:09:58.920
How do we ensure that each of
our service providers also

173
00:09:58.920 --> 00:10:05.089
works in a way that is the most
efficient way for our organization?

174
00:10:05.089 --> 00:10:06.360
Not for their organization.

175
00:10:06.360 --> 00:10:08.990
Let's be fairly mercenary
about this process.

176
00:10:08.990 --> 00:10:12.300
In that particular service provider,

177
00:10:12.300 --> 00:10:18.130
what we are concerned with is their
impact on us as the service integrator.

178
00:10:18.130 --> 00:10:20.480
As delivering value to our customer,

179
00:10:20.480 --> 00:10:25.070
we are concerned about how
their ways of working and

180
00:10:25.070 --> 00:10:30.400
how their standard processes
impacts our ecosystem.

181
00:10:30.400 --> 00:10:35.160
We are not necessarily, well,
we shouldn't be concerned about how

182
00:10:35.160 --> 00:10:38.630
their way of working impacts
their entire environment.

183
00:10:38.630 --> 00:10:43.610
Although that may be part of the criteria
when it comes to selecting that

184
00:10:43.610 --> 00:10:44.810
service provider.

185
00:10:44.810 --> 00:10:49.881
We may want a service provider that
can demonstrate some Lean principles,

186
00:10:49.881 --> 00:10:54.962
because we want to have that assurance
that they are certainly efficient.

187
00:10:54.962 --> 00:11:01.040
So when it comes to Lean, and I've got
a slide here that I've prepared for you.

188
00:11:01.040 --> 00:11:02.540
So as we've got written down here,

189
00:11:02.540 --> 00:11:07.400
then, these questions in front of us,
these come from our Lean guidance, and

190
00:11:07.400 --> 00:11:12.930
this is what we should be asking in our
SIAM ecosystem for all of our processes.

191
00:11:12.930 --> 00:11:16.000
So look at this,
what value does this process add?

192
00:11:16.000 --> 00:11:19.380
What value does this particular
step in the process add,

193
00:11:19.380 --> 00:11:24.380
does any step in our process repeat
any other step from our process?

194
00:11:24.380 --> 00:11:28.142
So think about duplication,
think about efficiencies,

195
00:11:28.142 --> 00:11:31.901
this is not necessarily going
to be an easy thing to apply,

196
00:11:31.901 --> 00:11:36.987
because we're going to be applying this
across all of our service providers.

197
00:11:36.987 --> 00:11:41.519
So across the entire ecosystem,
and as we've already mentioned,

198
00:11:41.519 --> 00:11:46.292
it's quite relatively easy to implement
in our service integrator but

199
00:11:46.292 --> 00:11:50.904
not necessarily so easy to implement
across our service providers,

200
00:11:50.904 --> 00:11:55.542
especially when we're talking
about external service providers.

201
00:11:55.542 --> 00:12:01.376
So Lean is absolutely perfect model
to be applying across our ecosystem,

202
00:12:01.376 --> 00:12:06.195
it's certainly something that we
want to be aspiring to, we have to

203
00:12:06.195 --> 00:12:11.840
consider the complexity of applying
this to all of our service providers.

204
00:12:11.840 --> 00:12:14.260
And we have to understand that
this has got to be planned.

205
00:12:14.260 --> 00:12:17.582
Whether we are talking
about existing processes,

206
00:12:17.582 --> 00:12:23.090
which most service providers will already
have long before the ecosystem evolves.

207
00:12:23.090 --> 00:12:26.680
Long long before we've decided
to implement an ecosystem.

208
00:12:26.680 --> 00:12:29.940
These service providers will
have already had these processes

209
00:12:29.940 --> 00:12:32.490
in place within their organization.

210
00:12:32.490 --> 00:12:37.479
So that means that not only will they
have to move towards our processes

211
00:12:37.479 --> 00:12:41.541
to ensure the consistency
across our service delivery,

212
00:12:41.541 --> 00:12:45.106
but when we move them towards,
to our processes.

213
00:12:45.106 --> 00:12:48.944
When we evolve and
when we transition them to our processes,

214
00:12:48.944 --> 00:12:53.320
we have to make sure that our
processes can meet their requirements.

215
00:12:54.380 --> 00:12:58.470
That our processes can accommodate
their ways of working.

216
00:12:58.470 --> 00:13:02.640
But we also have to ensure that our
processes are essentially Lean.

217
00:13:03.820 --> 00:13:08.710
So that brings us into COBIT, or
COBITs as Justin liked to call it.

218

That's why we have the service integrator.

484
00:30:51.104 --> 00:30:54.049
The relationship goes through
the service integrator and

485
00:30:54.049 --> 00:30:57.243
the service integrator has
a relationship with the customer.

486
00:30:57.243 --> 00:30:58.320
So A is wrong.

487
00:30:59.400 --> 00:31:03.620
C talks about a consistent method of
quantifying, tracking and managing.

488
00:31:03.620 --> 00:31:07.761
We already know that is down for
improvement and we know that.

489
00:31:07.761 --> 00:31:12.081
We mentioned this earlier on in
a previous question, that was CSI and

490
00:31:12.081 --> 00:31:17.146
then provided a structured approach that
delivers projects on time to budget and

491
00:31:17.146 --> 00:31:19.544
at the appropriate level of quality.

492
00:31:19.544 --> 00:31:22.071
That's project management.

493
00:31:22.071 --> 00:31:23.553
We're not dealing with project management.

494
00:31:23.553 --> 00:31:27.583
We're dealing service management
in our SIAM ecosystem.

495
00:31:27.583 --> 00:31:30.064
This is Service Integration and
Management.

496
00:31:30.064 --> 00:31:32.182
This is not project management.

497
00:31:32.182 --> 00:31:37.762
So the answer to this one is B,
defining process ownership.

498
00:31:37.762 --> 00:31:40.890
So every single process.

499
00:31:40.890 --> 00:31:41.390
It was B.

500
00:31:43.100 --> 00:31:50.162
So now we have completed then part one
of examination review, how did you do?

501
00:31:50.162 --> 00:31:54.536
Well, when you come back for
part two in our next episode,

502
00:31:54.536 --> 00:31:59.555
we'll be going through questions
11 through to question 20.

503
00:31:59.555 --> 00:32:03.885
So for now, I'm gonna sign off and
I'm gonna say, we'll see you in part two.

504
00:32:03.885 --> 00:32:08.229
But I'm Jo Peacock with ITProTV.

505
00:32:08.229 --> 00:32:11.912

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.680
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.680 --> 00:00:11.121
Hi and welcome to your
SIAM Foundation examination review.

3
00:00:11.121 --> 00:00:14.640
This is our second part of
our examination review.

4
00:00:14.640 --> 00:00:19.420
I'm Joy Peacock and
I'm gonna be taking you through questions

5
00:00:19.420 --> 00:00:24.470
11 through to questions 20 of your
SIAM Foundations sample test.

6
00:00:24.470 --> 00:00:29.400
In episode one, we looked at questions
one through to questions ten.

7
00:00:29.400 --> 00:00:33.630
And so now, we're just gonna jump straight
in and we're gonna take a look at question

8
00:00:33.630 --> 00:00:37.820
11 and we're gonna go through to
question 20, and we'll see how you did.

9
00:00:37.820 --> 00:00:42.640
Okay, so question 11 then, in the Run and
Improve stage of the SIAM roadmap,

10
00:00:42.640 --> 00:00:46.250
which activity provides an environment for
collaborative working?

11
00:00:46.250 --> 00:00:49.230
Well, the answer is,
our management structures.

12
00:00:49.230 --> 00:00:51.290
Operation of our management structures,

13
00:00:51.290 --> 00:00:54.320
that's the day to day
management structure.

14
00:00:54.320 --> 00:00:56.940
Let's take a look at why
it's not any of the others.

15
00:00:56.940 --> 00:00:59.350
Managing performance and improvement,

16
00:01:00.740 --> 00:01:05.220
managing performance is not going to
necessarily foster collaboration.

17
00:01:05.220 --> 00:01:08.770
And in fact, it could have a detrimental
effect on collaboration too,

18
00:01:09.820 --> 00:01:14.660
especially if we're managing performance
and we see some issues that exist maybe

19
00:01:14.660 --> 00:01:17.830
between relationships,
between our service providers.

20
00:01:17.830 --> 00:01:23.010
That if we don't manage that in
a sympathetic way and in a way that

21
00:01:23.010 --> 00:01:27.720
is impartial, then it could actually have
a detrimental effect on collaborations.

22
00:01:27.720 --> 00:01:31.932
So we've got to be very careful and
we know, when we discussed this in our

23
00:01:31.932 --> 00:01:35.664
episodes, when we looked at
the collaborative environment and

24
00:01:35.664 --> 00:01:40.243
the environment and the complexity of
managing all of our service providers.

25
00:01:40.243 --> 00:01:44.256
That it's really important that we
maintain those relationships and

26
00:01:44.256 --> 00:01:46.310
that they are good relationships.

27
00:01:46.310 --> 00:01:49.090
Then we have monitoring our audit and
compliance.

28
00:01:49.090 --> 00:01:53.200
Well, audit and compliance,
what I said in the previous answer,

29
00:01:53.200 --> 00:01:56.060
in answer A, that we didn't want
to use a baseball bat approach and

30
00:01:56.060 --> 00:02:01.240
we didn't want to be too regimented, well
this is exactly what we don't want to do.

31
00:02:01.240 --> 00:02:05.800
Audit and compliance are going to measure
whether our service providers are actually

32
00:02:05.800 --> 00:02:07.600
doing something.

33
00:02:07.600 --> 00:02:10.520
And compliance is just, it has a word

34
00:02:10.520 --> 00:02:15.040
that has a negative connotation when
it comes to dealing with collaboration.

35
00:02:15.040 --> 00:02:20.010
We want to foster an environment of
collaboration amongst our service

36
00:02:20.010 --> 00:02:20.560
providers.

37
00:02:20.560 --> 00:02:26.440
If they feel as though they're going to
be penalized for lack of collaboration,

38
00:02:26.440 --> 00:02:31.400
then that makes them even more determined,
should we say,

39
00:02:31.400 --> 00:02:34.600
to stick to the terms and
conditions of the contract.

40
00:02:34.600 --> 00:02:36.880
So, we wanna foster collaboration.

41
00:02:36.880 --> 00:02:41.120
We certainly don't want to be going in
there with a baseball bat approach.

42
00:02:42.410 --> 00:02:44.300
Operation of our governance boards?

43
00:02:44.300 --> 00:02:47.340
Well, we know that governance
sits at a strategic level.

44
00:02:47.340 --> 00:02:48.860
It sits at a very high level and,

45
00:02:48.860 --> 00:02:52.790
therefore, they're gonna be looking
at this from a strategic perspective.

46
00:02:52.790 --> 00:02:58.860
Governance boards are going to be asking
us, they're going to be requesting,

47
00:02:58.860 --> 00:03:02.790
they're gonna be advising, they're
going to be devising strategies for

48
00:03:02.790 --> 00:03:06.590
us to manage our service
providers in a collaborative way.

49
00:03:07.825 --> 00:03:11.345
But the question says, and
this is where you've got to be careful,

50
00:03:11.345 --> 00:03:15.085
remember my acronym RTFQ,
read the full question.

51
00:03:15.085 --> 00:03:20.121
The question says,
which activity provides an environment?

52
00:03:20.121 --> 00:03:24.153
This doesn't say,
which activity then encourages, or

53
00:03:24.153 --> 00:03:30.130
insures that we encourage collaborative
working, that would be governance.

54
00:03:30.130 --> 00:03:32.100
This is providing an environment.

55
00:03:32.100 --> 00:03:35.180
This is more about at the core phase.

56
00:03:35.180 --> 00:03:38.320
This is management of that environment.

57
00:03:38.320 --> 00:03:43.450
And so our management structures,
will demonstrate collaborative working.

58
00:03:43.450 --> 00:03:47.680
And our management will also ensure that
we are working in a collaborative way

59
00:03:47.680 --> 00:03:50.390
across our service providers.

60
00:03:50.390 --> 00:03:54.570
So, the answer to this one is,
D, cuz this is about operating,

61
00:03:54.570 --> 00:03:57.440
this is about running
the management structures,

62
00:03:57.440 --> 00:04:01.186
not about governance at a high level but
the management itself.

63
00:04:01.186 --> 00:04:06.120
So question 12, which of these,

64
00:04:06.120 --> 00:04:11.885
be careful of these questions, and, again,
I use the acronym, read the full question,

65
00:04:11.885 --> 00:04:17.140
okay, which of these is not a challenge
related to technology practice for

66
00:04:17.140 --> 00:04:19.800
creating a tooling strategy?

67
00:04:19.800 --> 00:04:22.340
Which of these is not a challenge?

68
00:04:23.720 --> 00:04:28.000
Ineffective legacy tools, we looked at
this when we looked at an episode where we

69
00:04:28.000 --> 00:04:33.650
looked at technology practices and we know
that legacy tools are a challenge to us.

70
00:04:33.650 --> 00:04:38.180
For implementing a tooling strategy for
our

71
00:04:38.180 --> 00:04:43.000
service management itself, we know that
legacy tools are a huge, big challenge.

72
00:04:43.000 --> 00:04:46.330
Legacy tools are something
that we have to accommodate.

73
00:04:46.330 --> 00:04:49.420
And some service providers
have legacy tools and

74
00:04:49.420 --> 00:04:51.613
we may have to accommodate those.

75
00:04:51.613 --> 00:04:56.505
That involves generally some translation,
some data sharing, and

76
00:04:56.505 --> 00:05:01.030
that in itself can bring many,
many challenges.

77
00:05:01.030 --> 00:05:05.117
Gaps between process activities or
be careful,

78
00:05:05.117 --> 00:05:08.314
the process should be defined first.

79
00:05:08.314 --> 00:05:12.740
We configure the process,
and then, we go and

80
00:05:12.740 --> 00:05:17.630
source a tool that will
facilitate the processes.

81
00:05:19.320 --> 00:05:23.930
So the reason why gaps between
process activities aren't a challenge,

82
00:05:23.930 --> 00:05:26.180
is because we defined the process first.

83
00:05:26.180 --> 00:05:28.277
The tool simply does
what you tell it to do.

84
00:05:28.277 --> 00:05:31.310
The tool is not a process.

85
00:05:31.310 --> 00:05:34.040
This is quite a common misconception,
by the way.

86
00:05:34.040 --> 00:05:37.512
Incident management is that tool,
no it's not,

87
00:05:37.512 --> 00:05:41.590
incident management
are the steps that you perform.

88
00:05:41.590 --> 00:05:44.210
Incident management is the process.

89
00:05:44.210 --> 00:05:47.890
The tool is what it facilitates
incident management.

90
00:05:47.890 --> 00:05:52.640
So, gaps between process activities
is not a challenge of a tool set.

91
00:05:52.640 --> 00:05:57.488
It's a challenge for a process owner,
but it's not a challenge for tool set

92
00:05:57.488 --> 00:06:02.280
because a tool set simply facilitates
whatever process it's been given.

93
00:06:02.280 --> 00:06:07.409
Defining the scope of the tool set, yes,
that is a challenge, because we need

94
00:06:07.409 --> 00:06:12.539
to know exactly who is going to be using
that tool set, in terms of which service

95
00:06:12.539 --> 00:06:17.720
providers, and also which processes
are going to be using that tool set.

96
00:06:17.720 --> 00:06:22.090
So which processes do we have to configure

97
00:06:22.090 --> 00:06:27.057
in order to use the tool set
to facilitate those processes?

98
00:06:27.057 --> 00:06:31.968
A non-compliant service providers
definitely, definitely a challenge here

99
00:06:31.968 --> 00:06:36.010
because, of course,
we've got multiple services providers.

100
00:06:36.010 --> 00:06:40.288
What if one of our service providers
decided not to use out tool set or

101
00:06:40.288 --> 00:06:43.988
maybe they don't want to use our tool set.

102
00:06:43.988 --> 00:06:47.706
But then we've got all of our other
service providers using that tool set and

103
00:06:47.706 --> 00:06:51.890
there's some consistency there, but then
there's not a huge amount of consistency

104
00:06:51.890 --> 00:06:55.577
because we've got one or two service
providers that don't want to use it.

105
00:06:55.577 --> 00:06:58.403
This is a challenge for
the service integrator, so

106
00:06:58.403 --> 00:07:03.460
this is definitely a challenge when
we're creating a strategy for tooling.

107
00:07:03.460 --> 00:07:08.120
Because we have to ensure consistency
across all of our service providers.

108
00:07:08.120 --> 00:07:11.260
Watch out for the word,
not in this question.

109
00:07:11.260 --> 00:07:17.150
If you miss this word,
you will be looking for the wrong answer.

110
00:07:17.150 --> 00:07:21.710
So easily done, and it's something that
I tell everybody at foundation level,

111
00:07:21.710 --> 00:07:24.480
with every test, and
I know that I use my acronym.

112
00:07:24.480 --> 00:07:28.430
And some people have a bit of a giggle
about that and I don't know why.

113
00:07:28.430 --> 00:07:31.140
RTFQ though, read the full question.

114
00:07:31.140 --> 00:07:35.190
Every single word that's in that
question is really important.

115
00:07:35.190 --> 00:07:37.100
And if you miss words like not and

116
00:07:37.100 --> 00:07:41.700
should and most, you'll be heading for
the wrong answer.

117
00:07:41.700 --> 00:07:44.300
So be very careful of that, very careful.

118
00:07:45.300 --> 00:07:47.330
Let's take a look at Question 13 then.

119
00:07:47.330 --> 00:07:50.869
So, in a hybrid service
integrator structure, so

120
00:07:50.869 --> 00:07:55.000
we know a hybrid is a mixture
of that internal and external.

121
00:07:55.000 --> 00:08:01.430
Which two parties collaborate to provide
the service integrated capability?

122
00:08:01.430 --> 00:08:03.880
Well, I've just given you
the answer to that, haven't I?

123
00:08:03.880 --> 00:08:08.010
It's internal to the customer
environment and external.

124
00:08:08.010 --> 00:08:09.000
So which two?

125
00:08:09.000 --> 00:08:11.120
Well, its got to be a, hasn't it, yeah?

126
00:08:11.120 --> 00:08:13.380
I've given you the answer to that.

127
00:08:13.380 --> 00:08:17.656
It's not gonna be the customer and
internal service integrator,

128
00:08:17.656 --> 00:08:23.340
because internal means internal to the
customer, so that doesn't make any sense.

129
00:08:23.340 --> 00:08:25.700
And we've got no mention
of any external in there.

130
00:08:26.770 --> 00:08:28.540
An external and a lead supplier,

131
00:08:28.540 --> 00:08:33.620
well a lead supplier is another
type of service integrator.

132
00:08:33.620 --> 00:08:37.890
And that's also external, so we're
talking external, and external again,

133
00:08:37.890 --> 00:08:39.250
that doesn't make any sense.

134
00:08:40.390 --> 00:08:44.080
Internal service integrator,
internal to the organization and

135
00:08:44.080 --> 00:08:46.090
retained capabilities.

136
00:08:46.090 --> 00:08:49.560
Retained capabilities are also
internal to the customer.

137
00:08:50.590 --> 00:08:55.890
So that's the customer's governance,
that's the customer's strategy.

138
00:08:55.890 --> 00:08:57.820
So, that doesn't make any sense either,

139
00:08:57.820 --> 00:09:01.071
because again,
we're talking internal and internal.

140
00:09:01.071 --> 00:09:04.750
The only one that mentions internal and
external is A,

141
00:09:04.750 --> 00:09:08.370
and that's your hybrid structure,
a mixture of the both.

142
00:09:10.570 --> 00:09:16.210
So which of these, then, is a challenge
when facing cross-functional teams?

143
00:09:16.210 --> 00:09:18.540
Let's take a look at 14 then.

144
00:09:18.540 --> 00:09:23.490
Which of these is the main challenge
associated with cross-functional teams?

145
00:09:23.490 --> 00:09:28.590
There I go again, yeah, reading the full
question, picking out these words.

146
00:09:28.590 --> 00:09:30.460
They're really important.

147
00:09:30.460 --> 00:09:33.430
It's not asking which is a challenge,

148
00:09:33.430 --> 00:09:36.420
cuz potentially in these answers
all of them could be a challenge.

149
00:09:36.420 --> 00:09:40.395
It's asking which one of these is
the main challenge associated with

150
00:09:40.395 --> 00:09:41.490
cross-functional teams.

151
00:09:42.580 --> 00:09:45.500
And of course the answer there is A,
conflicting objectives, and

152
00:09:45.500 --> 00:09:48.330
organizational strategies and
working practices.

153
00:09:48.330 --> 00:09:49.480
That's the main challenge.

154
00:09:50.630 --> 00:09:53.200
What about B,
gaps between process activities?

155
00:09:53.200 --> 00:09:55.120
It's that a main challenge?

156
00:09:55.120 --> 00:09:58.980
It's a challenge, but
it's not necessarily a main challenge.

157
00:10:00.720 --> 00:10:03.710
Inability to map end to end workflows.

158
00:10:03.710 --> 00:10:08.680
Well, an inability is not a challenge,
that simply means that you're unable to.

159
00:10:08.680 --> 00:10:12.840
So that's not necessarily a challenge,
that's more like an ability and

160
00:10:12.840 --> 00:10:15.270
the fact that you don't have that ability.

161
00:10:15.270 --> 00:10:17.810
You should be able to map
the end to end workflow.

162
00:10:17.810 --> 00:10:20.640
If you can't, then simply,

163
00:10:20.640 --> 00:10:26.138
you won't really have
a cross-functional team necessarily.

164
00:10:26.138 --> 00:10:31.490
So it's a challenge, but it's a side
challenge and it's not the main challenge.

165
00:10:31.490 --> 00:10:36.330
The lack of architecture, again,
very similar to that inability.

166
00:10:36.330 --> 00:10:39.470
A lack of architecture means
that you can't do anything.

167
00:10:39.470 --> 00:10:43.230
So that's another challenge to
managing cross functional teams,

168
00:10:43.230 --> 00:10:47.840
that's just a challenge in itself,
that is a huge challenge.

169
00:10:49.100 --> 00:10:53.618
But the main challenge here associated
with managing cross functional teams is A,

170
00:10:53.618 --> 00:10:55.370
it's conflicting objectives.

171
00:10:55.370 --> 00:10:59.700
It's having organizational strategies
that again maybe conflict, and

172
00:10:59.700 --> 00:11:02.670
working practices that conflict.

173
00:11:02.670 --> 00:11:05.700
Because every single service
provider organization

174
00:11:05.700 --> 00:11:07.900
will work in a completely different way,
and

175
00:11:07.900 --> 00:11:13.130
I know that I've said this multiple
times throughout our episodes.

176
00:11:13.130 --> 00:11:17.310
Every single service provider
organization works differently,

177
00:11:17.310 --> 00:11:19.040
every organization works differently.

178
00:11:19.040 --> 00:11:22.760
Even though they are in
the same industry sector,

179
00:11:22.760 --> 00:11:26.270
they still nevertheless
will work differently.

180
00:11:26.270 --> 00:11:31.550
And therefore ensuring
that the priorities and

181
00:11:31.550 --> 00:11:35.430
the objectives and the strategies don't
object is always going to be a challenge,

182
00:11:35.430 --> 00:11:38.950
and it's one that the service
integrator has to overcome.

183
00:11:40.520 --> 00:11:42.390
So question number 15.

184
00:11:42.390 --> 00:11:46.040
Which operational role is responsible for

185
00:11:46.040 --> 00:11:50.540
discussing lessons learned
arising from a major incident?

186
00:11:51.910 --> 00:11:56.460
And that is the incident management forum.

187
00:11:57.740 --> 00:12:03.140
Lessons learned from a major incident,
a working group

188
00:12:03.140 --> 00:12:09.200
is convened to discuss something
that we're working on right now.

189
00:12:09.200 --> 00:12:12.267
It's an issue that we have right now.

190
00:12:12.267 --> 00:12:13.972
The forum will discuss,

191
00:12:13.972 --> 00:12:18.764
a process forum will discuss what's
gone wrong with the process, and

192
00:12:18.764 --> 00:12:23.798
what has gone right with the process
that we can apply to another process or

193
00:12:23.798 --> 00:12:28.530
to another part of that process, so
that we can improve the process.

194
00:12:29.650 --> 00:12:34.900
So the forum will look back
as to what's happened, and

195
00:12:34.900 --> 00:12:38.640
looking at the question, and
again, read the full question.

196
00:12:38.640 --> 00:12:42.200
Which role is responsible for
discussing lessons learned?

197
00:12:43.450 --> 00:12:49.620
This is not about finding out what's gone
on and working out how to fix something.

198
00:12:49.620 --> 00:12:54.740
That would be a working group and
that would be an active major incident.

199
00:12:56.370 --> 00:12:58.770
But we're not talking about
an active major incident.

200
00:12:58.770 --> 00:13:02.300
In this question,
we're talking about lessons learned.

201
00:13:02.300 --> 00:13:06.330
And a lessons learned exercise,
called a major incident review,

202
00:13:06.330 --> 00:13:11.550
and we conduct a major incident review
after the incident has been resolved.

203
00:13:11.550 --> 00:13:14.180
So we do that in the process forum,
which is A.

204
00:13:15.720 --> 00:13:19.650
Of course, the change advisory board,
well, the change advisory board evaluates

205
00:13:19.650 --> 00:13:26.090
and assesses change, and integrated means
integrated across our service providers.

206
00:13:26.090 --> 00:13:31.440
So no, that will not discuss lessons
learnt from a major incident.

207
00:13:31.440 --> 00:13:34.130
And, again,
the major incident working group, well,

208
